questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles, as seen in the biopsy.

Image: Vacuolar myopathy in McArdle's disease

Features:

  • Poor exercise tolerance
  • Abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%)
  • Very low blood lactate after exercise

Image: Myophosphorylase enzyme histochemistry showing

(A) Normal muscle

(B) - McArdle's disease

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and asprin

questions.solution:
The next appropriate step in the management of a pregnant woman with a prosthetic valve on warfarin therapy at 36 weeks of gestation is to stop warfarin and start heparin. 

Warfarin is safe and effective in preventing thromboembolism in the mother during the 2nd trimester. However, it is teratogenic and can lead to miscarriage, stillbirths, and fetal embryopathy if used in the first trimester. Heparin is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but is less effective than warfarin.

The American College of Chest Physicians Guidelines for anticoagulation of pregnant women:

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it by heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to 12th week of gestation. 
  • This is then replaced by warfarin tablet 3 mg daily to be taken at the same time each day and continued up to 36 weeks.
  • Thereafter it is replaced by heparin which is discontinued 6 hours just before delivery
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after the cesarean section.
  • UFH (unfractionated heparin), LMWH, and Warfarin therapy are not contraindicated in breastfeeding.

Heparin should be discontinued just before delivery. If delivery occurs before discontinuation and there is extensive bleed­ing, then iv protamine sulfate can be given. Warfarin or heparin anticoagulation can be restarted after 6 hours of vaginal delivery, usually without any problem.

Summary:

Period of gestation Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

 LMWH or UFH
13 to 36 weeks Warfarin
36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery LMWH or UFH
6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)
 (LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin, UFH- Unfractionated heparin)

Note:

Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

questions.text: The USG of a child with recurrent urinary tract infection shows the following image. The probable diagnosis is ____
questions.solution:
The ultrasound shows the typical 'key-hole' sign in which the bladder and the proximal urethra is dilated; it is seen in cases of a posterior urethral valve.

Posterior urethral valve:

  • Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder
  • Babies present with urinary infection in the neonatal period or with uraemia and renal failure
  • The investigation of choice is micturating cystourethrography
  • Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the special programme for Research and Training in Tropical Disease (TDR) strategy of the WHO?
questions.solution:
The disease not included in the special programme for Research and Training in Tropical Disease is tick borne encephalitis.

The TDR is sponsored by the WHO, UNICEF, UNDP and World Bank.

The diseases included under this programme are:

  • Chagas disease
  • Dengue
  • Ebola
  • Helminthiasis
  • Leishmaniasis
  • Leprosy
  • Lymphatic filariasis
  • Malaria
  • Onchocerciasis
  • Schistosomiasis
  • Trypanosomiasis
  • Tuberculosis

The programme is sponsored by the WHO, UNICEF, UNDP, and World Bank.
World Neglected Tropical Diseases Day, observed annually on January 30th since 2021, promotes progress, unites efforts, and encourages action toward eliminating 20 tropical diseases that disproportionately affect underdeveloped regions. In 2024, the theme is "Unite. Act. Eliminate" encouraging global collaboration.

questions.text: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows placental tissue invading the myometrium of the uterus suggestive of placenta increta. 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be:

  • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta 
  • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.text: A young patient underwent surgery under General Anaesthesia with O2, Nitrous oxide, and Desflurane. Just after extubation, the patient started to desaturate. On auscultation, there are bilateral basal crepitations.  What can be the most common cause?
questions.solution:
The complication in this patient associated with extubation is negative pressure pulmonary edema ,which is a dangerous and potentially fatal condition.

Complications associated with extubation:

  • Laryngospasm and bronchospasm
  • Negative pressure pulmonary edema
  • Upper airway obstruction
  • Hypoventilation
  • Hemodynamic changes (hypertension, tachycardia)
  • Coughing and straining leading to surgical wound dehiscence
  • Laryngeal or airway edema
  • Paradoxical vocal cord motion
  • Arytenoid dislocation
  • Aspiration

Factors associated with increased extubation risk:

  • Airway risk factors
    • known difficult airway
    • airway deterioration (bleeding, edema, trauma)
    • restricted airway access
    • obesity and obstructive sleep apnea
    • aspiration risk
  • General risk factors
    • cardiovascular disease
    • respiratory disease
    • neuromuscular disease
    • metabolic derangements
    • special surgical requirements

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The superior border of the epiploic foramen is formed by the caudate lobe of the liver.

Epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow) is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. 

                Epiploic foramen
Boundaries Structures
Anterior Right free margin of lesser omentum (hepatoduodenal ligament) containing the portal triad (bile duct, hepatic artery and portal vein)
Posterior (SIT)

Suprarenal gland

Inferior vena cava

T12 vertebra
Superior Caudate process of liver
Inferior

First part of duodenum 

Horizontal part of the hepatic artery

 

Clinical note: Pringle manoeuvre is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

Related Pearl: Relations of Lesser sac and Foramen of Winslow (Important)

Relations of Epiploic foramen

Anterior

Hepatoduodenal ligament containing Hepatic artery, Portal vein, and Common bile duct

Posterior

IVC, Rt.suprarenal gland, and body of T12 vertebra

Superior

Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior

1st part of duodenum

Relations of Lesser Sac

Anterior

Caudate lobe of liver, lesser omentum, stomach, first 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed (pancreas, splenic artery, left kidney and suprarenal gland, the commencement of abdominal aorta & coeliac artery, left crus of the diaphragm, splenic flexure of the colon, and the transverse mesocolon)

Upper Border

Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Lower border

Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the OPD. His parents describe that the boy had an episode of abnormal jerking movements that started in his left hand and gradually involved the entire arm. Following this, the patient experienced weakness and difficulty in moving the left arm for about an hour. Two similar episodes have also occurred in the past. His father is a known case of epilepsy. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the first-line drug used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes Jacksonian march followed by Todd’s palsy. These are characteristics of a focal seizure. Among the given drugs, the first-line drug for focal seizures is carbamazepine which is a sodium-channel blocker.

First-line agents in the treatment of focal seizures:

  • Lamotrigine
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Levetiracetam

Carbamazepine is most effective in complex partial seizures. It is also used in GTCS and simple partial seizures, trigeminal and related neuralgias, manic depressive psychosis.

Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in water retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause leukopenia, aplastic anemia, or hepato-toxicity and hyponatremia in the elderly

questions.text: A 42-year-old male sustained a head injury in a road traffic accident after which he was unable to recall his name, the name of the place he lives in, or his date of birth but was able to remember the events such as his marriage. His non-declarative memory is intact. Which of the following areas of the brain is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The patient had a loss of memory associated with the facts (semantic memory), suggestive of injury to the prefrontal cortex or anterior/lateral temporal cortex.

Forms of memory:

Explicit/declarative memory: Memory of factual knowledge about the people, places, things, and events. It is associated with consciousness/awareness. They are of two types:

  • Semantic memory (facts) E.g., Knowing the capital of India, date of birth, names of people etc. The parts of the brain involved are the lateral & anterior temporal cortex; and prefrontal cortex.
  • Episodic memory (events) E.g., Recalling the events occurred on the first day in college. The parts of the brain involved are the hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and neocortex. 

Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory: It does not require being conscious or aware. They are of 4 types:

  • Procedural memory refers to skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic, such as riding a bicycle or driving a car. It is processed in the striatum.
  • Priming refers to the facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them. It is dependant on the neocortex.
  • Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitization. It is dependent on various reflex pathways.
  • Associative learning includes classical and operant conditioning in which one learns about the relationship between one stimulus and another. It is dependent on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 29-year-old presented with purple, pruritic plaques on the flexor aspect of the left forearm for 7 months. On examination, Koebner's phenomenon was elicited. A skin biopsy showed Civatte bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with symptoms of purple, itchy, plaque exhibiting Koebner's phenomenon is suggestive of lichen planus. It is characterized by the presence of Civatte bodies or colloid bodies.

The colloid body is a homogeneous, eosinophilic, rounded body resulting from the degeneration and death of keratinocytes, particularly in the lower layers of the epidermis. This structure is found in various lichenoid tissue reactions.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. Microscopy will show :

  • Acanthosis of the epidermis.
  • Irregular thickening of the granular layer.
  • Hyperkeratosis.
  • Colloid (civatte) bodies due to degenerating basal epidermal cells. 
  • Sawtooth appearance of rete ridges.
  • Max Joseph spaces due to focal separation from the dermis.
  • Band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae (seen below). They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia. 

Option A: Copper penny bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Option C: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale.

Option D: Kamino bodies are eosinophilic globules seen in the epidermis or in the region of the dermal-epidermal junction in the spindle and epithelioid cell (Spitz) naevi.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image : Trachonychia

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum

Psoriasis

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Vitiligo

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: All of the following findings indicate uterine scar rupture, except ______.

choices.text: Loss of station of presenting part

questions.solution:
Maternal bradycardia is not a feature of uterine rupture.

Uterine rupture is one in which all the layers of the uterus (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa ) are disrupted any time after 28 weeks of pregnancy.

A previous history of classical cesarean section, obstructed labor, manual removal of placenta, dilatation, and curettage are some risk factors for uterine scar rupture.

Clinical features of scar dehiscence:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia
  • Maternal hypotension
  • Uterine scar tenderness
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria 
  • Loss of station of presenting part

Management of uterine scar rupture includes resuscitation and laparotomy. Following resuscitative measures and laparotomy, subtotal hysterectomy is usually done unless there is sufficient reason to preserve the uterus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the casualty with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. His blood sugar levels are 421 mg/dl and his urine ketones are 3+. He is started on IV normal saline and insulin infusion. Which of the following electrolyte abnormality should he be monitored for?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, which is treated with insulin infusion. Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis are at risk for developing hypokalemia after the initiation of treatment.

Diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA) is a life-threatening condition characterized by elevated blood sugar levels and ketosis. Patients present with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, confusion, and abdominal pain.

DKA is managed with a combination of intravenous fluids, insulin, and potassium correction.

At presentation, these patients have normal to high potassium levels in spite of excessive potassium loss. This is because potassium moves out from the cell to the extracellular space as a result of acidosis.

Once insulin is administered and acidosis is corrected, the potassium ion flows back into the cells causing hypokalemia. Hence the physician should be vigilant and initiate intravenous potassium correction once insulin is given to the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a MINOR criteria in the 2015 revised Jones criteria in moderate to high risk population ?
questions.solution:
According to the modified Jones criteria (2015), in moderate to high-risk populations polyarthralgia is not a minor criterion. It is considered a major criteria.

Whereas in low-risk populations, polyarthralgia is considered as a minor criterion.

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HBsAg-positive male was planned for hernia surgery. Catheterization was done before the procedure.  According to the BMW management rules, the cover of Foleys catheter is discarded in ___________.
questions.solution:
The plastic cover of the Foleys catheter is discarded in a Black bag. 

Foley's catheters are packaged in plastic covers to keep them sterile. The plastic cover is not a biomedical waste. It is a general (municipality) waste; hence, it is discarded in the black bag.

As per Bio-Medical Waste Management Rules, the general waste generated must be disposed of according to the provisions of Solid Waste Management Rules:

  • Green bins (for recyclable waste) and Blue bins (for non-recyclable waste) are used
  • Black plastic bags are used inside these bins

Disposal of:

  • Cover of Foley's catheter: Black bag
  • Foley's catheter: Red bag

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was admitted for an RTA. He had severe blood loss and developed a crush injury to his left leg. His BUN to serum creatinine ratio is 24. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and BUN to serum creatinine ratio of >20 are suggestive of prerenal AKI(Acute kidney injury) due to hypovolemia.

Nephrotoxic drugs, fat embolism and rhabdomyolysis cause renal AKI where BUN to serum creatinine ratio is <10:1. Rhabdomyolysis leads to muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury by the following mechanisms:

  • Direct toxic effect of myoglobin and heme on the PCT
  • Tubular obstruction by precipitation of pigmented casts
  • Renal vasoconstriction can cause FeNa < 1 (unlike other renal causes of AKI)
The factors that can help differentiate prerenal and renal causes of AKI are as follows:
Indices Prerenal Renal
Spot urine sodium (mEq/L) <20 >40
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% >2%
Fractional excretion of urea (FEUrea) <35% >35%
Urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) >500 <350
BUN to serum creatinine ratio >20:1 <10:1
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1
Urinary sediment Nil or hyaline casts only Renal tubular epithelial casts, muddy brown granular casts

questions.text: Which murmur is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given above is of an ejection systolic murmur.

This murmur starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2.

Ejection systolic murmur(ESM) is most commonly heard in aortic stenosis and in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.

Auscultation of ESM in aortic stenosis.

  • In the early stages, an early systolic ejection sound may be heard. It disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid.
  • As the stenosis worsens, the LV systole gets prolonged and there is delayed closure of the aortic valve. This leads to the narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, it might lead to the paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 sounds may be heard in severe cases when the diastolic and systolic functions of the left ventricle have been reduced.
  • Murmur: The murmur in aortic stenosis is an ejection systolic murmur. The murmur radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect
Inspiration (↑venous return to right atrium) ↑ intensity of right sided sounds
Hand grip (↑afterload ) ↑ intensity of MR, AR and VSD murmurs
↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
MVP: delayed onset of click / murmur
Valsalva-Phase II, standing up (↓ preload) ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur
Rapid squatting (↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)		 ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
↑ intensity of AS, MR and VSD murmurs
MVP: later onset of click / murmur

questions.text: A cattle farmer presented with a lesion on the arm. Gram staining showed gram-positive rods with square ends with a central spore. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive rod with square ends giving it a characteristic box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive, endospore-forming (non-bulging spores), rod-shaped bacterium. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule.

The image shows the characteristic box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance of bacillus anthracis on Gram staining.

Bacillus anthracis is a category A bioterrorism agent which can cause:

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is caused by contact with infected animal/ animal products. It is seen in tanners and hide-porters. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops in about 1–7 days. This develops into a vesicle that later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a malignant pustule. The majority of the patients recover spontaneously, but a few may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax: It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis and sepsis. 
  • Intestinal anthrax: It is caused rarely, by ingesting infected animals. 

The image below shows necrotic eschar seen in anthrax:

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Microscopy of the smears shows bacilli arranged end to end in the form of long chains. This is called bamboo stick appearance.
  • Under the low-power microscope, the edge of the colony is composed of long, interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling locks of matted hair, called Medusa head appearance.

Fluid or pus from cutaneous lesions, pleural fluid, blood, or CSF can be cultured on:

  • Nutrient agar- frosted glass appearance
  • Gelatin stab culture- Inverted fir tree appearance
  • Blood agar- Non-hemolytic colonies
  • Solid medium with penicillin- String of pearls appearance

Other options:

Option A: Infection with Bacillus cereus causes food poisoning with a longer incubation period of 8-16 hours. But patients usually have a history of consumption of fried rice.

Option C: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Burns infections
  • Opportunistic and nosocomial infections
  • Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum
  • Green-nail syndrome

Option D: Brucellosis is a zoonotic infection transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products from goats, sheep, cattle, pigs, and other animals. Clinically, patients may present with an acute infection comprised of undulant fever (Rising and falling fever). They may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is seen in tumour lysis syndrome (TLS). 

It is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy. It is characterized by:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia 
  • Acidosis
  • Acute renal failure

The management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol 
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate(Only advisable if rasburicase is not readily available. The level of calcium should be serially monitored)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is presbyopic. The power of his prescription glasses should be _______.
questions.solution:
The power of the prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man should be +2D.

This condition of falling near vision due to age-related decrease in the amplitude of accommodation or increase in punctum proximum is called presbyopia.

Roughly, the power of prescription glasses age-wise is as follows:

Age Power
40–44 years +1D
45–49 years

+1.5D
50–54 years +2D
55–60 years +2.5D

questions.text: The instrument used to measure corneal thickness is the _________
questions.solution:
The pachymeter is used to measure corneal thickness.

Options a and d: A keratometer (ophthalmometer) measures the curvature of the anterior surface of the cornea at two points about 1.25 mm on either side of its center.

Option c: Specular microscopy is the study of the corneal endothelium under a very high magnification (100 times greater than slit lamp biomicroscopy).

questions.text: A child on workup is found to be suffering from a rare form of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency for which he has developed high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the best dietary advice for the patient?

choices.text: High protein and low carbohydrate intake
High carbohydrate and low fat intake
High fat and low carbohydrate intake

questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency(PDH) can be due to a defect in any one/more of the components of the PDH enzyme complex. Patients are advised to follow a high fat and low carbohydrate intake.

In pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, there is a defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex, leading to impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This results in the accumulation of pyruvate and subsequent conversion to lactate, causing lactic acidosis and high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

To provide an alternative fuel source for the body, patients with pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency are often advised to follow a high-fat and low-carbohydrate diet. By reducing the intake of carbohydrates, which are metabolized to pyruvate, and increasing the intake of fats, which can be metabolized via alternative pathways, the reliance on the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex can be minimized.

Therefore, option C (High fat and low carbohydrate intake) is the most appropriate dietary advice for a patient with pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency and high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Other options:

Option A: High protein and low carbohydrate intake - This option is incorrect because a high protein intake would still involve the metabolism of amino acids, which can contribute to the production of pyruvate and further exacerbate the metabolic acidosis in pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency. 

Option B: High carbohydrate and low-fat intake - This option is incorrect because pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency impairs the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, resulting in the accumulation of pyruvate and subsequent lactic acidosis. 

Option D: Only carbohydrate intake henceforth - This option is incorrect because pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency specifically affects the metabolism of carbohydrates, leading to the accumulation of pyruvate. Relying solely on carbohydrate intake would exacerbate the metabolic acidosis by increasing pyruvate levels.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with erectile dysfunction, his internal pudendal artery was found to be stenosed. Which of the following​ vessels is this a branch of?

choices.text: Anterior division of internal iliac artery
Posterior division of internal iliac artery

questions.solution:
The anterior division of the internal iliac artery gives rise to the internal pudendal artery.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the anterior division of internal iliac artery:

  • Obturator artery
  • Superior vesical artery(in males)
  • Inferior vesical artery (in males)
  • Inferior gluteal artery
  • Middle rectal artery
  • Vaginal artery (in females)
  • Uterine artery (in females)
  • Internal pudendal artery

Branches of the posterior division of internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, bluish discoloration was present over the left 9th and 10th rib area. On asking the patient to take a deep breath, he winced due to pain in the left shoulder region.  Identify the most likely sign elicited here.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette mentions pain over the left shoulder tip on inspiration. This is known as Kehr's sign, seen in splenic trauma.

Blunt trauma to the spleen results in torsion of short gastric vessels in the gastrosplenic ligament leading to subphrenic hematoma. The irritation at the left hemidiaphragm by subphrenic hematoma leads to positive Kehr's sign.

The initial investigation for abdominal injury in patients who are hemodynamically unstable is FAST (focused assessment with sonography in trauma) to explore for free fluid.

In all hemodynamically stable patients, CT is the investigation of choice for identifying and characterizing splenic injuries.

Other options:

Option A- Courvoisier's sign is palpable gall bladder in the presence of jaundice due to periampullary carcinoma.

Option B- Cullen's sign is dark bluish discoloration around the umbilicus due to hemoperitoneum.

Option C- Ballance sign is a sign of splenic injury. Persistent dullness on the left side of the abdomen due to early coagulation of blood from the spleen is a positive sign. Shifting dullness can be present on the right side.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

questions.text:
Consider the causes of alopecia. Which among the following cause(s) non-scarring alopecia?

1. Alopecia areata
2. Telogen effluvium
3. Androgenic alopecia
4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Non-scarring alopecia is caused by androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium.

Alopecia areata

It is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases, including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

Telogen effluvium 

It is a type of nonscarring alopecia that is marked by diffuse shedding of normal hair. This occurs due to premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle.  It can be either acute or chronic.

Acute telogen effluvium occurs 2–3 months after a stressful event such as high fever, surgery, starvation, and hemorrhage. Hormonal fluctuations during the postpartum period can trigger it (telogen gravidarum). Telogen effluvium can result in a diffuse reduction in hair density but never total baldness. It generally resolves spontaneously.

Chronic telogen effluvium is used to describe the diffuse shedding of telogen hair for more than 6 months. Common causes include thyroid disorders, iron-deficiency anemia, and malnutrition. 

Androgenetic alopecia

It is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fiber production by follicles and miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone, an androgenic metabolite, is implicated in the etiology. It is of two types: male-pattern and female-pattern hair loss. Male-pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.  Female-pattern hair loss involves the mid-frontal scalp diffusely. There is no or minimal involvement of the temporal region.

Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a scalp condition that affects post-menopausal women in particular and frequently involves the eyebrows. It is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text:
A patient presented with a lesion, as shown in the image below. She is an immunocompromised patient currently on HAART. What are the systemic antifungal drugs that can be added along with the HAART in this patient?

Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART)

choices.text: Inj. Amphotericin B 4-8 weeks, followed by oral itraconazole
Inj. Amphotericin  B 8 weeks, followed by oral posaconazole
Inj. Fluconazole, followed by oral fluconazole
Inj. Amphotericin  B, followed by flucytosine

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. The patient can be given injection amphotericin B for 8 weeks, followed by oral posaconazole.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis. It is typically seen in immunocompromised patients and invades blood vessels.

The rhino-orbital-cerebral is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients present with rhinitis, eye or facial pain, and facial numbness, followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and swelling along with blurry vision.

Diagnosis is made by biopsy with histopathologic examination. The biopsy shows characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

The image below shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis:

Treatment of the infection includes 4 steps:

  1. Initiation of therapy (amphotericin B) as early as possible. Posaconazole can also be used in the management of this condition.
  2. Surgical debridement
  3. Reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors
  4. Treatment of underlying malignancy if present

Amphotericin B is a broad-spectrum antifungal. It binds to ergosterol in the fungal membrane and forms pores or channels in the fungal cell membrane. This allows the leakage of cytosolic molecules and ions, leading to a loss of membrane integrity.

Other options:

Option A: Itraconazole can be used for the treatment of chronic aspergillosis if there is resistance or failure of voriconazole. Ketoconazole is used for both dermatophytosis and deep mycosis, but it has been replaced by itraconazole.

Option C: Fluconazole is used for the treatment of candidiasis and cryptococcosis.

Option D: Amphotericin B in combination with 5-flucytosine is used as induction treatment for cryptococcal meningitis. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Human skeletal remains were found in an abandoned basement in Wuhan. Which of the following would indicate that the victim was a Caucasian?

choices.text: Lack of the third upper molar

questions.solution:
Carabelli’s cusps are most commonly seen only in Caucasian races and rare in the other major racial groups. These are small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars.

The image below shows Carabelli’s cusps seen in Caucasian races.

Features of mongoloid dentition include:

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a central depression
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • Taurodontism (bull-tooth) - Pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep
  • A congenital lack of the third upper molar

The image below shows shovel-shaped upper central incisors seen in mongoloid races compared to non-shovel shaped incisors:

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abnormal skin pigmentation over his forearms and face. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. Which stain has been used to identify his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features suggest a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. Prussian blue stain is used to identify this condition. On this stain, the hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes appear blue in color. 

Hemochromatosis occurs due to excessive iron absorption that leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs. It involves liver, pancreas, myocardium,endocrine organs (pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid, and parathyroid glands), joints and skin.

It can be primary hemochromatosis (inherited disorder) or secondary hemochromatosis (accumulation of iron due to other causes). The adult form of primary hemochromatosis usually occurs due to mutations of the HFE gene.

Clinical features include:

  • Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly
  • Diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of pancreatic islets
  • Slate-grey color skin pigmentation due to increased melanin production
  • Cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy)
  • Acute synovitis due to excessive deposition of calcium pyrophosphate that produces disabling polyarthritis known as pseudogout
  • Atrophic testes secondary to pituitary involvement

The image below shows a slide of liver microscopy that has been stained with Perls Prussian blue stain. The hepatocellular iron appears blue due to the stain.

Other options:

Option A: Masson trichrome stain can be used to demonstrate collagen. 

Option B: Congo red stain can be used to demonstrate the accumulation of amyloid.

Option C: Sudan black stain is a fat-soluble dye that is used to demonstrate lipid inclusions.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in Asherman's syndrome?

choices.text: Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol

questions.solution:
Asherman's syndrome has Normal FSH, Normal LH, and Normal estradiol.

Asherman's syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium, most commonly as a result of trauma to the endometrium following pregnancy-related curettages. Oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae. The laboratory investigations and hormonal assays are generally normal in isolated cases of uterine synechiae. Diagnosis is generally established using hysteroscopy. Moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome. Treatment is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis. 

Condition Lab markers 
1. Sheehan's syndrome C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
2. Premature Ovarian failure D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
3. PCOS B. High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
4. Asherman's syndrome A. Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol

Premature Ovarian failure or premature menopause is the development of menopause before the age of 40 years. It is diagnosed when at least 2 serum FSH levels are elevated (>40 mIU/l) when measured at least 1 month apart in a woman <40 years. The other findings consistent with POF include low estradiol and an elevated FSH/LH ratio.

PCOS is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrone(E1) levels are elevated but estradiol level in PCOS is low in comparison to Estrone (E1). 

Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy is hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it's called Sheehan's syndrome. Affected women may present with panhypopituitarism and may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to the deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to the deficiency of gonadotropins).

questions.text: A woman is planning a trip to Morocco, which is endemic for yellow fever. As per travel regulations, she receives the yellow fever vaccine. After how many days following vaccination is she eligible to travel?
questions.solution:
This woman is eligible to travel to the endemic area 10 days after being vaccinated for yellow fever. This period is required for the majority of vaccine recipients to develop immunity.

The 17D vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, administered subcutaneously.  It is valid for a lifetime beginning 10 days after vaccination.  The incubation period of yellow fever is 3–6 days. Unvaccinated people are required to remain quarantined for 6 days (maximum period of incubation).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with resting tremors, difficulty in initiating movements, poor balance, and frequent falls. What is the site of the lesion of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Parkinson's disease, and the site of the lesion is substantia nigra.

Parkinson's disease is a degenerative condition of the dopamine-secreting neurons of the substantia nigra. Patients present with muscular rigidity, involuntary resting tremors of the hands, akinesia - difficulty in initiating movement - and postural instability. On examination, cog-wheel rigidity and a shuffling gait are seen. Dysphagia, speech disorders, sleep disturbances and cognitive impairment are also seen. 

The substantia nigra is a part of the basal ganglia of the brain. It is a part of the ancillary putamen circuit. Neurons from the substantia nigra project to the caudate nucleus and putamen, known as the nigrostriatal pathway. They secrete dopamine, which is inhibitory. Thus, the caudate nucleus and putamen send continuous excitatory signals to the corticospinal tract. This contributes to the rigidity seen in Parkinsonism.  

The primary treatment for Parkinson's disease is L-dopa. It is converted to dopamine in the brain and reduces the motor symptoms. 

Other options:

Option B: Thalamus plays a role in memory, emotions, the sleep-wake cycle, and in the processing of sensory information and relaying it to the cortex. Lesions in the thalamus are seen in a multitude of disorders including vascular diseases, metabolic disorders, inflammatory diseases, and infections.

Option C: A lesion in the globus pallidus can give rise to athetosis. This involves spontaneous and continuous writhing movements of the hand, arm, neck, or face.

Option D: A lesion in the subthalamic nucleus causes sudden violent involuntary, and flinging movements confined to one side of the body, commonly affecting the proximal muscles of the limbs, a condition called hemiballismus. The movements are seen contralateral to the side of the lesion.

questions.text: A patient with lung cancer was found to have the following finding on his anterior abdominal wall. On examination, you observe that the blood flow in these blood vessels is completely downwards. CT chest showed obstruction of a thoracic vessel. Which of the following is false about the same?

choices.text: Pierces the pericardium at 3rd costal cartilage
Enters the heart at the level of 4th intercostal space
Receives azygous vein below sternal angle

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of obstruction of the superior vena cava. It does not pierce the pericardium at the level of 3rd costal cartilage.

The superior vena cava pierces the pericardium opposite 2nd costal cartilage (angle of Louis/sternal angle), at the level of T4-T5 intervertebral disc. It also receives the azygous vein about 2 cm below the sternal plane at the level of T5 vertebra. 

It enters the right atrium at the level of the 4th intercostal space.

Superior vena cava syndrome:

Obstruction of superior vena cava due to metastatic cancers (eg. lung cancer, breast cancer, etc.) can result in reduced venous return from head and neck and upper extremities. It presents with swelling of the neck and face, dyspnea, headache, dizziness, and hemoptysis. Symptoms are aggravated by bending forwards.

On examination, the following may be seen

  • Dilated neck veins
  • Proptosis
  • Papilledema
  • Increased collateral veins on the anterior chest wall - flow is completely downward

CT-chest shows an absence or reduction of the opacification of the central veins and the presence of prominent collateral venous circulation.

 

Related Pearl: Angle of Louis

The angle of Loius (sternal angle) is formed by the manubriosternal joint at the level of 2nd costal cartilage anteriorly.

A plane joining the angle of Louis to the intervertebral disc between T4 and T5, called the sternal plane marks the following anatomical landmarks: 

  • Separates superior mediastinum form inferior mediastinum. 
  • Marks the position superior limit of pericardium.
  • Bifurcation of pulmonary trunk
  • Bifurcation of trachea (newer studies shows its lower)  
  • Origin of arch of aorta.
  • Site where superior venacava pierces the pericardium.

questions.text: A patient suffered burns from an overhead electric supply line. What is the leading cause of death in such burns?
questions.solution:
The leading cause of death in electrical injuries is cardiac arrest. This is due to ventricular fibrillation which is the most common cause of death following both high- and low-voltage electrical injuries.

  • Low-voltage injuries cause small, localised, deep burns. They can cause cardiac arrest through pacing interruption without significant direct myocardial damage.
  • High-voltage injuries cause external and internal burns. The fash ignites the patient’s clothes and causes a flame burn. They cause damage to the subcutaneous tissues and muscles. The entry and exit points and subcutaneous tissue between these two points are damaged.

Carbon monoxide poisoning is the most common immediate cause of death from fire. Sepsis is the leading cause of death after burn injury.

questions.text: What is the minimum acceleration required to call a non-stress test reactive?
questions.solution:
The nonstress test is a screening test for fetal wellness. It describes fetal heart rate acceleration (measured by a Doppler) in response to fetal movements (perceived by the mother). 

On conducting an NST:

  • Reactive NST: When 2 or more accelerations of more than 15 beats per minute above the baseline and longer than 15 seconds in duration are present in a 20-minute observation. Reassure the patient and send her back home.
  • Non-reactive NST: When there is an absence of any fetal reactivity Biophysical profile(BPP) has to be assessed.

questions.text: Which of the following was recommended by the Shrivatsav committee?
questions.solution:
The village health guide scheme was proposed by Shrivastav committee. 

Village health guide:

  • Guidelines for choosing VHG 
    • Person can be from either sex but must be resident of the village.
    • Person must know to read and write and have education up to 6th grade.
    • He/she must be able to spare around 2-3 hours a day for community work.
    • He/she must be acceptable to all parts of the community.
  • VHGs were trained for 2-3 months before beginning of work.
  • Norm was 1 VHG per 1000 population.

Other Options:

Option A: The health survey and development committee (or Bhore committee) started the 3 million plan. 

Option B: The integration of health services was proposed by Jungalwallah committee.

Option C: The multipurpose worker scheme was by Kartar Singh committee.

  • Also known as Health Survey and Planning Committee

  • Outlined responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme

  • Family planning assistants were for family planning work and basic health workers for other activities.

questions.text: With respect to the condition shown below, choose the false statement.

choices.text: Loss of abduction of the arm
Loss of lateral rotation of the arm
Loss of sensation in the lateral 2 fingers
Loss of flexion of the elbow

questions.solution:
The image shows Erb's palsy (waiter's tip deformity) in which there is a loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid.

It is caused by injury to C5, C6 and rarely C7. It is seen most commonly in babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery.

The following are seen in Erb's palsy:

  • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Loss of flexion of the elbow
  • Loss of supination of the forearm
  • Loss of biceps, supinator and inverse supinator jerks
  • Loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies:

Features Erb's palsy Klumpke's Palsy
Causes

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

Hyperabduction of shoulder. Lower plexus root involved.

Eg. Difficult breech delivery, Holding on to something (e.g. a branch) during a fall, Cervical rib syndrome, Scalene syndrome
Nerves roots  C5 and C6 C8 and T1
Muscles involved

Deltoid, Supraspinatus - loss of abduction 

Infraspinatus - loss of lateral rotation 

Biceps brachii - loss of flexion and supination

Position of the upper limb/hand Policeman's tip/Waiter's tip/ Porter's tip position Claw hand
Sensory loss +/- Along the outer aspect of the arm Along the medial border of forearm and hand
ANS signs  Absent

Horner syndrome

questions.text: The characteristic features of Tourette's disorder include all of the following except ______.

choices.text: Persistence of tics  for at least 6 months
No tic-free period of more than three consecutive months in 1 year.
Presence of at least one vocal tic

questions.solution:
Tourette's syndrome is diagnosed when there is a persistence of tics for at least 1 year.

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics. Coprolalia may be seen, which refers to vocal tics that can be socially offensive, such as loud grunting, barking noises, or shouted words, which may be obscenities.

Over half of the children diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome also meet the criteria for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD).

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome include:

  • Presence of both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics, at some time during the illness. Although both need not occur simultaneously.
  • The tics may wax and wane in frequency but have persisted for more than 1 year since the onset of the first tic.
  • Onset is before age of 18 years.
  • The disorder is not attributable to the physiological effects of substance abuse (e.g. cocaine) or underlying medical condition (e.g., Huntington’s disease, postviral encephalitis).
Management:

Behavioural interventions are the first line of treatment. Pharmacotherapy must be included in severe cases. Tics require treatment when they cause social and emotional problems, depression, or isolation. 

In mild cases, where academic performance or social life is not affected, the first line of management is to provide psychoeducation, followed by a wait-and-watch strategy.

For severe cases:

  • Behavioural interventions:
    • Habit reversal
    • Exposure and response prevention
  • Pharmacological treatment:
    • Antipsychotics like risperidone
    • Noradrenergic agents like atomoxetine
    • Alternative treatments such as tetrabenazine, topiramate, and tetrahydrocannabinol

questions.text: The ferrous form is converted to ferric form in the basolateral aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Hephaestin (Hp) converts Fe2+(ferrous) to Fe3+ (ferric), which is transported in plasma bound to transferrin.

Other Options:

  • Ferric Reductase (DCYTB): Converts dietary Fe3+ to absorbable Fe2+ in the apical/luminal aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell.
  • Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1): Transports Fe2+ from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal mucosal cell.
  • Ferroportin 1 (FPN1): Transports Fe2+ from the mucosal cell into the interstitial fluid and then into the plasma.

questions.text: A patient in the emergency department has the following findings on ECG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lateral wall myocardial infarction is the likely diagnosis in this patient.

The patient's ECG demonstrates elevated ST segments in lead I and aVL. In such an infarction, the left anterior descending or the left circumflex coronary is involved.

Additionally, a posterior wall myocardial infarction is also likely in this patient due to ST segment depression in lead III. Posterior wall infarctions are difficult to diagnose and usually are associated with other myocardial infarctions such as lateral wall infarction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the clinical presentation of mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia is thymoma. 

Thymoma refers to the tumours of the thymic epithelial cells. They commonly occur in the anterior mediastinum. Clinical features can be chest pain, dyspnea, cough, or superior vena cava syndrome.

It is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like myasthenia gravis, pure red cell aplasia, or hypogammaglobulinemia. It is rarely associated with limbic encephalitis, hemolytic anaemia, aplastic anaemia, and other autoimmune conditions like Sjogren's syndrome.

Pure red cell aplasia: It is a marrow disorder where only erythroid progenitors are suppressed. The complete absence of red cell progenitors is seen in severe cases.

Hereditary causes include Diamond-Blackfan anaemia or congenital pure red cell aplasia.

Acquired causes:

  • Cancer
    • Thymoma
    • Lymphoid malignancies (eg. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, large granular lymphocytosis)
    • Paraneoplastic to solid tumors
  • Connective tissue disorders with immunologic abnormalities
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Viruses
    • Persistent B19 parvovirus, hepatitis, adult T cell leukemia virus, Epstein-Barr virus
  • Drugs
    • Phenytoin, azathioprine, chloramphenicol, procainamide, isoniazid
  • Multiple endocrine gland insufficiency
  • Antibodies to erythropoietin
  • Idiopathic

Other options:

Option B: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma can cause pure red cell aplasia but it commonly presents as peripheral adenopathy rather than mediastinal mass.

Options C and D: Germ cell tumors and bronchogenic carcinoma are not commonly known to be associated with red cell aplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following will not commonly present as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dermatophytic infection in the groin region. It is not caused by Aspergillus.

Dermatophytes include 3 genera: Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc.
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but not nails. It contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. 
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails but not hair. Floccosum is the only species in the genus

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with a history of recurrent episodes of bloody stool. The following investigation is performed, and the child was found to have Meckel diverticulum. Which of the following radionuclide agents is used for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of  99mTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy, which is the most accurate diagnostic test for Meckel diverticula in children.

Meckel diverticulum results from the failure of the yolk sac to close during fetal life. It is located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. It is usually detected incidentally, but can present with gastrointestinal bleeding. The bleeding is usually from a chronic acid-induced ulcer adjacent to a Meckel diverticulum that contains ectopic gastric mucosa.

Radionuclide like the 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in the diverticulum.

 Other uses of 99mTc-pertechnetate:

  • Thyroid imaging
  • Parathyroid imaging to distinguish it from the thyroid gland
  • Testicular imaging

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with hematuria and a mass in the left kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of an elderly male presenting with painless hematuria, renal mass, and an axial renal cortical phase CECT image showing renal lesions with irregular enhancement is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50–70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It usually presents with painless gross hematuria, flank pain, or painless flank mass.

Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC. On CT, small lesions enhance homogeneously, whereas larger lesions have irregular enhancement due to areas of necrosis. The clear cell subtype may show much stronger enhancement, which is a differential for angiomyolipoma. Still, it is essential to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

T1-weighted MRI is often heterogeneous due to necrosis, hemorrhage, and solid components. T2-weighted MRI is hyperdense for clear cell RCC and hypodense for papillary RCC. Thus, a T2-weighted MRI can be used for histological diagnosis. Contrast-enhanced MRI is the investigation of choice for detecting vascular invasion of RCC.

Other options:

Option A: Renal angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. The mean age of presentation is 43 years, and there is a female predilection. CT findings show cortical lesions that demonstrate macroscopic fat (less than -20 HU) and absence of ossification or calcification.

Option B: Renal oncocytomas are relatively benign in nature and usually present in the 6th to 7th decade. An important point regarding this tumor is its similarity with RCC, and hence, it is very difficult to differentiate between them preoperatively. A sharp central stellate scar may be seen in one-third of the cases. But RCC may also show this stellate scar appearance in some cases.

Option D: Renal cysts is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions needs evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification of renal cysts is given above.

Image showing a simple renal cyst:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about cystosarcoma phyllodes?

choices.text: Bulky and fungates through the skin
Treatment is wide excision with margin

questions.solution:
Malignant cystosarcoma phyllodes metastasize via the bloodstream.

Phyllodes tumour (sero-cystic disease of Brodie or cystosarcoma phyllodes):

  • It originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. Most phyllodes tumors behave benignly, with local recurrences occurring in a small proportion of cases.
  • Affects women >40 years of age, but can be seen in younger women.
  • The histopathology shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor.
  • Distant metastasis is a feature of malignant phyllodes tumours. It is most common in the lungs.
  • Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.
  • Clinical features:
    • Large, sometimes massive, with an unevenly bosselated surface
    • Ulceration of overlying skin occurs because of pressure necrosis
    • Remains mobile on the chest wall
  • Treatment:
    • Tumours are treated by excision with margins of at least 1 cm to prevent local recurrence

Malignant phyllodes tumours contain liposarcomatous or rhabdomyosarcomatous elements rather than fibrosarcomatous elements.

questions.text: The most common variety of cancer cervix is ______
questions.solution:
The most common variety of cancer cervix is squamous cell carcinoma.

The two most common histologic subtypes of cervical cancer are squamous cell and adenocarcinoma. Squamous cell tumours make up 70% and arise from the ectocervix.

The clear cell type vaginal and cervical adenocarcinomas are most closely associated with DES- diethylstilbestrol exposure.

questions.text: A patient chronically on corticosteroids was diagnosed with a complicated cataract. His slit lamp examination finding is shown below. What is this type of cataract called?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of chronic use of steroids along with slit lamp examination showing a granular appearance in the lens is suggestive of posterior subcapsular cataract.

Posterior subcapsular opacity lies in front of the posterior capsule and has a granular or plaque-like appearance on oblique slit lamp examination .On retro- illumination , black vacuoles are seen which are swollen migratory lens epithelial cells called as Wedl cells (or bladder cells). As it is in the centre of the eye it has a significant impact on vision. Symptoms like glare are often perceived and aggravated by miosis , near visual activity and in bright light. 

The following conditions mainly present with a posterior subcapsular cataract and therefore have a similar clinical picture:

  • Complicated cataract
  • Steroid-induced cataract
  • Radiation

 These cataracts present with central opacities and has difficulty in seeing objects in bright light because:

  • When a person is exposed to bright light, the pupil undergoes miosis (constriction).
  • These central opacities come to lie directly in the path of axial rays, allowing no transmission of rays.
  • Therefore, there is an inability to see objects in bright light.
  • However, in dim light, when there is mydriasis (dilatation of pupil), some rays may pass around the opacity, leading to an improvement in dim-light vision.

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract

questions.text: A 1.5 kg child born at 32 weeks by LSCS, presents with moderate respiratory difficulty  (RR: 70/min, SpO2:  92%). Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of respiratory distress syndrome in this preterm neonate is providing CPAP-continuous positive airway pressure.

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is a common cause of respiratory distress in a newborn, presenting within hours after birth. RDS primarily affects preterm neonates, and infrequently, term infants and occurs due to a deficiency of surfactant.

Warm, humidified oxygen is started to maintain a saturation of 90-95%. 100% oxygen is harmful, causing increased oxidative stress and retinopathy of prematurity. CPAP started at birth is the choice for the management of a preterm infant at risk for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) without respiratory failure. Early nasal CPAP has been shown to lower mortality and risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

In neonates with RDS who fail CPAP and require intubation and mechanical ventilation, treatment with endotracheal surfactant should be initiated by the INSURE method.INSURE- INtubate SURfactant and Extubate. Other techniques such as MIST (minimally invasive surfactant therapy) or LISA (less invasive surfactant administration), in which a small feeding tube, rather than an endotracheal tube (ETT), is used to deliver intratracheal surfactant to a spontaneously breathing infant on CPAP.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought to the hospital with a fever and respiratory rate of 60/min. The child is irritable, feeds well, has no stridor, no chest indrawing, and no convulsions. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a 3-month-old child with fast breathing and fever is suggestive of pneumonia.

The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

1. Pneumonia: with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.

Age of child Fast breathing RR
<2 months  >60 breaths/min
2-12 months  >50 breaths/min
1-5 years  >40 breaths/min

2. Severe pneumonia: pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy.

Danger signs of pneumonia in children include: 

  • Not able to drink 
  • Persistent vomiting 
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious 
  • Stridor in a calm child 
  • Severe malnutrition 

If a child has only fever, cough or cold, it is categorised as no pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient who underwent skull base surgery developed drooping of the left side of his face and loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the general sensation over the tongue is intact. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of damage to the facial nerve above the level of the stylomastoid foramen, resulting in injury to chorda tympani nerve.

Taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by chorda tympani nerve, whereas general sensation is carried by the lingual nerve. 

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Anterior 2/3rds

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)
