questions.text: An infant is brought with complaints of constant watering of eyes with mucopurulent discharge and a non-pulsatile swelling as shown in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of excessive watering of the eyes and swelling over the lacrimal sac in an infant is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis.

Congenital dacryocystitis is the chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac due to the accumulation of secretions. This occurs secondary to an obstruction along the course of the nasolacrimal duct.

Clinical features are epiphora progressing to mucopurulent discharge, positive regurgitation test, and swelling over the lacrimal sac area.

The treatment plan is decided according to the age at presentation. Massaging over the lacrimal sac and topical antibiotics are used as first-line treatment.

Management

  • Massage over the lacrimal sac area along with topical antibiotics is a conservative management method that can cure symptoms in infants up to 6-9 months
  • Probing of the nasolacrimal duct with Bowman's probe can be attempted if symptoms do not resolve within 6 months. 
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy may be done if the child is brought late or if all other treatment methods fail. 

Other options:

Option A: Anterior encephalocele is a pulsatile swelling in the superomedial part of the orbit. It is caused by the herniation of intracranial content through a congenital defect in the skull.

Option C: Syringomas are benign proliferations of eccrine sweat glands and are noted as multiple small papules. 

Option D: Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous, painless swelling of the Meibomian gland in the eyelid.

questions.text: A patient with obsessive-compulsive disorder picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face, as given in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This given image shows acné excoriée on the chin of a male with compulsive picking of the face using nail pliers and tweezers.

Acné excoriée is regarded as a self‐inflicted skin condition in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is mostly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are: 

  • Body dysmorphic disorder - Some patients have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Eating disorders - reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenaged age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne. 

Option B: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face and presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

Options C: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses which commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne mechanica describes acne that occurs at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet resulting in comedo formation. Examples include ‘fiddler’s neck’, which may occur on the neck of violin players, and is characterized by well‐defined plaques with the presence of comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation

questions.text: The blood-testis barrier is formed by______

choices.text: Tight junctions between adjacent leydig cells
Tight junctions between adjacent sertoli cells

questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is formed by the tight junctions between adjacent Sertoli cells.

This Sertoli-Sertoli cell tight junctions divide the seminiferous epithelium into 2 compartments:

  • Basal compartment - contains the spermatogonia and early-stage primary spermatocytes.
  • Adluminal compartment - contains later-stage primary spermatocytes and all subsequent stages of sperm cells.

It imparts a selective permeability, allowing few substances such as testosterone to cross and preventing noxious substances that might damage the developing sperm. It also protects sperm from antibodies by creating a specialized, immunologically safe microenvironment for developing sperm.

 BELOW DIAGRAM - 

1- basal lamina, 2- spermatogonia, 3- 1st order spermatocyte, 4- 2nd order spermatocyte, 5- spermatid, 6 mature spermatids, 7 Sertoli cell, 8 tight junctions(Blood- Testis Barrier)

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked as A in the given image below?
questions.solution:
The cadaveric image shown is of the left lung. The arch of aorta is related to the area marked as A in the given image. 

The left lung is divided into superior and inferior lobes by the oblique fissure. The pulmonary root connects the medial surface of the lung to the heart and trachea. It is formed by structures that enter or leave the hilum. The left root is present inferior to the arch of the aorta.

The vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum from above to below is:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

The arrangement of the lung hilar structures from the anterior to posterior in the order is:

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the left lung.

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the right lung.

questions.text: A patient presented the clinical finding shown in the image. His showed serum cholesterol is 283 mg/dL and his serum LDL is 202 mg/dL. His triglyceride levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia(FH)(type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia). This is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors and Apo B100.

This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk of developing atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over the Achilles tendon and the dorsum of the hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL >190 mg/dl, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins.

Recent drugs for the specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

 A plain lateral radiograph of both ankles shows bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum.

Patients can also have yellowish plaques around the eyes (Xanthelasma) and corneal arcus.

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk of atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

 

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. Patients are generally neonates who present with adrenal insufficiency.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, TG and cholesterol Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

Related Pearl: Lipoprotein: Types, Sources and Action

Lipoproteins

Source

Action

Chylomicrons

Carry exogenous/dietary triacylglycerol from the intestine to peripheral organs

Very low density lipoproteins (VLDL)

Derived from the liver

Carry endogenous triacylglycerol from the liver to peripheral organs

Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)

Derived from VLDL

Involved in cholesterol transport

Highdensity lipoproteins (HDL)

Derived from Liver, intestine, VLDL, chylomicrons

Involved in reverse cholesterol & Phospholipids transport and also in VLDL and chylomicron metabolism

Intermediate density lipoproteins(IDL)

Triacylglycerol & cholesterol transport

questions.text: Which agency promotes health awareness in India?
questions.solution:
The Central Health Education Bureau(CHEB), under the Directorate General of Health Services is responsible for promoting health education in India.

The five divisions of CHEB are :

  • Media and editorial division  
  • Health promotion and education
  • School health education division
  • Training Division  
  • Administrative Division

The objectives of CHEB are to :

  • Interpret the plans, programmes and achievements of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • Design, guide and conduct research in health behaviour, health education processes and aids.
  • Produce and distribute type health education material in relation to various health problems and programmes.
  • Train key health and community welfare workers in health education and research methods, evolve effective methodology and tools of training.
  • Help schools and teacher training institutes for health education of the school population.
  • Provide guidelines for the organizational set-up and functioning of health education units at the state, district and other levels.
  • Offer technical help to official and non-official agencies engaged in health education work and coordinate their programmes.
  • Collaborate with international agencies in promoting health education activities.

questions.text: X is a drug that follows first-order one compartment model. A 40 mg intravenous dose results in a plasma concentration of 2mg/L initially and 1mg/L 4 hours later. Which of the following is the most likely clearance of the drug X?
questions.solution:
The clearance of drug X is  3.5 L/hr

Time taken for plasma concentration to drop from 2 mg/L to 1mg/L = 4 hours (plasma half life-t1/2)

Volume of distribution of drug (Vd) = Amount of drug in the body/ Initial plasma concentration 

  • Vd=40/2=20 L 
  • Clearance = 0.693 * Vd/ t1/2
  • Clearance ~ 0.7 * 20L/4hr 

Clearance ~ 3.5 L/hr

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cystic fibrosis is not true?

choices.text: Abnormality in CFTR gene leads to defective calcium transport
It affects lungs, pancreas, intestine and sweat gland.
Males have infertility in adult life

questions.solution:
Abnormalities in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein (CFTR) gene lead to defective chloride channels and not calcium channels. Sweat chloride levels are generally elevated > 60 mEq/L.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal-recessive disorder in children and adults. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion. More than 95% of males are azoospermic because of the failure of the development of Wolffian duct structures and the absence of vas deferens, but sexual function is generally unimpaired.

Lung disease occurs due to an obstruction from thickened mucous secretion. Pancreatic manifestations are due to obstruction of the pancreatic ductules by thickened secretions resulting in greasy stools, colicky abdominal pain, and malabsorption of nutrients from foods. Specifically, fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Intestinal involvement is typically seen in children with meconium ileus at birth and intestinal obstruction later in life. Failure of the chloride channel to reabsorb chloride leads to a loss of sodium onto the skin surface and a subsequent fluid loss. This causes the salty skin seen with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: Following an earthquake, the building codes were changed to earthquake-resistant buildings. Which of the following step of disaster management does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Changing the building codes to earthquake-resistant buildings are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements disaster preparedness and response activities and includes measures taken to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures are:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Other options:

Option A - Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage and tagging that form a part of the emergency care needed in the first few hours after a disaster.

Option B - Disaster reconstruction is a part of the recovery phase after a disaster.

Option C - Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.

The disaster management cycle is given below:

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the secondary prevention of mental illness in patients except:
questions.solution:
Improving the social environment is a method of primary prevention of mental illness, not secondary prevention. 

The levels of prevention of mental illness and measures are given below:

  • Primary prevention - Improving the social environment and promoting mental health awareness.
  • Secondary prevention - Early diagnosis and family-based health services like casework and family counselling.
  • Tertiary prevention - Measures to reduce the duration of mental illness and family and community stresses to prevent further breakdown and disruption.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Kallman syndrome -  hypothalamic hypogonadism is a cause of primary amenorrhea, not secondary. 

Primary amenorrhoea: is defined as an absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years. At age 13 years, if no menses have occurred and there is a complete absence of secondary sexual characteristics such as breast development, evaluation for primary amenorrhea should begin.. Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome), androgen insensitivity syndrome, and Turner syndrome present with primary amenorrhea. 

Kallman syndrome is associated with a low or absent GnRH. The condition is characterized by anosmia, hypogonadism, infertility, and absent, or partial pubertal maturation. Treatment includes GnRH, pituitary hormones, estrogen, and progestogen to induce menstruation.

Secondary amenorrhoea refers to the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses. Pregnancy is the most common cause of secondary amenorrhea. Sheehan's syndrome and Asherman's syndrome are other examples.

The flowcharts summarize the various causes of primary amenorrhea and the investigations undertaken for evaluation.

questions.text:
An obese and diabetic man presented with the lesions as shown below over his abdomen. On examination, he had diastolic hypertension. 24-hour urinary-free cortisol was increased. ACTH levels were high. What is the likely diagnosis?

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an obese, diabetic man with the image showing purple striae, diastolic hypertension, increased 24-hour urinary cortisol levels, and high levels of ACTH. So the likely diagnosis is Cushing's syndrome. 

Cushing's syndrome is a group of clinical features that occur due to chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids of any etiology. Cushing's disease is specifically Cushing's syndrome that occurs due to pituitary corticotrope adenoma. 

Typical features include

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Low libido
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic hypertension 
  • Edema 
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression, anxiety
  • Psychosis 
  • Irritability

 

Management of Cushing's syndrome includes

  • Surgical removal of the tumor followed by hydrocortisone replacement with gradual tapering is preferred.
  • Medical management includes metyrapone and ketoconazole. 

Other options:

Option A: Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), and aldosterone (mineralocorticoid). The features are fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, salt craving, hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

Option B: Adrenal crisis or acute adrenal insufficiency is an emergency usually occurring in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency. It is triggered by conditions like intercurrent illness and stress. The features include hypovolemic shock, acute abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, decreased responsiveness, stupor and coma.

Option C: Conn's syndrome or primary aldosteronism occurs due to aldosterone secreting adrenal adenoma leading to mineralocorticoid excess. It is characterized by hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, muscle weakness, proximal myopathy and muscle cramps.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

The given clinical scenario suggests alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes which are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency: 

  • It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum.
  • Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema.
  • It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. 
  • Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. 
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of cases.

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. If the compliance of the lung in Pulmonary fibrosis  is represented by curve C, what could curves A and B  most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Curves A and B will represent a normal lung and emphysema respectively.

  • The diagram depicts the change in volume with a change in intrapleural pressure, which is nothing but compliance.
  • Curve A represents the normal compliance of the lungs. 
  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve C, meaning that it takes greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve B is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).
  • Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.
  • Compliance is increased in emphysema due to the following.

The difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–volume curve of the lung is termed hysteresis. The surfactant help reduce surface tension and keep alveoli from collapsing, contributing to hysteresis.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the X-ray shown below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the classic 'pencil-in-cup deformity' of psoriatic arthritis with subluxation of the thumb. 

These changes occur due to periarticular erosion and bony resorption.

The images below shows the pencil-in-cup deformity in psoriatic arthritis.

Other deformities in psoriatic arthritis:

  • Marginal erosions with the adjacent bony proliferation 
  • Small joint ankylosis and osteolysis of phalangeal and metacarpal bones
  • Telescoping of digits, periostitis, and proliferative new bone 
  • Axial changes like asymmetric sacroiliitis

Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP).

The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands.

questions.text: All of the following statements about glucokinase are true in comparison to hexokinase, except ________.

choices.text: It is present in most tissues

questions.solution:
Glucokinase is present only in the liver and the beta cells of the pancreas, not most of the tissues.

Glucose is the only cellular substrate that can be phosphorylated by glucokinase. 

Glucokinase has a higher Vmax and a higher Km value than hexokinase. This means it requires a higher concentration of glucose for half saturation.

Characteristics Hexokinase Glucokinase
Tissue distribution Most tissues Liver and beta cells of the pancreas
Km Low High

Vmax

 Low High
Inhibition by G6P Yes No
Inducible No Inducible
Clinical significance Deficiency causes hemolytic anemia Less activity in diabetes mellitus
Biological significance Involved in maintaining intracellular glucose concentration  Involved in maintaining blood glucose concentration

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was being administered hydrocortisone for the treatment of autoimmune disease. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone may cause elevation of the plasma protein levels. All other options are incorrect.

Effects of cortisol/hydrocortisone:

On carbohydrate metabolism:

  • Increases gluconeogenesis
  • Decreases utilization of glucose by the cells.
  • Elevates blood glucose (option d)concentration.
  • Increases insulin secretion (option a).

On protein metabolism:

  • Causes decreased protein synthesis and increased catabolism of cellular proteins, especially in the extrahepatic tissues such as muscles and lymphoid tissue.
  • This leads to decreased muscle mass, and muscle weakness (patient may not be able to rise from a squatting position). 
  • Enhances amino acid transport into the liver, leading to increased liver proteins. As a result, there is increased production of plasma proteins in the liver, which are then released into the blood (option c).

On Fat metabolism:

  • Promotes mobilisation of fatty acids from the adipose tissue
  • Increases oxidation of fatty acids.
  • There may be deposition of fat in the chest and head regions of the body, giving a buffalo-like torso and a rounded moon face appearance.

High plasma levels of hydrocortisone, causes suppression of CRH and, consequently, reduces ACTH secretion (option b).

questions.text: Anteflexion of uterus is at the level of ______
questions.solution:
Anteflexion of uterus is at the level of internal os. 

Angle of Anteversion Angle of Anteflexion
Angle between the cervix and vagina Angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o
(Remeber: V for version, V for vagina)  

The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion.

In anteversion, the external os is directed downward and backward, so that on vaginal examination, the fingers find that the lowest part of the cervix is the anterior lip.

When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forward, and the lowest part of the cervix is either the external os or its posterior lip.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign of venous occlusion in a free flap?
questions.solution:
Sign of venous occlusion in a free flap is increasing warmth.

Clinical signs of arterial and venous compromise in a free flap:

Clinical Sign

 Arterial Compromise Venous Compromise

Color

 Becoming paler Increasingly reddish or purplish

Temperature 

 Becoming cooler Becoming warmer

Tissue turgor  

 Reducing Increasing

Capillary refill time

 Becoming slower  Becoming faster

Pinprick bleeding

Increasingly sluggish

Quickening (and darkening)

Note that venous and arterial compromise may coexist, and one may lead to the other.

questions.text: During a cricket match, a batsman controls his urge to urinate as he is unable to take a break in-between. While batting, he suffers a sudden blow as the ball hits him in the suprapubic region. He presents to the emergency department with severe hypogastric pain and the inability to pass urine. He collapses suddenly during the examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of injury to a full bladder, inability to pass urine, and syncope are suggestive of intraperitoneal rupture of the bladder.

Bladder rupture can be of two types:

  Extraperitoneal rupture Intraperitoneal rupture
  More common (80%)  Less common (20%)
Cause
  • Penetrating trauma
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Surgical damage
  • Associated with proximal urethral injury
  
  • Direct blow or fall on a distended bladder
Clinical features
  • Pelvic urinoma (encapsulated collection of extravasated urine) is seen
  • Blood at the tip of the meatus
  • Sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium
  • Syncope
  • Peritonitis
 
Treatment
  • Catheter drainage for 7–10 days
  • Laparotomy
  • Repair of bladder
  • Bladder drainage
 


Pubic diastasis refers to the separation of the pubic symphysis without concomitant fracture. Pubic diastasis with bulbar urethra rupture usually occurs due to straddle injury and presents with blood at the tip of the meatus.

questions.text: A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of respiratory distress, intermittent abdominal pain, scaphoid abdomen, absent breath sounds in both sides of the chest, and an X-ray image showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity is diagnostic of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), the most common variant being Bochdalek hernia.

If the defect is posterolateral it is called Bochdalek hernia and if it's anteromedial it is called Morgagni hernia. 

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

Other options:

Option B: Chest radiograph revealing bowel loops in the thorax is not seen in pneumonia.

Option C: Morgagni hernia: Here the defect is at the anteromedial location. It is rarer than Bochdalek hernia and accounts for only 2-5% of CDH. About 90% of the cases occur on the right side.

It is less symptomatic and the diagnosis is usually delayed until childhood. The patient presents with respiratory or upper GI symptoms. Respiratory symptoms like distress, tachypnea, and recurrent pulmonary infections are common in children. Other symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspnea, flatulence, and indigestion.

Radiographic findings

  • Radiolucent paracardiac shadow may be seen retrosternally on lateral chest x-ray if there is bowel herniation.
  • Rounded opacity in the right cardiophrenic angle may be seen if there is herniation of omentum or solid organs.(Shown below)

 

Option D: Eventration of the diaphragm: It refers to the abnormal contour of the dome of the diaphragm without any disruption to the diaphragmatic continuity. It usually involves a segment of the hemidiaphragm. It can cause respiratory distress in newborns and is usually asymptomatic in adults.

Radiographic findings: The affected portion of the hemidiaphragm is elevated and is seen as a smooth hump, while the normal contour is seen in the remaining part. 'Double diaphragmatic contour' may be seen in frontal view and is confirmed with a lateral X-ray.

Image showing eventration of the right dome of the diaphragm-

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought with fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction. An endomyocardial biopsy is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with complaints of fever, fatigue, and left ventricular dysfunction, and a biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

The inflammatory process of the myocardium is termed myocarditis. Patients mostly present with fatigue, chest pain, cardiogenic shock, and even cardiac arrest. Viruses are the most common among the infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis, and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration, as shown below.

Myocarditis begins with the direct invasion of an infectious agent. It subsequently replicates within and around the myocardium, causing myonecrosis. 

They are treated with supportive management. 

Other Options:

Option A: Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections, and Aschoff's bodies are seen in the image below.

Option B: The myocarditis of Chagas disease has distinctive features of the parasitization of scattered myofibers by trypanosomes accompanied by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils, lymphocytes, macrophages, and occasional eosinophils. The clusters of amastigotes cause swelling of individual myocardial fibers and create intracellular pseudocysts. There is focal myocardial cell necrosis accompanied by extensive, dense, acute interstitial inflammatory infiltration throughout the heart.

The image below shows the amastigotes within a myocyte (arrow) and the surrounding inflammatory response.

Option C- In most bacterial infections, the heart can be involved through direct invasion and abscess formation. Causes include diphtheria, brucellosis, legionella, Meningococcus, and Mycoplasma, and require treatment of the systemic infection.

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1  had an LMP of Jan 9th 2023. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele’s rule:
questions.solution:
According to Naegele’s rule, a quick estimate of the EDD using the LMP(the 1st day of the last menstrual period) can be made by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the LMP (or adding 9 months and 7 days to LMP)

Here, the LMP is January 9th.

Applying Naegele’s formula, the EDD is on the 16th of October.

Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. Naegle's Rule is based on 28 days regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated. 

For a 35-day cycle add another 7 days (35-28=7) to the calculated EDD to get corrected EDD.

For a 25-day cycle subtract 3 days(28-25=3) from the calculated EDD to get corrected EDD.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman was admitted by her parents due to inappropriate behaviour for the past 7 months. In the OPD, she constantly wandered, pointed aimlessly at her surroundings, burst into laughter without any reason, and made lip-sucking actions. She said that an evil giant was always around her although no one was near her. Lack of personal care and unorganized behaviour was also noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of schizophrenia, which is likely to be of the hebephrenic or disorganized type.

Hebephrenic schizophrenia (disorganized) has early onset, generally occurring before 25 years of age. It is characterized by marked regression of behaviour that becomes disorganized and poor contact with reality. Social behaviour and emotional responses are inappropriate. It has the worst prognosis after simple schizophrenia. 

Schizophrenia is a psychotic disorder with the following criteria: 

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms), where 2 or more of the following have to be present (at least one must be among the a, b, or c): 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behavior
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

3. The rest of the 6-month period may include

  • Continuing psychotic symptoms
  • Prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • Residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as

  • Odd beliefs
  • Magical thinking
  • Ideas of reference
  • Odd perceptual experiences
  • Peculiar or concrete thinking
  • Vague speech
  • Odd behavior
  • Negative symptoms may also be included

5. Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Other types of schizophrenia

Paranoid schizophrenia:

  • Most common type.
  • Often called paraphrenia in progressive deterioration. 
  • Usual onset in 3rddecade
  • Characterized by delusions of persecution, grandeur, control, etc.
  • Can be associated with hallucination

Catatonic schizophrenia:

  • Marked disturbance in motor function
  • May involve stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing
  • Alteration between extremes of excitement and stupor
  • Best prognosis
  • Term coined by Kahlbaum

Simple schizophrenia:

  • The primary symptom is withdrawal from social and work-related situations
  • Characterized by a gradual, insidious loss of drive and ambition
  • Do not experience persistent hallucinations or delusions
  • Poor prognosis (simple > hebephrenic)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bilateral adnexal masses and ascites. Histopathological examination of resected specimen shows sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. The most likely diagnosis is ____.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis with the above clinical interpretation is metastatic signet-ring carcinoma called Krukenberg tumor.

  • Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic signet-ring cell adenocarcinoma of the ovary, accounting for 1% to 2% of all ovarian tumors.
  • Primary sites: Stomach (70%); Carcinomas of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma)
  • Often bilateral
  • Microscopically, it is composed chiefly of mucin-laden signet-ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei.

Image showing metastastic signet-ring cells in Krukenberg tumor

questions.text: A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with an extradural tumor in the posterior cranial fossa that involved the hypoglossal nerve. On examination, when the patient protruded his tongue, it deviated to the right. Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralysed?
questions.solution:
The right genioglossus muscle is paralysed in the above given clinical scenario.

Actions of genioglossus muscle:

  • When both the right and left genioglossi contract, they protrude the anterior part of the tongue out of the mouth in the midline. When only one muscle contracts, it protrudes and turns the tongue to the opposite side.
  • It depresses the central part of the tongue.

Clinical considerations:

  • The genioglossi are attached to the genial tubercle present on the mandible. This prevents the tongue from sinking backwards and obstructing the respiration. Hence this muscle is known as the safety muscle of the tongue.
  • Genioglossus is the major muscle innervated by the hypoglossal nerve. In conditions affecting the hypoglossal nerve, the genioglossus muscle on that side is paralysed. In such cases, when the patient protrudes the tongue, it deviates towards the affected side due to the contraction of the muscle on the normal side.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage (APH).

Placental abruption or abruptio placenta is the premature separation of a normally situated placenta. The bleeding can be revealed, concealed or mixed type.

Causes of APH:

  • Placental causes:
    • Abruptio placenta (most common)
    • Placenta previa (2nd most common)
    • Circumvallate placenta
    • Circummarginate placenta
  • Fetal causes:
    • Vasa previa
  • Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions):
    • Local trauma
    • Varicose veins
    • Cervical polyp
    • Carcinoma cervix.

questions.text: An intern posted in the labor room is administering birth-dose vaccines to a newborn baby. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which of the following vaccine would he not administer?
questions.solution:
The pentavalent vaccine is not given at birth. The vaccines given at birth are BCG, OPV (0 dose) and hepatitis B vaccines.

questions.text: Nitrogenous waste is excreted from the body in the form of __?
questions.solution:
Nitrogenous wastes are excreted from the body in the form of urea.

Depending on their ecology and physiology, different animals excrete excess nitrogen as ammonia, uric acid, or urea.

In aqueous animals nitrogenous waste is excreted as ammonia. The constant excretion of water permits them to excrete the highly toxic ammonia, as it highly water soluble. Birds must both conserve water and maintain low weight and hence excreting nitrogen-rich uric acid. Many land animals, including humans, excrete nontoxic, highly water-soluble urea. High blood levels in renal disease are a consequence of impaired renal function.

 

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Where are owl's eye inclusion bodies seen?
questions.solution:
Owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

Cytomegalovirus is a type of herpes virus, which causes severe disease in immunocompromised patients. In most other cases, it is inapparent and marked by prolonged latency with intermittent reactivation.

Diagnosis:

  • IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). 
  • Avidity level measured by avidity index is used to describe the percentage of IgG bound to the antigen after being treated with denaturing agents.These assays are based on the fact that low avidity IgG antibodies are present during the first few months after the infection and avidity increases over time indicating maturation of the immune response. So the presence of high avidity IgG denotes a past infection rather than a primary one. Low avidity IgG signals a primary infection within the last 3-4 months. 
  • IgM detection can be used as an indicator of acute infection, but it lacks specificity for primary infection. This is because it persists for years in some individuals and is also produced during reactivation.

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. 

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases
