questions.text: A newborn infant is found to have a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. It is resulting in difficulty in directing the urine stream due to the ventral curvature of the penis. Which of the following is the cause of this malformation?

choices.text: Failure of the fusion of urethral folds

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes hypospadias. It occurs due to the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds.

Development of external genitalia in males

It is under the influence of androgens secreted by the fetal testes. The genital tubercle elongates to form phallus. During this elongation, the phallus pulls the urethral folds forward so that they form the lateral walls of the urethral groove. This groove extends along the ventral aspect of the elongated phallus, but not up to the glans. The urethral folds which form the lateral wall of the urethral groove fuse to form the penile urethra. The most distal part of urethra is formed by the penetration of the ectodermal cells from the tip of the glans. These form a short epithelial cord that forms the external urethral meatus.

Incomplete fusion of the urethral folds leads to hypospadiasis. 

Other options:

Option A- Splitting of genital tubercles leads to bifid or double penis.

Option C- Improper development of urorectal septum or cloaca leads to absent perineal and anal openings in association with ambiguous genitalia and urogenital and colonic malformations.

Option D- Improper developmental paramesonephric duct leads to uterine anomalies like uterus didelphys, uterus arcuatus, uterus bicornis, etc.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient died from respiratory distress following pneumonia caused by COVID-19(test positive). What should be recorded in line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
COVID-19 will be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate, as one of the antecedent causes in the order of the events that took place.

In this patient:

  • I(a)- Disease directly leading to death: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome(ARDS).
  • I(b)- Antecedent cause: Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Condition which gave rise to antecedent cause: COVID-19

Line II is filled with contributory factors/causes such as diabetes or hypertension.

Other scenarios:

1. In case of pregnancy, puerperium, or birth leading to death in conjunction with COVID-19, record the sequence of events as usual.

For example: 

  • I(a)- ARDS
  • I(b)- Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Pregnancy complicated by COVID-19

2. If an HIV patient is dead due to ARDS caused by COVID-19

  • I(a)- ARDS
  • I(b)- COVID-19
  • II- HIV disease

3. Note that COVID-19 patients may die of other diseases or accidents, such cases are not deaths due to COVID-19 and should not be certified as such. In case you think COVID-19 aggravated the consequences of the accident/disease, it may be reported in part II.

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: According to various types of thyroplasty, as described by Isshiki, type II thyroplasty refers to:
questions.solution:
The Lateralization of the vocal cord is a type II thyroplasty procedure.

Thyroplasty is a phono-surgical technique that aims to improve the voice by altering the thyroid cartilage of the larynx (the voice box), which houses the vocal cords in order to change the position or the length of the vocal cords.

There are four different types of thyroplasty procedures described by Isshiki:

Type

Thyroplasty

Uses

I

Medialization

In Complete palsy

II

Lateralization

In RLN palsy

III

Shortening (relax the vocal cord)

To reduce pitch

IV

Lengthening (tighten the vocal cord)

To increase pitch

Note to remember: MLSL

questions.text: An infant presents with copious bilious vomiting and abdominal distension on the 5th day of life. He had not passed meconium for the first 3 days after birth. An abdominal radiograph shows the presence of dilated bowel loops. What is the gold standard investigation for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease.

A rectal biopsy 2 cm above the dentate line is the ideal area for a biopsy.

Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The initial investigation is a contrast enema. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone. The affected part shows the absence of ganglion cells and hypertrophy of nerve trunks in the rectal biopsy.

Other investigations for Hirschsprung’s disease include:

  • Water-soluble contrast enema - shows the presence of contracted aganglionic rectum, transition zone, and a dilated normally innervated colon.
  • Anorectal manometry - shows the failure of the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter.

 Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure, where endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum. The ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be tested by noninvasive prenatal testing using cell-free fetal DNA?
questions.solution:
Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) can not test for Klinefelter syndrome.

NIPT is used for the screening of Trisomy 13, 18(Edwards syndrome), 21(Down syndrome), and Turner's syndrome. It is not a diagnostic test. It is a novel genetic test that uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum for screening of chromosomal anomalies.

DNA from the fetus is found circulating in the maternal blood in two forms, either inside the intact fetal cells or as cell-free DNA from the breakdown of placental fetal cells.

In NIPT, the cell-free chromosome fragments are measured. A fetus with aneuploidy will have a significantly larger number of abnormal DNA fragments than a normal fetus.

NIPT can be performed after 9-10 weeks of gestation. It is recommended after the routine first-trimester ultrasound assessment. The American College of Obstetrics and Gynaecology advises the use of NIPT for pregnancies with a high risk of fetal autosomal trisomy.

Its disadvantage is that it is very costly and it can be used for screening of chromosomes 13, 18, 21, and Turner's syndrome only. Other atypical chromosomal abnormalities can be missed on NIPT.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the bradycardia seen in Cushing reflex?
questions.solution:
The bradycardia seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by baroreceptor activation in response to a raised arterial blood pressure.

The Cushing reflex is a triad of raised arterial blood pressure, bradycardia, and irregular respiration caused by raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Raised ICP compromises blood flow to the brain and activates the rostral ventrolateral medulla with an increase in arterial blood pressure. The increased arterial pressure maintains cerebral perfusion and activates the baroreceptor reflex that causes bradycardia.

The irregular respiration seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by inadequate blood flow and increased pressure on the brainstem.

Bainbridge reflex: It refers to the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and pulmonary circulation.

J reflex: C fiber-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. 

Bezold Jarisch reflex (Coronary chemoreflex): Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not true for cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma?

choices.text: It is the second most common form of skin cancer

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is it has rolled out margins. An ulcer of SCC will have everted margins, not rolled-out margins.

SCC is the second most common skin cancer, while BCC is the most common skin cancer. Variants of SCC in situ include:

  • Bowen's disease- Full-thickness dysplasia in hypertrophic actinic (solar) keratoses
  • Erythroplasia of Queyrat- Bowen's disease on the glans penis.

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. These lesions then ulcerate and form a characteristic, everted edge, surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Cautery ablation
  • Cryotherapy
  • Drug therapy including Imiquimod
  • Radiation therapy

The below image shows SCC with everted margins:

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of fever in this patient is atropine toxicity.

The clinical scenario is suggestive of organophosphate consumption and atropine is used for its management. Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist, and it competitively blocks the acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. 

Organophosphates are powerful acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. It is absorbed by inhalation or through the skin. Mucous membranes and the gastrointestinal tract are also the sites for absorption. 

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhoea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headache, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Atropine in larger doses can lead to atropine toxicity. The features are depicted in the following image:

questions.text:
Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them:
A. Axe 1. Incised wound
B. RTA 2. Tram track bruise
C. Blade 3. Grazed abrasion
D. Lathi 4. Chop wound
questions.solution:
The correctly matched sets of the above-mentioned weapons and the possible injuries are as follows:

A. Axe 4. Chop wounds
B. Road traffic accident 3. Graze abrasions
C. Blade 1. Incised wound
D. Lathi 2. Tram track bruise

Mechanism of injury with the above-mentioned weapons:

Axe - Injury is produced by the chopping action of the weapon and it may be in a spectrum of an incised wound to laceration depending upon the sharpness of the blade.

Road traffic accident - Rubbing of epidermis tangential to a rough or hard surface gives rise to graze abrasion also called brush burn. It can occur in a road traffic accident after a pedestrian is being hit by a vehicle and the victim is slid/grazed for some distance before he comes to a halt.

Blade - It gives rise to a clean-cut wound which is usually deepest at its starting. Tailing of the wound indicates the direction of injury. Length is the biggest parameter of this type of wound.

Lathi- It is a blunt force injury giving rise to a patterned abrasion with 2 parallel lines and a normal unbruised area on site of impact or stick/lathi. The lathi forces the blood from the site of impact to either side which gives rise to tramline appearance.

The image below shows a chop wound inflicted on the scalp:

 

The image below shows a schematic illustrating heaping up of epidermis in a graze abrasion or brush burn:

 

The image below shows production of a tramline bruise associated with a lathi strike:

questions.text: Which of the following is an important sign of antemortem drowning:
questions.solution:
An important sign of antemortem drowning is cadaveric spasm which manifests as weed, grass ,sticks etc. floating in the water being firmly grasped in the hands. When present, it is an important sign suggesting that the victim struggled for existence while in water.

 Features like emphysema aquosum, froth in the air passages, hemorrhage into the middle ears, and subpleural hemorrhages are seen in cases of drowning. Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. The edema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death, holding the lungs in the inspiratory position. In drowning this may be sufficient to mark the lateral surfaces of the lungs with the impression of the ribs, leaving visible and palpable grooves after removal of the organs from the thorax. This is a valuable positive sign of drowning to be gained at autopsy.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But, absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs.
  • Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural haemorrhages that probably reflect haemolysis within intra-alveolar haemorrhages, and have been described in 50–60% of drownings.
  • Dilation of right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.
  • Foreign material in stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed or sand. This is also not a finding which can diagnose drowning.
  • Haemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, it is a non-specific finding.
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - Also not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning.

Note - Thus, the autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

       Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Foam/froth at nostrils or mouth Not present
Cadaveric spasm Not present
Lungs usually are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated ,called as emphysema aquosum. Passive collection of water  in the lungs without any formation of columns of froth,has been called as oedema aquosum.
Presence of foam, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc. in the bronchi and bronchioles. Foreign matter may passively find access only to the upper respiratory passage.
Demonstration of diatoms in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc. Diatoms may reach the lungs but not to the distant organs because of absence of circulation.
Stomach may contain water and foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc which may be swallowed while struggling for life. Water could enter the stomach. However, quantity of foreign matter may become the decisive issue.

questions.text: Which of the following provides reducing equivalents required for de-novo fatty acid synthesis?
questions.solution:
NADPH is the source of reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis.

 This NADPH is derived from 3 sources:

  • HMP shunt pathway (main source)
  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

Fatty acids are synthesized by an extramitochondrial system, which is responsible for the complete synthesis of palmitate from acetyl-CoA in the cytosol.

The synthesis of fatty acids takes place in the following organs:

  • Liver
  • Kidney
  • Brain
  • Lung
  • Lactating mammary gland
  • Adipose tissue

Related Pearl: Reducing Equivalents and Their Uses

Reducing agents

Uses

NADPH

Lipid synthesis

Cholesterol synthesis 

Fatty acid chain elongation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylation of aromatic compounds, steroids, alcohols, and drugs

NADH

Metabolizes alcohol

Glycolysis & Krebs cycle

Oxidative phosphorylation

β- Oxidation of fatty acid

Catalyzes reactions in muscle and liver cells

Electron Transport Chain

FADH2

Krebs cycle

Electron Transport Chain

Oxidative Phosphorylation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylase cycle

β-Oxidation of fatty acid

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in Fatty acid Transfer Across Mitochondrial membrane

Enzyme

Site of action

Action

Acyl-CoA synthetase

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Converts free fatty acid into Acyl CoA

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Transfers long-chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine.

Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Help Acylcarnitine to penetrate the inner membrane

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Along with carnitine palmitoyl transferase I oxidizes long-chain fatty acids in the mitochondria.

questions.text: A resected specimen of the kidney is shown in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of a kidney showing pinpoint petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface with a flea-bitten appearance is characteristically seen in malignant hypertension.

Malignant hypertension is characterized by severe hypertension with ischemic complications of multi-organs. The commonly affected organs are eye (resulting in retinal hemorrages, hard exudates, cotton wool spots with or without papilledema) and kidney (causing malignant nephrosclerosis). 

The pathophysiology behind this condition is due to hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. It affects small arteries and arterioles causing thickening and hardening of the wall with loss of elasticity. 

Histopathological features of malignant hypertension are: 

  • Smooth muscle and collagen proliferation are seen resulting in reduced size of the lumen. This further leads to concentric, laminated arteriolar thickening of the vessel wall with duplication of the basement membrane giving rise to an onion-skin appearance. 
  • They are also accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arterioles), particularly in the kidney and can lead to acute renal failure. 
  • Small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages may appear on the cortical surface from rupture of arterioles or glomerular capillaries, giving the kidney a peculiar flea-bitten appearance.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with long-standing hypertension has tried hydrochlorothiazide but his BP still remains uncontrolled. His BP is 158/96 mm of Hg and his BMI is 35. He has a bruit in the right flank. Doppler ultrasonography reveals severe right renal artery stenosis due to atherosclerosis. Which of the following drugs is recommended for managing this patient's hypertension?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with a patient having resistant hypertension, with right flank bruit and doppler findings of stenosis describes a case of right-sided renal artery stenosis. Medical management of renal artery stenosis is achieved using ACE inhibitors.

Clinical presentation: hypertension before 30 years of age, resistant or malignant hypertension, worsening renal function after taking an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocking (ARB) agent, hypertension, abdominal or flank bruit through.

Renal artery stenosis is a relatively common finding in older patients with chronic essential hypertension. However, it is clinically significant (ie, renovascular hypertension) only if the stenosis is greater than 75 percent in both renal arteries, or 50 percent stenosis with post-stenotic dilatation.

There are two major causes of bilateral renal artery stenosis:

  • Atherosclerosis (most common)- It affects patients over the age of 45 years.
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia – Most often affects women under the age of 50 years.
Unilateral renal artery stenosis Bilateral renal artery stenosis

U/L atherosclerosis

U/L fibromuscular dysplasia

External compression (e.g pheochromocytoma)  

Stenosis of only kidney

Systemic vasculitis

Atheroembolic diseases  

The gold standard for diagnosing renal artery stenosis is renal angiography. Other modalities include duplex doppler ultrasonography, computed tomographic angiography (CTA), and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)

Management: Medical management must be first pursued before vascular repair, with ACE inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers. Vascular repair may not benefit patients with advanced renal insufficiency, long-standing hypertension, or diabetes mellitus. Vascular repair shows better results in cases of fibromuscular dysplasia possibly due to younger age, shorter duration of hypertension, and less systemic disease.

questions.text: Which agency of the United Nations has the following logo?

choices.text: United States Agency for International Development

questions.solution:
The given logo is of the World Bank.

It helps less developed countries raise their living standards with economic support. The allocation of funds is decided by its Board of Governors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a lump in her right breast for the past two months. Her BIRADS score is 6. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's BIRADS score is 6 which means she is a case of known biopsy-proven malignancy. The most likely diagnosis among the given options is adenocarcinoma.

Fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumour are benign tumours which are BIRADS 2 lesions. Traumatic fat necrosis may mimic a carcinoma, even displaying skin tethering and nipple retraction. A biopsy is required for diagnosis. Since this patient has a biopsy-proven malignancy, the lesion cannot be traumatic fat necrosis.

BI-RADS refers to Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System. It is based on a thorough evaluation of the mammographic features of the breast. 

BI-RADS Categories:

Grades 1 and 2: 0% chance of being malignant.

Grade 3: >0% but ≤2% chance of being malignant

Grade 4: >2 but <95% chance of being malignant

Grade 5: ≥95% chance of being malignant.

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Annual screening
2 Benign finding Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding 6 monthly mammogram for next 2 years
4 Suspicious abnormality (2%-95% malignant) Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy (>95% malignant) Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy—proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: A 3-day-old infant is brought with a rash. On examination, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions are noted, with no cardiovascular abnormality. CT head shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this infant with periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly is congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

CMV is the most common congenital infection. The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Diagnosis can be made by the presence of IgM antibodies in the fetal blood. Isolation of the virus from the urine or blood by PCR is more sensitive.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness. Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

Other options:

Option A- Congenital rubella syndrome is due to the rubella virus. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome are deafness, cataract and congenital heart disease. Patent ductus arteriosus is the common cardiac defect. Eye findings also include salt and pepper retinopathy as shown below.

Option B- Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly, jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands and feet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions. 

Skeletal changes like saber shins, dental abnormalities like Hutchinson's teeth, and saddle nose - depression of the nasal root are some late findings.

Option C- Congenital toxoplasmosis is due to Toxoplasma gondii. A classic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications is seen. Blueberry muffin baby appearance is also seen in this. Calcifications occur randomly throughout the brain in congenital toxoplasmosis while periventricular calcification is characteristic of congenital CMV infection.

questions.text: The intravenous urogram finding shown in the image is seen in:
questions.solution:
The image shows a thimble bladder which is seen in tuberculosis.

Thimble bladder has a markedly contracted bladder wall with reduced capacity.

Other features are:

  • Golf hole appearance of the ureteric orifice on cystoscopy
  • Usually, the bladder doesn't calcify in TB, stippled calcification may be seen.
  • Moth eaten calyx refers to the ragged, feathery calyceal outline due to irregular erosions of the calyx. It is one of the earliest excretory urographic appearances of genitourinary tuberculosis.

Other options;

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination. A Christmas tree or pine cone appearance is seen with severe neurogenic bladder (seen in the image below).

The below image shows calcification of the bladder wall which is seen in bladder schistosomiasis. It is also known as bilharzia of the bladder.

The image below shows a teardrop bladder / pear-shaped bladder characteristically seen in pelvic lipomatosis, bilateral pelvic hematoma, pelvic abscess, bilateral pelvic lymphadenopathy, and intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

questions.text:
Identify the causative organism of the following lesion.

EBV-Epstein Barr virus
questions.solution:
The lesion shown in the picture is herpes labialis caused by HSV-1.

Herpes infection can be caused by HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes which is characterised by vesiculoulcerative lesions of the penis of the male or of the cervix, vulva, vagina, and perineum of the female.

The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers that heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is in the face, cheeks, chin, around the mouth and forehead. A cesarean section is performed in a case of active genital herpes at the time of labour in order to prevent neonatal herpes infection.

Acyclovir, at a high dose of 60 mg/kg/day, administered intravenously every eight hours, should be the first line of treatment for any infant with a confirmed or suspected neonatal HSV infection.

The image below shows herpes labialis.

Other options:

Option B: Epstein Barr virus affects adolescents and younger adults more frequently but may occur from childhood to old age. It is transmitted primarily through close contact with oropharyngeal secretions. The incubation period of EBV infectious mononucleosis is 4-6 weeks. Clinically, patients may present with, fever, malaise, nausea, anorexia, lymphadenopathy- bilateral and symmetrical, pharyngitis, tonsillar enlargement, hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.

Option C: Measles is caused by the measles virus from the paramyxoviridae family. The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, URTI, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This follows the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face below the hairline and spreads to the torso and extremities.

Option D: Rubella, also known as German measles is caused by the rubella virus, an enveloped RNA virus belonging to the family Togaviridae. The period of infectivity is usually a week before and a week after the onset of the rash appears and the incubation period is around 2-3 weeks. The child presents with low-grade fever, centrifugal macular rash, and prominent lymphadenopathy (suboccipital, postauricular, and anterior cervical lymph nodes). Forchheimer spots which are tiny rose-colored lesions on the soft palate may be present.

Related Pearl: Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus

  1. Cutaneous lesions: Fever blister, herpetic whitlow, herpetic gladiatorum, eczema herpeticum. Eczema herpeticum is a generalized eruption caused by Herpes infections in children suffering from eczema
  2. Mucosal: most common site involved is buccal mucosa. It may cause Gingivostomatitis & Pharyngitis, Recurrent herpes labialis.
  3. Ophthalmic: Follicular conjunctivitis, Herpes simplex keratitis, and acute keratoconjunctivitis also occur. 
  4. Nervous System: HSV encephalitis(Temporal lobe involvement), HSV meningitis, Mollaret’s meningitis. 
  5. Genital system: Genital herpes

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding oxytocin?

choices.text: It can be given by oral route
It is secreted by anterior pituitary
In higher doses, it exerts diuretic like action

questions.solution:
Oxytocin is responsible for galactokinesis (milk ejection reflex).

Other options:

  • It can not be given by oral route because it has emotional side effects.
  • It is secreted by the posterior pituitary.
  • It does not have diuretic-like action at higher doses.

WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) recommends oxytocin administration immediately (within 1 minute) after the delivery of the fetus.  Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. It should be given after the delivery of the fetus and before the delivery of the placenta. 

Milk ejection by oxytocin follows a stimulation mechanism similar to uterine contraction in delivery (cervical dilatation). 

The physiological actions of oxytocin are: 

  • Contraction of the pregnant uterus: Cervical dilatation transmits signals to the hypothalamus and stimulates the secretion of oxytocin, which acts on the smooth muscles of the uterus and contracts it. 
  • Milk ejection from breasts: Suckling reflex transmits signals to the hypothalamus which causes the release of oxytocin which acts on the myoepithelial cells of the breast. This results in ejection of milk. 

The action of oxytocin is an example of positive feedback mechanism. 

AMTSL  guidelines recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

questions.text: Identify the Doppler waveform and the condition associated with it.
questions.solution:
The given Doppler waveform is monophasic, which is seen in severe stenosis of the artery.

A normal artery has a triphasic signal. The waveform becomes biphasic in mild-moderate stenosis and monophasic in severe stenosis.

The image given below shows the normal triphasic signal from an artery.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient needs to undergo cataract surgery. Before initiating the surgery, the following procedure is performed. What is the most common complication seen in the procedure?
questions.solution:
The most common complication seen in the procedure of retrobulbar block is retrobulbar haemorrhage.

The image shown above depicts the technique of retrobulbar block which is a regional anaesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery. It involves the injection of a local anaesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction of the middle and lateral one-third of the orbit.

Related Pearl: Complications and contraindications of retrobulbar block

Complications:

  • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication)
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
  • Proptosis
  • Perforation of the globe
  • Optic nerve atrophy
  • Oculocardiac reflex
  • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
  • Trigeminal nerve block
  • Respiratory arrest
  • Acute neurogenic pulmonary edema (rarely)

Contraindications:

  • Bleeding disorders (because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage)
  • High myopia (if the axial length is greater than 25 mm, then sclera would be thin which could increase the risk of globe perforation)
  • Open eye injury or penetrating eye injury: injection of local anesthetic behind the globe could increase the intraocular pressure which could lead to extrusion of the orbital contents.

questions.text: You are evaluating the patency and function of the Eustachian tube in a patient with a right earache and ear block. Which of the following test you will not do?
questions.solution:
Stenger test is not used for the assessment of patency or function of the eustachian tube. It is used to detect malingering of hearing loss.

Tests of Eustachian tube patency:

  • Pneumatic otoscopy
  • Nasopharyngoscopy
  • Valsalva manoeuvre
  • ET catheterization
  • Politzer test.

Tests of Eustachian tube function:

  • Toynbee’s test
  • Tympanometry
  • Saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears
  • Sonotubometry.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee joint for one week with the following lesions on his soles. He also complains of pain in his ankle and feet for the past 2 days. He gives a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows keratoderma blennorrhagica. The clinical scenario describes acute arthritis following a recent infection with an additive pattern (involvement of new joints within a few days). These features suggest the diagnosis of reactive arthritis or Reiter's syndrome. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) is a condition included in the spectrum of seronegative spondyloarthropathies. It is an acute asymmetric nonpurulent oligoarthritis precipitated by an antecedent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. It is characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. It occurs most commonly in the age group 18-40 years and is associated with HLA-B27.

Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Chlamydia trachomatis, Clostridium difficile, certain toxigenic Escherichia coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, and Mycoplasma genitalium.

The clinical features of reactive arthritis include constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue, weight loss. Patients develop arthritis which is asymmetric and additive involving large weight-bearing joints like the knee and ankle. Sacroiliitis and spondylitis occur as late sequelae and are more commonly asymmetric. Non-marginal syndesmophytes which are comma-shaped arising from the middle of the vertebral body are seen. Dactylitis or sausage digit and enthesitis are also seen.

Extraarticular manifestation of reactive arthritis:

  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles.
  • Oral ulcers: Superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic.
  • Circinate balanitis: consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis.
  • Anterior uveitis
  • Conjunctivitis

Laboratory investigations reveal elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. Synovial fluid analysis shows inflammatory changes with negative culture. Joint radiograph shows juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, loss of joint space, and periostitis with new bone formation.

Treatment includes NSAIDs, intralesional glucocorticoids, and antibiotics during the antecedent infection.

Other options:

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. 

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months 

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

Sacro-iliac joints show cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints

Vertebral changes: Earliest change is the flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’). Bamboo spine appearance occurs due to bridging at several vertebral levels.

X-ray showing the characteristic bamboo-spine appearance:

Option B: Psoriatic arthritis is an asymmetrical oligoarthritis. It is associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or dactylitis, enthesitis. The inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints. There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping. Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the fingers. Axial involvement may occur.

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"

X-ray shows 'pencil-in-cup' involving metacarpophalangeal joints:

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age. The patient usually presents with swelling and pain in the small joints of the hands. Metacarpophalangeal(MCP) and proximal interphalangeal(PIP) joints are commonly involved. The patient also has morning stiffness in the affected joints.

questions.text: Phlegmasia alba dolens refers to_______

choices.text: Extensive DVT of deep veins only
Extensive DVT of deep veins and collaterals

questions.solution:
Phlegmasia alba dolens (PAD) refers to extensive DVT of deep veins only.

Phlegmasia alba dolens (PAD) and phlegmasia cerulea dolens (PCD) are conditions that result from acute, massive deep vein thrombosis of the lower extremities. 

Phlegmasia alba dolens also called milk leg. It involves thrombosis of major deep venous channels of the extremity, sparing collateral veins. There is an absence of limb ischemia. The venous drainage is decreased but still present. It is characterized by pain and edema without cyanosis.

Phlegmasia cerulea dolens is extensive DVT of deep venous channels of the lower extremity with the thrombosis extending to collateral veins. It is characterized by pain and pitting with associated cyanosis. (PCD=Cyanosis). 

The image below shows cyanosis of the left leg depicting phlegmasia cerulea dolens.

questions.text: A 30 year old female recently started feeling like an outcast in her office. She had been suffering from on and off nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Her examination revealed foul smelling nasal discharge which the patient was totally unaware,  thick nasal crusts but with a wide and clear nasal pathway. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is typical of atrophic rhinitis.

It is also known as 'Ozaena'. It is a chronic inflammation of nose characterised by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The nasal cavities are roomy and full of foul smelling crusts. Atrophic rhinitis is of 2 types: Primary & Secondary.

PRIMARY ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

AETIOLOGY: (Mn: HERNIA)

  • Hereditary factors 
  • Endocrine disturbances - starts at puberty
  • Racial factors - white & yellow races are more susceptible.
  • Nutritional deficiency- may be due to vitamin A, D or iron deficiencies.
  • Infective - Klebsiella ozaenae , E.coli, Proteus vulgaris, staphylococci, etc., are all thought to be involved.
  • Auto-immune process - Viral infection or some other unspecified agents may trigger antigenicity of nasal mucosa.

PATHOLOGY:

Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. 

Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterating endarteritis. The bones of the turbinate undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers.  

CLINICAL FEATURES:

Disease is commonly seen in females and starts around puberty. There is foul smell from the nose making the patient a social outcast though patient himself is unaware of the smell due to masked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
Patient may complain of nasal obstruction in spite of unduly wide nasal chambers. This is due to large crusts filling the nose. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

TREATMENT:

a) MEDICAL :

Aims at maintaining nasal hygiene by removal of crusts and the associated putrefying smell and to further check crust formation.

  • Nasal irrigation and removal of crusts
  • 25% glucose in glycerine
  • Local antibiotics 
  • Oestrodiol spray
  • Placental extract
  • Systemic use of streptomycin
  • Potassium iodide ( liquefies nasal secretion when given by mouth)

b) SURGICAL:

  • Young's operation - both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps.They are opened 6 months later.
  • Modified Young's operation- To avoid the discomfort of bilateral nasal obstruction, it aims to partially close the nostrils.
  • Narrowing the nasal cavities- It helps to relieve the symptoms 

SECONDARY ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 Specific infections like syphilis, leprosy and rhinoscleroma may cause destruction of the nasal structures leading to atrophic changes.

   Atrophic rhinitis can also result from long- standing purulent sinusitis, radiotherapy to nose or excessive removal of turbinates.

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

A)Hypertrophic rhinitis presents with thick nasal discharge, nasal block with hypertrophic turbinates.

C)Rhinitis sicca presents with thick and dry nasal discharge but most commonly occurs among people working in hot, dry and humid conditions.

D)Rhinitis caseosa presents with foul smelling nasal discharge with cheesy material.

questions.text: Identify the hysterosalpingography
questions.solution:
The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.

A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity due to the failure of the medial segments of the Müllerian ducts to regress. The septum can project partially from the fundus or can extend completely to the cervical os. On HSG, the septate uterus is seen as widely diverging horns with an intercornual angle <75 degrees. 

Hysterosalpingogram cannot differentiate between a septate uterus and a bicornuate uterus. A septate uterus has a smooth fundal contour whereas a bicornuate uterus has an indented fundus.

 

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (cockscomb cervix)   Ectopic pregnancy,  cervical incompetance,  clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina and cervix 

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about section 45 of IEA ?

choices.text: Has the knowledge to draw conclusions from the facts available
Witness Bata may be paid to Doctors even in Criminal Cases

questions.solution:
IEA Section 45 gives information regarding Expert witness. 

The first-hand knowledge Rule is applicable to common witness, not an expert witness.

A common witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him based on the first-hand knowledge rule (only facts perceived by him).

Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act defines an expert witness. An expert witness is one who has acquired special knowledge, skill or experience in any science, art, subject, or profession. He could have acquired such knowledge by practice, observation, or careful studies.

An expert witness may give his opinion

(I) upon facts which are either admitted, or proved by himself or other witnesses at the trial,

(2) on matters of common knowledge, and

(3) on hypothetical questions (questions based on stated assumptions) based thereon.

Hypothetical questions may be asked to extract an opinion from the expert, after he assumes certain facts to be true, describing a specific situation, even though he may not have first-hand knowledge of the actual case.

A doctor's testimony that a certain thing is possible is no evidence at all. A doctor's testimony can only be considered evidence when he states that the conclusion he gives is based on "reasonable medical certainty" (more probable than not in a medical sense) that a fact is true or untrue.

If the witness is a doctor in private practice, he may request the court for conveyance charges and daily allowance according to the Government rules(even in criminal cases). As per law (Section 312 CrPC), he or she will be paid the travel allowances (TA) by the court. This is referred to as "Witness Bata".

A doctor can be both a common and expert witness. When he describes the wounds on the body, he acts as a common witness. But when he says that the wounds were antemortem or post-mortem, or they were suicidal, homicidal, or accidental, or gives opinion regarding the cause of death, he acts as an expert witness.

The chemical examiner is also an expert witness

Also note:

A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of events that occur during necrosis?

1) Cell swelling
2) Karyolysis
3) Karyorrhexis
4) Pyknosis
questions.solution:
The sequence of events in necrosis is: cellular swelling → pyknosis → karyorrhexis → karyolysis

Necrosis is defined as the spectrum of morphological changes that follow cell death due to the progressive degradative action of enzymes.

Morphological changes that occur in necrosis are as follows:

Cytoplasmic changes -

  • Increased eosinophilic staining on H&E specimens
  • Moth-eaten appearance of the cytoplasm - due vacuolated cytoplasmic organelles formed by enzymatic degradation
  • Glossy and homogenous cytoplasm - due to loss of glycogen in the cytoplasm

Nuclear changes -

  • Pyknosis - nucleus first shrinks and becomes more condensed
  • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus
  • Karyolysis - nucleus fades away leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months and the otoscopic finding is suggestive of serous otitis media. 

The given otoscopic image shows a dull and opaque tympanic membrane with clear effusion.

Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

Glue ear is thought to happen due to either malfunctioning (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the eustachian tube (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. Mild earaches with a history of upper respiratory tract infection are usually seen. 

On otoscopy, 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • If the tympanic membrane is transparent fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen

 The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques. 
  • Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Myringitis bullosa is characterized by painful hemorrhagic blebs on the tympanic membrane and deep meatus. It occurs due to infection by a virus or mycoplasma. 

Option C: Acute otitis media is an acute infection of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. It presents with marked earache and hearing loss is seen in later stages. Otoscopy shows a red and bulging tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin?
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenckii causes infection followed by traumatic inoculation into the skin.

It is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection.

Subcutaneous mycoses are usually caused by traumatic inoculation of the causative fungus. These include:

Subcutaneous mycoses

 Causative agent/s

Sporotrichosis

 Sporothrix schenckii
Chromoblastomycosis

Phialophora verrucosa

Fonsecaea pedrosoi

Fonsecaea compacta

Rhinocladiella aquaspersa

Cladophialophora carrionii

Phaeohyphomycosis

Exophiala jeanselmei

Phialophora richardsiae

Bipolaris spicifera

Wangiella dermatitidis

Mycetoma

 Pseudallescheria boydii (Anamorph Scedosporium apiospermum).

Madurella mycetomatis

Madurella grisea

E jeanselmei

Acremonium falciforme

Other options:

The fungi mentioned in options b, c, and d causes endemic mycosis. The disease is initiated in the lungs due to the inhalation of spores.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early sign of malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Hyperthermia is a late sign of malignant hyperthermia.

Malignant hyperthermia is an emergent condition that occurs in susceptible individuals when they are exposed to an inhaled anesthetic agent (isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane) or succinylcholine.

Clinical manifestations of malignant hyperthermia:

Early Signs:

  • Elevated end-tidal carbon dioxide
  • Tachypnea and/or tachycardia
  • Masseter spasm, if succinylcholine has been used
  • Generalized muscle rigidity
  • Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis
  • Profuse sweating
  • Mottling of skin
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Unstable blood pressure

Late Signs:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Rapid increase of core body temperature- body temperature rises by 1°C every 5 minutes
  • Elevated creatine phosphokinase levels
  • Gross myoglobinemia and myoglobinuria
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in:

choices.text: Prevention of Seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.solution:
Magnesium sulphate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a premature baby.

Magnesium sulfate administered parenterally is an effective anticonvulsant that avoids producing central nervous system depression. It may be given intravenously by continuous infusion or intramuscularly by intermittent injection. Magnesium sulfate has a neuroprotective effect

It reduces contractility of the uterus and can be used as a tocolytic.

MgSo4 is a membrane stabilizer and a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach. Very low-birthweight neonates whose mothers were treated with magnesium sulfate for preterm labor or preeclampsia were found to have a reduced incidence of cerebral palsy at 3 years.

questions.text: Identify the given image based on the Doppler findings.
questions.solution:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts the reversal of end-diastolic flow (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. 

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)

Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise - terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks.

Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death - terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Stool microscopy showed the oocysts which were 4-8 μm in size. The image is shown below. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the stool microscopy show oocysts of Cryptosporidium.

Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The two cryptosporidium species responsible are C. hominis and C. parvum. 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round contains 2 sporocyst each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval cysts contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

Treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

Acid-fast staining showing oocysts of Cyclospora.

Acid-fast staining showing oval oocysts of Isospora.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Protozoans

questions.text: The chromosomal abnormality associated in a neonate with prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet is most probably _________
questions.solution:
Prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet are all features of Edwards syndrome, i.e., Trisomy 18.

Trisomy 18 - Edwards syndrome:

  • Low birth weight
  • Closed fists with index finger overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th
  • Narrow hips with limited abduction
  • Short sternum
  • Rocker-bottom feet
  • Microcephaly
  • Prominent occiput
  • Micrognathia
  • Cardiac and renal malformations
  • Intellectual disability

questions.text: A woman was slowly poisoning her husband by adding arsenic to his food daily. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
Acrodynia (pink disease) is a feature of mercury poisoning, not arsenic poisoning. 

Pink disease or Acrodynia is the dermatological manifestation of mercury poisoning. Children are usually affected by this hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by sweating, skin rash, with hands and feet becoming puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated paresthesia and skin peeling are also seen.

Features of chronic arsenic exposure:

  • Skin lesions-
    • Hyperpigmentation (raindrop pigmentation resembling measles) or hypopigmentation
    • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles.
    • Nail changes (Mees lines)
    • Skin carcinomas and Bowen disease
    • Peripheral vascular disease leading to Blackfoot disease (gangrene)
  • Neurologic manifestations -
    • Polyneuropathy
    • Painful paraesthesia of hands and feet
  • Cardiovascular - coronary heart disease and stroke
  • Endocrine - Diabetes Mellitus type 2

Note: Some people take arsenic daily as a tonic or as an aphrodisiac and they acquire tolerance to 250–300 mg or more in one dose. Such people are known as arsenophagists.

The image below shows hyperkeratosis of palms.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera-like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • Prolonged QT interval
  • Ventricular fibrillation
  • Atypical ventricular tachycardia

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to Blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: Which of the following increases the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
Copper IUCDs increase the risk of PID. The most common organism causing PID in an IUCD user is Actinomyces.

OCPs, Mirena and DMPA injectables contain progesterone which causes thickening of the cervical mucus and decreases the motility of the female genital tract. Thus, they reduce the risk of PID by preventing the ascent of bacteria from the vagina.

questions.text: Which of the following auscultatory findings do you expect to hear in a child during clinical examination in a child with an ASD?
questions.solution:
In Atrial septal defect (ASD), the characteristic finding is that the second heart sound is widely split and fixed during all phases of respiration.

Other options:

  • In Ventricular septal defect (VSD) – Wide variable splitting of the 2nd heart sound which is masked by the pansystolic murmur.
  • In Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) – the first sound is accentuated and the second sound is narrowly or paradoxically split.
  • In the Coarctation of the aorta – the first sound is accentuated, the second sound is normally split with a loud aortic component.

questions.text:
Recently, a new latex agglutination test was approved for the screening of a disease. Calculate the sensitivity and specificity based on the table given below:
  Test +ve Test -ve
Disease+ 27 3
Disease - 5 95
questions.solution:
• Let us first reconstruct the table to indicate true (TP/TN) and false (FP/FN) positives and negatives.
  Test + Test -
Diseased 27 (TP) 3 (FN)
Not diseased 5 (FP) 95 (TN)
  • Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 and specificity is given as TN/(FP + TN) x 100
  • In this scenario, sensitivity is 90% and specificity is 95%

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

questions.text: A patient is known to have mitral stenosis had an acute onset of weakness of the left arm which recovered completely in 10 hours. The most likely diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
This patient with acute onset weakness that recovered within 10 hours is said to have a transient ischemic attack(TIA). Mitral stenosis is known to cause atrial fibrillation and is a common cause of cardioembolic stroke.

TIA is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) owing to focal ischemia of the brain, retina or cochlea. It lasts for less than 24 hours. Most TIAs last for less than 1 hour to a few minutes. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA. 

ABCD2 Score is used for stroke risk assessment following a transient ischemic attack.

Related Pearl: ABCD2 Score

The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by ABCD2 score.

Clinical factors Score
Age > 60 1
SBP>140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1
Clinical symptoms
Unilateral weakness 2
Speech disturbances without weakness 1
Duration 
>60min 2
10-59min 1
Diabetes 1
Total Score Sum Each Score
ABCD2 Score Total 3-months Rate of stroke (%)
0 0
1 2
2 3
3 3
4 8

questions.text:
Choose the correctly matched pairs regarding the drugs used in schizophrenia:
1. D2 antagonism Reduces positive symptoms
2. 5HT2A antagonism Reduces negative symptoms
3. 5HT1A agonism Weight loss
4. Muscarinic antagonism Reduces extrapyramidal symptoms
questions.solution:
The correct option regarding the drugs used to treat schizophrenia symptoms is option C.

Drugs used to treat schizophrenia can be classified:

  • Typical or 1st generation antipsychotics.
  • Atypical or 2nd generation antipsychotics.

All typical antipsychotics markedly improve positive symptoms of schizophrenia, which is attributed to their antagonism at the D2 receptor. Some of the drugs included in this class are chlorpromazine and haloperidol.

Atypical antipsychotics are antagonists or inverse agonists at the 5HT2A receptor. 5HT2A antagonism is responsible for reducing negative symptoms in schizophrenia. Some of the drugs that belong to this class are clozapine, aripiprazole, and brexpiprazole.

Atypical antipsychotics have lower extrapyramidal symptoms as compared to typical antipsychotics as the former has a lesser affinity to the D2 receptor. Muscarinic antagonists can be given to decrease the extrapyramidal symptoms. For example, promethazine or hydroxyzine is given for acute muscular dystonia, which is a form of extrapyramidal symptoms.

5HT1A receptor antagonism, not agonism, has been found to reduce food intake and hence reduce body weight.

Aripiprazole and brexpiprazole are atypical antipsychotics that have partial agonist effects at the 5HT1A receptor. They have been approved for the treatment of schizophrenia and as an adjunctive treatment for depression.

Related Pearl: Actions of antipsychotic drugs

Dopaminergic pathway Significance Action of drug blocking D2 receptors
Nigrostriatal Movement Extrapyramidal symptoms
Mesolimbic Speech, grasp of reality, mentation, and mood Reduces positive symptoms of schizophrenia
Mesocortical Motivation, pleasure, socialization May increase negative symptoms of schizophrenia
Tuberoinfundibular pathway Inhibits prolactin release Hyperprolactinemia
Chemoreceptor trigger zone Vomiting reflex Anti emetic

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following complement components causes hereditary angioneurotic edema?
questions.solution:
C1 esterase inhibitor (C1 INH) blocks the activation of C1, the first protein of the classical complement pathway. The inherited deficiency of this inhibitor is the cause of hereditary angioedema.

Hereditary angioneurotic edema:

  • Autosomal dominant; Deficiency of C1 INH leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein and increased production of bradykinin.
  • Episodes of skin, laryngeal(result in life-threatening asphyxia)and gastrointestinal mucosal edema.

C2

  • Deficiency of C2 is the most common complement protein deficiency.
  • Deficiency of C2 or C4, which are early components of the classical pathway, is associated with increased bacterial or viral infections. 

Deficiencies of early components of the classical complement pathway, including C1, C4, and C2, recurrent pyogenic infections and SLE.

C5

  • C5 is a terminal component of complement required for the assembly of membrane attack complex (MAC) involved in the lysis of organisms.
  • Deficiency of C5 to C8 increases susceptibility to recurrent neisserial (gonococcal and meningococcal) infections.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular analysis methods is used to detect RNA?
questions.solution:
RT PCR (Reverse Transcriptase PCR) is a molecular analysis method used for the detection of RNA. It can be used to quantitate mRNA levels by generating complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme. 

The northern blot technique can also be used to detect RNAs. Here, the mixture of mRNA molecules is separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with radiolabeled probes.

Sanger’s technique:

  • This was the first technique used to determine the sequence of proteins.
  • Sanger’s reagent is 1- Flouro 2,4 Dinitro benzene.
  • The first protein to be sequenced by this method was insulin.

G banding (Giemsa banding):

It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype by staining condensed chromosomes. It is useful for identifying genetic diseases through the photographic representation of the entire chromosome complement. The metaphase chromosomes are treated with trypsin (to partially digest the chromosome) and stained with Giemsa stain. 

Heterochromatic regions, which tend to be rich with adenine and thymine (AT-rich) DNA and relatively gene-poor, stain darker and appear as dark bands in G-banding. In contrast, less condensed chromatin, which tends to be rich with guanine and cytosine (GC-rich) and more transcriptionally active incorporates less Giemsa stain, and these regions appear as light bands in G-banding. The image below shows a G-banding karyogram of a normal human male.

Western blot, also called immunoblots, is a technique used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

questions.text: Fleischer's ring is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Fleischer's ring is seen in keratoconus. Slit-lamp examination reveals Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone formed.

Keratoconus or the conical cornea is a bilateral non-inflammatory progressive condition of the axial part of the cornea. Central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea are pathognomonic. This is attributed to mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue synthesis defects. 

Clinical features of the condition include defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism. Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present. Complications include acute hydrops following the rupture of Descemet's membrane.

Deep, vertical stromal striae (Vogt lines) that disappear with external pressure are characteristic. Retinoscopy shows a scissoring reflex. The bulging of the lower lid in the downgaze, called Munson's sign, is shown in the image below.

The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry. Corneal topography is a diagnostic modality with the highest sensitivity for early cases.

Intacs or intracorneal ring segments are useful in moderate cases due to their flattening effect. Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses, corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin, and keratoplasty are the other treatment modalities.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: A  45-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of increasing pain in his right hand over the past few months. On examination, there is a palpable lump, and an x-ray was done which is given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation at this age and the radiograph showing popcorn calcification are suggestive of chondrosarcoma.

Chondrosarcoma is the second most common nonhematological primary malignancy of the bone(Osteosarcoma is the commonest). It can be primary or secondary. Secondary chondrosarcomas develop at the site of a previously existing benign cartilage lesion.

Primary chondrosarcomas are commonly seen at 40-60 years of age whereas the age group for secondary chondrosarcoma is 25-45 years.

Clinical features:

  • Pelvis, proximal femur, and proximal humerus are the common locations.
  • The hand is a rare location. However, it is the most common primary bone malignancy in the hand.
  • Primary chondrosarcoma usually presents with increasing pain and a palpable lump.
  • Asymptomatic radiological abnormality is a common presentation in enchondromas but is not seen in chondrosarcomas.

Conditions that can cause secondary chondrosarcoma includes:

  • Multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses.
  • Ollier disease(multiple enchondromas)
  • Maffucci syndrome(multiple enchondromas with soft-tissue hemangiomas).
  • Synovial chondromatosis
  • Periosteal chondroma
  • Chondroblastoma
  • Previous radiation treatment
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Chondromyxoid fibroma

Radiological findings:

  • It arises from the medullary cavity and shows irregular matrix calcification.
  • Characteristic calcification pattern is described as "popcorn", "punctate", or "comma-shaped"
  • Bone destruction, cortical erosion, and periosteal reaction may be seen.
  • CT or MRI is used to identify the presence of secondary chondrosarcomas.
  • Secondary chondrosarcoma is suspected of the cartilage cap of the lesion is more than 2 cm in a skeletally mature patient.

Treatment:

  • Extended curettage with intraoperative adjuvant treatments is considered for low-grade lesions confined to the medullary canal.
  • Low-grade lesions with soft tissue extensions should be treated as high-grade lesions.
  • High-grade lesions are managed with wide or radical resection or amputation.
  • Chemotherapy is not indicated for conventional chondrosarcoma but is used for mesenchymal or dedifferentiated variants.
  • Radiotherapy is only used as a palliative measure for surgically inaccessible tumors.

Other options:

Osteosarcoma:

It is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. 

Radiographic findings: The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a "Codman's triangle" or it may have a "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on X-ray.

Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor:

The commonly affected age group is 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.
