 Fibrous dysplasia  The upper end of femur > tibia  1st to 3rd decade
 Chordoma  Sacrum  5th to 7th decade
Multiple myeloma Vertebrae 5th to 7th decade

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of a child who presented with stridor. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed on a lateral x-ray of the soft tissues of the neck.  The features include :

  • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • Loss of cervical lordosis
  • In an acute abscess,  air-fluid levels can be seen.

Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It is the result of suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity.

In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include

  • Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing - as the abscess obstructs the air and food passages. 
  • Stridor and croupy cough 
  • Torticollis - the neck becomes stiff and the head is kept extended. 
  • A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, usually seen on one side of the midline. 

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is the result of

  • Caries of the cervical spine
  • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical nodes.

questions.text: A female patient with invasive breast cancer in the right breast is posted for modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following step is not done in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major is not removed in modified radical mastectomy.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy are:

  • Whole breast tissue
  • Skin over the breast tissue
  • Nipple-areola complex
  • Pectoral fascia
  • Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss)

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin.
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Axillary lymph nodes (Levels I + II ± III)
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor divided
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iversion) mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular lymph nodes
  • Super radical mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular + Mediastinal lymph nodes

questions.text: A young man presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, dizziness, breathlessness, and blurring of vision while trekking on a mountain at an altitude of 5000 meters. He is unable to climb any further. Which of the following indicates the development of high-altitude cerebral edema?
questions.solution:
Altered mental status is a clinical finding indicative of the development of high-altitude cerebral edema. 

At high altitudes, the partial pressure of oxygen in the atmosphere is low. When people ascend to high altitudes hypoxia causes systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and lungs. This results in cerebral edema and pulmonary edema respectively.

Pathophysiology: Vasogenic edema occurs due to the leaking of proteins and water through the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Causes of increased BBB permeability include:

  • Mechanical factors: loss of autoregulation and increased capillary pressure due to increased sympathetic activity (option D).
  • Increased chemical mediators of permeability: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) (option C), nitric oxide, and cytokines (option A).

Patients with cerebral edema usually present with:

  • Headache
  • Altered mental status (progressive decline of mental function and consciousness)
  • Papilledema leading to a blurring of vision
  • Breathlessness (due to hypoxia)
  • Nausea and vomiting.

Treatment involves administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude, and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension. Glucocorticoids are administered as well.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: A farmer is brought to the hospital 8 hours later, following a snake bite. He complained of headache, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, dizziness, vertigo, and multiple episodes of vomiting since the bite. He has signs of respiratory depression and a pulse <50. The local wound showed mild swelling and blistering. There are no apparent bleeding manifestations. He was administered 10 vials of antivenom. Which of the following is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a neurotoxic snake bite. Since this patient has already passed 8 hours without any bleeding manifestations, the bite of a hemotoxic snake is unlikely and the better management would be to address his neurotoxic symptoms with the administration of neostigmine with atropine.

The neurotoxic symptoms are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs, such as neostigmine. Atropine is administered to counter the muscarinic side effects of neostigmine. 

Neurotoxic symptoms include: 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Perioral paraesthesia (tingling sensation around the mouth)
  • Vomiting
  • Dizziness
  • Vertigo
  • Hyperacusis
  • Gooseflesh
  • Hypersalivation

Respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, at this stage or later. If it progresses to paralysis, it initially presents with ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia, which may appear between a few minutes after the bite or after some hours.

ASV(Anti Snake Venom) is the mainstay of snakebite treatment. Neurotoxicity effects may wear off spontaneously in about a week and are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase. Atropine can be used in the management of venom that acts postsynaptically. Ventilatory support is provided in cases complicated with severe respiratory depression, in the event of failure of other measures of management. 

ASV used in India is effective against:

  • Cobra
  • Common krait
  • Russel viper
  • Saw scaled viper

Measures that can be done in the case of snakebite:

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Clean the wound with soap and water, or iodine and cover it with a sterile dressing 
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap) on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. 
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb

questions.text:
Match the following:
1 - Kleptomania A - Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
2 - Pyromania B - Intense desire to mutilate
3 - Mutilomania C - Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
4 - Dipsomania D - Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the repeated failure to resist an impulse, drive, or urge to perform an act that is rewarding to the person, at least in the short-term, despite consequences such as long-term harm either to the individual or to others; marked distress about the behavior pattern; or significant impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

It includes

  1. Pyromania
  2. Kleptomania 
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are of no value to the person. The individual can usually afford the object or does not need it, but it is the act of stealing itself that is the goal. The stolen objects are usually given away, returned, or kept hidden. The act is not planned and is carried out alone.

Pyromania is the deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion. 

Pyromania is significantly associated with the following:

  • Substance abuse disorder (especially alcoholism).
  • Affective disorders (depression or bipolar)
  • Other impulse control disorders, such as kleptomania in female firesetters.
  • Personality disturbances, such as borderline personality disorders.
  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and learning disabilities in childhood pyromania.

Mutilomania is an irresistible impulse to mutilate animals.

Dipsomania is an irresistible impulse to drink alcohol at periodic intervals.

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
The site of the lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.

Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the light reflex, where, illumination of the blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction while illuminating the normal half shows a pupillary reaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumours of the optic thalamus.

The optic tracts contain both visual and pupillomotor fibres. The visual fibres terminate in the lateral geniculate body, but the pupillary fibres leave the optic tract anterior to the lateral geniculate body to terminate in the pretectal nuclei.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: What is the minimum dose of radiation exposure that may result in hematopoietic acute radiation syndrome?
questions.solution:
The hematopoietic system is the first organ system that demonstrates injury at doses between 0.7-10 Gy (70-1000 rads). The prodromal phase occurs within hours to days from exposure and is followed by a latent phase for 1-3 weeks.

Radiation damages the bone marrow cells and the circulating hematopoietic cells- mainly the lymphocytes. Granulocytes, platelets, and erythrocytes are also affected, erythrocytes being the least affected as they lack nuclei.

Cell counts increase immediately after the exposure because they are markers of inflammation. However, they later decline and reach an all-time low within 30 days of the injury. Since there is preferential destruction of lymphocytes, the peripheral lymphocyte count is currently the best marker to grade the extent of the injury.

The survival rate of hematopoietic syndrome decreases with increasing doses, but aggressive management with blood products and growth factors makes survival possible.

Syndrome    Dose* Prodromal Stage  Latent Stage Manifest Illness Stage Recovery
Hematopoietic (Bone marrow)  >0.7 Gy (>70 rads) (mild symptoms may occur as low as 0.3 Gy or 30 rads) 

Symptoms are

  • anorexia, nausea and vomiting.
  • Onset occurs 1 hour to 2 days after exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to days.  

Stem cells in bone marrow are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.

Stage lasts 1 to 6 weeks. 

Symptoms are

  • anorexia, fever, and malaise.
  • Drop in all blood cell counts occurs for several weeks.
  • Primary cause of death is infection and hemorrhage.
  • Survival decreases with increasing dose.
  • Most deaths occur within a few months after exposure.  

In most cases, bone marrow cells will begin to repopulate the marrow.

  • There should be full recovery for a large percentage of individuals from a few weeks up to two years after exposure.
  • Death may occur in some individuals at 1.2 Gy (120 rads).
  • The LD50/60† is about 2.5 to 5 Gy (250 to 500 rads). 
Gastrointestinal (GI) >10 Gy (>1000 rads) (some symptoms may occur as low as 6 Gy or 600 rads)

Symptoms are

  • anorexia, severe nausea, vomiting, cramps, and diarrhea.
  • Onset occurs within a few hours after exposure.
  • Stage lasts about 2 days.

Stem cells in bone marrow and cells lining GI tract are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.

Stage lasts less than 1 week.

Symptoms are

  • malaise, anorexia, severe diarrhea, fever, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Death is due to infection, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Death occurs within 2 weeks of exposure.
 The LD100 is about 10 Gy (1000 rads).
Cardiovascular (CV)/ Central Nervous System (CNS) >50 Gy (5000 rads) (some symptoms may occur as low as 20 Gy or 2000 rads)

Symptoms are

  • extreme nervousness and confusion; severe nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea; loss of consciousness; and burning sensations of the skin.
  • Onset occurs within minutes of exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to hours.

Patient may return to partial functionality.

Stage may last for hours but often is less.

Symptoms are

  • return of watery diarrhea, convulsions, and coma.
  • Onset occurs 5 to 6 hours after exposure.
  • Death occurs within 3 days of exposure.
 No recovery is expected.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is most abundant in collagen?
questions.solution:
The most abundant amino acid in collagen is glycine.

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. It consists of three alpha chains held together by hydrogen bonds forming a triple helical structure.

A striking characteristic of collagen is the occurrence of glycine residues at every third position, (Gly-X-Y) repeats.

Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues. This hydroxylation is catalyzed by the enzyme prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, and cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.

Intracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Signal peptide cleavage
  • Hydroxylation of prolyl residues and some lysyl residues, glycosylation of some hydroxylysine residues
  • Intrachain and interchain S–S bonds formation in extension peptides
  • Triple helix formation

Extracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Amino and carboxyl-terminal propeptides cleavage
  • Collagen fibers assembly in quarter-staggered alignment
  • Oxidative deamination of h-amino groups of lysyl and hydroxylysine residues
  • Intra and interchain cross-links formation

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. What is the staging?
questions.solution:
The given CT image is consistent with a staging of T4N1MO. It depicts the involvement of the lesion beyond the thyroid cartilage indicating a T4 stage.

 

Laryngeal cancer is more commonly seen in men. Alcohol and tobacco usage are considered risk factors for the development of the condition. The most common type is squamous cell carcinoma.

According to the american joint committee on cancer (AJCC) the larynx is divided into three regions - supraglottis, glottis, and subglottis. In the TNM system: T indicates extent of the tumor, N indicates lymph node involvement, and M indicates distant metastasis.

TNM classification of laryngeal carcinoma: 

Tumor (T)

1. Supraglottis

  • T1: Tumor limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility.
  • T2: Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsites of the supraglottis, glottis, or region outside the supraglottis.
  • T3: Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: post cricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space, and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion.
  • T4a: Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx
  • T4b: Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery, or invades mediastinal structures.

2. Glottis

  • T1: Tumor limited to vocal cord(s) with normal mobility
    • T1a: Tumor limited to one vocal cord
    • T1b: Tumor involves both vocal cords
  • T2: Tumor extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, and/or with impaired vocal cord mobility
  • T3: Tumor limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion.
  • T4a: Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx
  • T4b: Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery, or invades mediastinal structures

3. Subglottis

  • T1: Tumor limited to the subglottis
  • T2: Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility
  • T3: Tumor limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation
  • T4a: Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx
  • T4b: Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery, or invades mediastinal structures

Regional lymph nodes (N)

  • Nx: Cannot be assessed
  • No: No regional lymph node metastasis
  • N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, ≤3cm
  • N2: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, >3cm but <6cm or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes or bilateral lymph nodes none more than 6cm
  • N3: Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6cm 

Distant metastasis (M)

  • Mx: Metastasis cannot be assessed
  • Mo: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis

questions.text: 50 year old hypothyroid female presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass, which progresses over weeks to years associated with dysphagia. Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues,most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Hard “woody” thyroid gland is a feature of Riedel’s thyroiditis.

Riedel’s thyroiditis:

  • Invasive fibrous thyroiditis which is of autoimmune origin.
  • Characterised  by replacement of thyroid gland tissue with Fibrous tissue and may also invade  adjacent tissues.
  • The disease occurs predominantly in women between the ages of 30 and 60 years old.
  • It typically presents as a painless, hard anterior neck mass.
  • It progresses over weeks to years to produce symptoms of compression, including dysphagia, dyspnea, choking, and hoarseness.
  • Patients may present with symptoms of hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism as the gland is replaced by fibrous tissue.
  • Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues.
  • The diagnosis needs to be confirmed by open thyroid biopsy, because the firm and fibrous nature of the gland renders FNAB inadequate.

Treatment includes long-term glucocorticoids to decrease the inflammation being first choice. Tamoxifen has also been used. Surgery is indicated to relieve obstruction.

questions.text: The mode of gene transmission from one bacterium to another through bacteriophage is known as?
questions.solution:
Transduction is the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage.

Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option A - Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C - Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

Option D - Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the effect of substrate concentration on the rate of reaction?

choices.text: As substrate concentration increases, the initial velocity of the reaction increases until it reaches a maximum value (Vmax)
The substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half maximum is called Km
The Michaelis-Menten equation says that initial reaction velocity (Vi) = Vmax [S]/ Km+[S]
The plot of reaction velocity against substrate concentration is linear

questions.solution:
The plot of reaction velocity against substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

For a typical enzyme, as the substrate concentration increases, initial velocity (Vi) increases until it reaches a maximum value of Vmax. With further increase in the substrate concentration [S], the enzyme is said to be “saturated” with the substrate and the velocity remains the same. Hence, the shape of the curve that relates to the velocity of the reaction to substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

The Michaelis-Menten equation illustrates mathematically the relationship between Vi and [S] i.e,

Vi = Vmax ×[S]/Km+[S]

The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which Vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2).

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as____
questions.solution:
The above phenomenon is best described as the "tracking" of blood pressure.

In this phenomenon, the blood pressure of individuals is followed up from early childhood into adulthood. The BP in individuals with low BP levels tend to remain low, and in those with high BP levels, they tend to remain high. This phenomenon of persistence of rank order of blood pressure has been described as "tracking".

Other options:

Option A: The rule of halves depicts the disease burden of hypertension in the community. It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

A pictorial representation of the rule of halves in hypertension is shown below:

Option B: The WHO STEPwise approach to non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factor surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method for collecting, analyzing, and disseminating data on key NCD risk factors such as tobacco use, alcohol use, physical inactivity, unhealthy diet, overweight and obesity, raised blood pressure, raised blood glucose, and abnormal blood lipids.

questions.text: Light microscopy would not be helpful in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Light microscopy would not be helpful in minimal change disease (MCD).

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, oedema, hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral oedema.

A renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome. Light microscopy shows normal glomeruli and electron microscopy shows effacement of podocyte foot processes.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 60 mg/m2/day for 6 weeks, followed by a single dose of 40 mg/m2 on alternate days for the next 6 weeks is the standard treatment.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Intramembranous Dense deposits

questions.text: Which of the following artery does not take part in the cruciate anastomosis?
questions.solution:
The superior gluteal artery does not contribute to the formation of cruciate anastomosis.

Cruciate anastomosis lies at the level of the lesser trochanter and is formed by:

  • Transverse branches of medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries
  • Descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery
  • Ascending branch of the first perforating artery

The image given below shows the anastomosis around the hip joint.

Note: Traumatic insults to the lower extremity (fractures, stab wounds, or gunshot wounds) can result in blood loss. It is important for the clinician to understand the arterial anastomoses in the affected area so that bleeding can be appropriately managed and exsanguination can be avoided.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of Stapedotomy?
questions.solution:
Cholesteatoma is not a complication of stapedotomy.

Complications of stapedotomy:

  • SNHL
  • Facial palsy
  • Floating/ submerged footplate
  • Endolymph gusher due to damage to inner ear
  • Dislodgement of piston
  • Post-op vertigo

questions.text: A woman presents with complaints of greenish frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. On speculum examination, you are able to see the below finding. This is associated with
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is suggestive of a strawberry cervix. It is seen in trichomoniasis

The clinical features include vaginal discharge which is profuse, thin, slightly green in color, and frothy. It may be associated with vaginal irritation, dysuria, and increased frequency. Cervical inflammation with punctate hemorrhagic spots known as the strawberry cervix is typically seen in trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Motile trichomonads are seen on wet mount examination.

questions.text: An 80 year old woman presents with rapidly enlarging neck swelling, weight loss and hoarseness of voice. FNAC of the swelling reveals poorly differentiated follicular cells of the thyroid gland. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid is an undifferentiated aggressive carcinoma arising from follicular cells. It occurs commonly in elderly females. It is a very aggressive tumour of short duration.

Clinical features

Rapidly progressive swelling of the thyroid gland which causes stridor and hoarseness of voice due to tracheal obstruction, dysphagia and fixity to the skin.

Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis

Tracheostomy and isthmectomy have got a role to relieve respiratory obstruction temporarily. Treatment is external radiotherapy, as usually thyroidectomy is not possible. The prognosis is poor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with persistent backache not responding to conservative treatment. He has a history of lifting heavy weights 4 months back and progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking. The pain starts radiating down his legs after walking for a distance of around 100 m. However, he feels no pain walking uphill. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this scenario is lumbar stenosis.

Lumbar spinal stenosis is a common source of leg and back pain. It refers to a narrowing in the vertebra, in the areas of the central canal, lateral recess, or the neural foramen.With aging and wear-and-tear changes the intervertebral discs degenerate and protrude posteriorly. This lead to posterior vertebral osteophyte formation and ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, which in turn will cause spinal stenosis.

Patients present with pain exacerbated by prolonged ambulation, standing, and with lumbar extension, and is relieved by forward flexion and rest. Neurogenic claudication is an important feature of lumbar spinal stenosis. Symptoms are typically bilateral, but usually asymmetric. Low back pain, numbness, and tingling are present in a majority of patients. Numbness and tingling in lumbar spinal stenosis typically involve the entire leg and rarely affect only a single nerve root distribution

Treatment involves bony decompression of the nerve structures.

questions.text: A 1-week-old infant was born with a laryngeal defect. CT-scan revealed an ​absence of greater cornu of the hyoid and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition?

Greater horn (greater cornu) and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone are formed from the 3rd pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the local police station with a complaint of sexual assault. She mentions that she was raped by her husband even though she is legally separated from him for the past two years. She registers a complaint against him. Which among the following statements is false?

choices.text: Minimum punishment for this offence is 2 years imprisonment
Section 376B of the IPC deals with such cases
This is a cognizable offence on complaint of victim

questions.solution:
Sexual assault by the husband upon his wife during separation is a bailable offence. 

Section 376B deals with sexual intercourse by the husband with his wife during separation. It is cognizable (only on a complaint of the victim) and bailable. Punishment is imprisonment for not less than 2 years but which may extend to 7 years and with a fine.

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after consuming 100 tablets of aspirin. What should be the next step in management?

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.solution:
The next step in the management of this patient who consumed 100 tablets of aspirin is to give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize the urine.

Alkalinization of urine will be helpful in the removal of aspirin, which is a weakly acidic drug and is susceptible to ion trapping in the urine. It is done by administration of sodium bicarbonate in 1 L of 5% dextrose in water (D5W). It is infused intravenously at twice the maintenance fluid requirements.

Alkalinization of urine is contraindicated in renal failure or if fluid administration may worsen pulmonary edema or congestive heart failure.

Other options:

Option A: N-acetyl cysteine is used as an antidote for the treatment of paracetamol poisoning which replenishes glutathione stores in the liver.

Option B: Pralidoxime is also used in organophosphate poisoning. It regenerates active acetylcholinesterase and relieves skeletal muscle end-plate block. It is usually used as an adjuvant to atropine.

Option D: Glucagon is used in beta-blocker toxicity.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has a history of biting his lips and fingers. On evaluation, you notice lip lacerations, missing portions of fingers of his hands, and developmental delay. On inquiry, the parents say that two male cousins on the mother's side with similar complaints have been diagnosed with a genetic disorder. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones, positive family history and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) involved in the salvage pathway.

Purines produced in the body or introduced through diet can be converted to nucleoside triphosphates to be reused by the body. This pathway is called the salvage pathway for purines and is shown below

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). An increase in guanine and hypoxanthine eventually gets converted into uric acid, There is increased de novo purine synthesis.

The clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements, and hyperuricemia. The excess uric acid can form kidney stones (urolithiasis) or deposits in joints as urate crystals (gouty arthritis).

The treatment of this condition includes:

  • Allopurinol or febuxostat for hyperuricemia
  • Behavioural management using restraints for self-mutilation
  • High fluid intake, reduced fructose and purine intake

Partial deficiency of HGPRT leads to Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency leads to severe T-cell deficiency with normal B-cell function. Patients present with autoimmune diseases and opportunistic infections.

Option C: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) is another enzyme along with HGPRT to be involved in the salvage of purine bases to nucleotides. 

Option D: Adenosine deaminase deficiency leads to sparse or defective T cells and B cells. Patients suffer from severe immunodeficiency and often succumb to fatal infections. 

 

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

Related Pearl: Enzymes and Steps Involved in Purine Degradation
