questions.text: The best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area is by:
questions.solution:
Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman at 10 week of gestation comes to the clinic for a check-up following an MTP. On ultrasound, retained tissue was found and the following instrument was used for its removal. What is this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe.

Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done upto 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only upto 10 weeks of gestation . 

The indications of this procedure are given as follows:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy
  • Incomplete abortion or missed abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Endometrial aspiration

Karman's cannula is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.

questions.text: A girl presents with prolonged menstrual bleeding and her investigations showed- normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT while bleeding time was increased. On further analysis, a deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa was found. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

  • Autosomal recessive platelet surface receptor disorder of GPIIb/IIIa (ITG αIIbβ3), either qualitative or quantitative - Faulty platelet aggregation and diminished clot retraction.
  • Acquired GT is seen with platelet transfusions, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myelodysplastic syndrome, hairy cell leukemia, and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
  • Normal platelet morphology and normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, absent or decreased clot retraction, and normal platelet aggregation in the presence of ristocetin.
  • Platelet aggregation is absent in the presence of epinephrine, collagen, arachidonic acid, ADP.
  • Under flow cytometric analysis, CD41 and CD61 levels are markedly decreased or absent

Classification of platelet disorders

 

  Pathology Plt count BT PT aPTT
Vwd Qualitative and quantitative defects in vWF Usually normal Increased Normal Increased
Bernard Soulier Inherited deficiency of Gp Ib-IX Decreased Increased Normal Normal
ITP Autoantibodies against IIb-IIIa Decreased Increased Normal Normal
Glanzmann thrombasthenia Inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa Normal Increased Normal Normal

Note: PFA-100 system is a platelet function analyzer designed to measure platelet-related primary hemostasis which uses two disposable cartridges: a collagen/epinephrine (CEPI) and a collagen/ADP (CADP) cartridge. 

CEPI cartridges detect qualitative platelet defects, including acetylsalicylic acid (ASA)-induced abnormalities, while CADP cartridges detect only thrombocytopathies and not ASA use.

questions.text: Above knee perforators are called as:
questions.solution:
Above knee perforators are called as Dodd veins.

Perforator veins connect the deep and superficial venous systems, allowing the passage of blood in between them. Following are the named perforators of the lower limb:

  • Proximal thigh level perforators- Hunter perforator veins
  • Distal thigh perforators- Dodd perforator veins
  • Below the knee perforators- Boyd perforator veins 
  • Calf level perforators- Cockett perforator veins.

questions.text: Which intravenous fluid is preferred for the hydration of patients with pre-renal acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Isotonic crystalloids like 0.9% NaCl are preferred for the correction of hypovolemia in pre-renal AKI.

Management of AKI:

1. AKI care bundle:

  • Nephrotoxic drugs should be avoided and the dosage of other drugs must be adjusted according to kidney function
  • Creatinine levels and urine output must be closely monitored

2. Hemodynamic management:

  • If hypovolemic - fluid replenishment using isotonic crystalloids (normal saline)
  • If euvolemic - fluid intake = urine output + additional ~500 mL 
  • If hypervolemic - diuretics are administered. If the response is unsatisfactory, dialysis is required.

3. Management of complications:  

  • Pulmonary edema - Treated with diuretics, non-invasive ventilation, and dialysis if refractory
  • Metabolic acidosis - Treated when pH <7.2 with oral or IV sodium bicarbonate
  • Hyperkalemia - Treated by restriction of dietary potassium, administration of sodium polystyrene sulfonate, insulin, glucose, inhaled β-agonist, and calcium gluconate

Options A and B: Hydroxyethyl starch solutions and dextrans increase the risk of severe AKI and are contraindicated.

Option D: Ringer's lactate is preferred only when a large volume of fluids is required.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the standard care along with ORS in children with acute diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Zinc is given as a part of the standard care along with ORS in children with acute diarrhoea

Zinc deficiency has been found to be widespread among children in developing countries. Intestinal zinc losses during diarrhoea aggravate pre-existing zinc deficiency. Zinc supplementation is now part of the standard care along with ORS in children with acute diarrhoea. It is helpful in decreasing the severity and duration of diarrhoea and also the risk of persistent diarrhoea.

Vitamin A should therefore be given to all severely malnourished children as a part of the management of SAM and is not a routine standard of care in acute diarrhoea.

Antibiotics are not recommended for routine treatment of acute diarrhoea in children. In acute diarrhoea, antimicrobials are indicated in bacillary dysentery, cholera, amebiasis and giardiasis.

Probiotics contain microorganisms that exert beneficial effects on human health when they colonize the bowel. They have been proposed as adjunctive therapy in the treatment of acute diarrhoea and is not a routine standard of care.

WHO IMNCI PLANS:

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community?
questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate (IMR) is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care in a community.

Infant mortality rate (IMR) = Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births x 1000.

It is one of the universally accepted healthcare indicators for the whole population and the socioeconomic conditions under which they live.

Other options:

Option B:  While the maternal mortality rate is an important indicator of maternal healthcare services, it is not as sensitive as the infant mortality rate in reflecting the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community.

Option C: Immunization coverage is an essential factor in preventing diseases and promoting public health. However, it is a narrower indicator than the infant mortality rate, focusing primarily on preventive healthcare services for children. Full immunization coverage is defined as the proportion of infants 9-11 months old who have received the 3 doses of DPT vaccine, BCG vaccine, 3 doses of OPV, and one dose of measles vaccine against the estimated number of infants during a specific year.

Option D: Disability-adjusted life years are a useful measure of the overall burden of disease in a population, but they are less sensitive in assessing the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare services in a community compared to the infant mortality rate.

questions.text: A 44-year old businessman came to the casualty with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis since early morning. He was diagnosed with depression 4 months back and has been on phenelzine. He gives the history of attending an office party the previous night where he consumed some red wine. On examination, his BP was 190/120. What is false about his present condition?

choices.text: The condition is less common with selegilline.
He is suffering from serotonin syndrome.
Tyramine is involved the pathogenesis of the condition.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cheese reaction, not serotonin syndrome.

Here, the patient on phenelzine (non-selective and irreversible MAO inhibitor) developed the clinical features of cheese reaction on having tyramine-rich food (red wine, cheese, milk).

Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter the systemic circulation. It is taken up by adrenergic neurons and a hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of the powerful pressor effect of tyramine. 

The drug of choice to treat hypertensive crisis in cheese reactions is phentolamine. 

MAO-inhibitor with SSRI causes serotonin syndrome. Symptoms are fever, altered mental status, rigidity, hyperreflexia, and autonomic dysfunction.

Selegiline and rasagiline do not functionally inhibit MAO-A. They do not cause cheese reaction with doses used in clinical practice.

questions.text: A woman underwent internal fixation for a fracture of the femur shaft. She was put on an above-knee cast after the surgery which was removed after a month. While massaging her legs the next morning, she developed sudden onset of breathlessness and chest pain. Her chest examination was normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of immobilization after the application of the cast is a risk factor for Deep Vein Thrombosis. Massaging the leg may dislodge the thrombus causing pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system. It is the commonest complication of deep vein thrombosis leading to death. Larger emboli wedge in the main pulmonary artery causing a wedge-shaped infarct, while smaller emboli occlude the peripheral arteries.

Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) include Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause), childbirth, Immobility – Bed-ridden, long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis), pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives.

It occurs commonly in the pelvic veins and leg veins-femoral and popliteal veins.

Patients present with fever, tenderness, warmth and pale swollen calf. Homan’s, Mose’s or Neuhof’s signs and inverted champagne bottle sign can be seen on examination.

Pneumothorax presents with sudden onset breathlessness but has reduced breath sounds and hyper resonant on percussion. This patient has a normal chest examination.

questions.text: A patient started on an antihypertensive presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The image shows edema over the lips and face and its occurrence following intake of an antihypertensive is suggestive of drug-induced angioedema. Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor), is most likely responsible for this condition.

Angioedema with ACE inhibitors:

In very few patients(0.1%-0.5%), ACE inhibitors cause rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. Once the drug is stopped symptoms improve drastically over hours. Angioedema of the intestine can occur very rarely. 

ACE inhibitor-associated angioedema is a class effect, and patients who develop this adverse event should not be prescribed any other drugs within the ACE inhibitor class.

Other adverse effects of ACE inhibitors:

  • A sudden fall in blood pressure can occur following the first dose of ACE inhibitors.
  • It can produce a bothersome dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs. The cough usually disappears within 4 days of the stoppage of the drug.
  • Hyperkalemia due to K+ retention can occur.
  • Acute renal failure can occur with ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, stenosis of the artery to a single remaining kidney, heart failure, or volume depletion due to diarrhea or diuretics.
  • It should be discontinued in pregnant women as it can cause developmental defects.
  • It can also cause maculopapular skin rash in some cases.

Other options:

Option B: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker. Common adverse effects include headache, flushing, and dizziness. Peripheral edema (pedal edema) may rarely occur.

Option C: Atenolol is a beta-1 selective antagonist. Bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities are common adverse effects. CNS side effects like nightmares and depression are less frequent with atenolol than other beta-blockers.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. The main adverse effects of clonidine are dry mouth and sedation. Bradycardia and sexual dysfunction are other effects.

questions.text: The term demographic bonus is denotes______
questions.solution:
The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility.

A decline in the dependency ratio especially young age dependency ratio has been identified to be a key factor underlying the rapid economic development.

Demographic burden refers to an increase in the total dependency ratio, mostly caused by increased old-age dependency ratio.

Dependency ratio:

  • Adults ≥65 years and children from 0 – 14 years are considered dependents.
  • The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 – 65 years.
  • Total dependency ratio = (children 0-14 years age + population above 65 years age) x 100/Total population in the age group of 15 – 64 years).
  • It is also called societal dependency ratio.
  • The total dependency ratio can also be divided into young age dependency ratio and old age dependency ratio.
  • As of 2016, the dependency ratio of India is 52%.
  • The potential support ratio is the inverse of the old age dependency ratio. It is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more.

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.solution:
The image above shows the fungus cryptococcus.

The image shows India ink preparation which is employed to detect the presence of capsulated yeast, cryptococcus neoformans. It induces negative staining by creating a black, semi-opaque background that makes the capsule of the yeast clearly visible. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is demonstrated as clear halos against a black background.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. It may cause infection in immune-competent people, resulting in a flu-like illness with complete recovery.

Infection in immunocompromised people like AIDS patients or patients with hematological malignancies results in meningoencephalitis.

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of cryptococcus. The image given below shows mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci.

Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37'C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white. The cryptococcal antigen(in serum and CSF) is sensitive and specific and can be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves a combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole can be added with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is due to a lesion in the _______.
questions.solution:
Lesion to the medial longitudinal fasciculus causes internulcear ophthalmoplegia.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

  • Lesion to medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
  • Seen in multiple sclerosis

Anatomy

  • After initiation, horizontal eye movements are generated in the horizontal gaze centre (PPRF) and mediated via a common pathway.
  • From here, impulses travel
    • directly to the ipsilateral sixth nerve nucleus and
    • indirectly via internuclear neurons that cross the midline at the level of the pons and pass up the contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), to motor neurones in the medial rectus subnucleus of the contralateral third nerve complex.
  • Stimulation of the horizontal gaze center on one side, thereby causing a conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side.

Features:

  • Defect in ipsilateral adduction: Medial rectus defect
  • Horizontal diplopia
  • Nystagmus of opposite eye
  • Convergence is normal

 Image: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

questions.text: An elderly patient in the gynecology ward was diagnosed with urge incontinence. What is the etiology of this condition?

choices.text: Pelvic mass in pouch of Doughlas

questions.solution:
A patient who suffers from urge incontinence suffers from detrusor instability.

The patient experiences an involuntary escape of urine with an urge to urinate. It occurs due to detrusor muscle overactivity or detrusor instability. It is seen more commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity, decreased sensation, and central nervous system (CNS) inhibition.

questions.text: All are true regarding Caroli’s disease except?
questions.solution:
The presentation of Caroli’s disease may be with abdominal pain or sepsis and not ascites.

Caroli’s disease:

  1. Caroli’s disease is congenital dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary tree.
  2. There is biliary stasis and sludge formation leading to obstruction of bile flow.
    Patients present with episodes of recurrent bacterial cholangitis: abdominal pain, fevers, chills, and jaundices
  3. At an older age, after the development of hepatic fibrosis, and patients present with signs of portal hypertension such as ascites and variceal bleeding.
  4. Patients with Caroli disease are at an increased risk for the development of cholangiocarcinoma.
  5. This disease is often complicated by the presence of intrahepatic stone formation.
  6. Biliary stasis with stone formation can lead to biliary sepsis.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in a partial hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Partial hydatidiform mole has focal villous edema.

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Partial moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms.
  • The karyotype is usually triploid (69, XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92, XXXY).
  • Fetal tissues are typically present.
  • They are associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but are not associated with choriocarcinoma.

Complete moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes.
  • In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46, XX karyotype.
  • In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46, XX, or 46, XY.
  • In complete moles, the embryo usually dies early in the development, and hence, cannot be identified. 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: What is the indication for the procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
The given procedure is McDonald's cerclage which is done for cervical incompetence. 

Cervical incompetence is the impairment of the retentive power of the cervix. It can be due to anatomical causes or functional causes. It leads to painless dilation of the cervix and painless expulsion of the products of conception in the mid-trimester.  Cervical incompetence is diagnosed by clinical examination and ultrasonography showing the presence of short cervix (<25 mm) with or without funnelling of the internal os.

Prophylactic cerclage is done around 14 weeks of pregnancy or 2 weeks earlier than the previous fetal loss. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation.

Removal of cerclage should be done by 37 weeks of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labor or if signs of abortion are seen.

Commonly used types of procedures for cervical cerclage during pregnancy:

  • McDonald's procedure: purse-string suture
  • Modified Shirodkar's procedure:

questions.text: A 40-year-old construction worker involves in work where he gets repeatedly exposed to noise of around 100 dB at the construction site. This could lead to ____
questions.solution:
Repeated exposure to the sound of 100 dB can lead to permanent hearing loss.

Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when the sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text:
Match the following splints and the conditions where they are used.
  1. Cervical spine injury
  2. Brachial plexus injury
  3. Radial nerve palsy
  4. Ulnar nerve palsy
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

  1. Knuckle bender splint - Ulnar nerve palsy
  2. Cock-up splint  - Radial nerve palsy
  3. Aeroplane splint - Brachial plexus injury
  4. SOMI Brace - Cervical spine injury

Knuckle bender splint :

In cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated, the knuckle bender splint can be used to correct and prevent MCP (metacarpophalangeal) hyperextension.

Cock-up splint - 

it is used in the management of radial nerve palsy.

Aeroplane splint:

It is used in the management of brachial plexus injury and axillary nerve injury.

SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is used to treat cervical spine injury. 

It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. The SOMI brace may be used as a treatment for cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed after cervical spine surgery as a recovery aid.

questions.text: A 5-day-old infant is seen with a rash on his nose, cheek and forehead, as shown in the image below. On examination, they are noted to be pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Milia is the most probable diagnosis. This condition presents with small cysts formed around the pilosebaceous follicles usually seen over the nose, cheek, and forehead. They are pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. 

Infantile milia may occasionally be associated with oral lesions on the gingivae or palate. Milia are more common in white children, but less frequent in children born prematurely or of low gestational weight. They resolve spontaneously without scarring.

 Other options:

Option A: Erythema toxicum presents with papular lesions on an erythematous base with eosinophil laden sterile lesions, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. It is a normal finding in many newborns. They are seen 1–3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week and resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment.

Option B: Pustular melanosis is a benign transient condition that lasts for 2-3 days in newborns. It is seen predominantly in black neonates. The lesions are vesiculopustular eruption and have neutrophils.

Option C: Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: The most common renal lesion in hepatitis C infection is
questions.solution:
The most common renal lesion in hepatitis C infection is cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis, followed by membranous glomerulonephritis, and type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate when the temperature is less than 37°C. Cryoglobulinemia means the presence of cryoglobulins in the serum. Deposition of these immune complexes leads to cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis. 

Causes of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis:

  • Idiopathic
  • Hepatitis C
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Liver diseases

The presence of cryoprecipitate containing oligoclonal/polyclonal immunoglobulins in the absence of underlying disease was called essential mixed cryoglobulinemia. The majority of these cases have an underlying hepatitis C infection.

Laboratory investigations will show the presence of circulating cryoprecipitates, positive for rheumatoid factor, and hypocomplementemia. They have to be tested for hepatitis C antibodies and hepatitis C RNA.

questions.text: A young intravenous drug abuser presents with a 1-week history of malaise, fatigue, and rigors. On examination, a high-pitched murmur was heard loudest at the fourth intercostal space in the parasternal region and a cutaneous lesion as seen in the image below was observed. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is infective endocarditis. The most common cause of this disease in intravenous drug users is Staphylococcus aureus.

Infective endocarditis is caused due to an infection of cardiac valves. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus.

Infective endocarditis in patients who inject drugs commonly affects the tricuspid valve. In the case of tricuspid regurgitation patients present with high-pitched murmur heard loudest at the fourth intercostal space in the parasternal region.

The image in the vignette is of Osler's nodes. Osler nodes are painful, with raised lesions of the fingers, toe, and feet. They are peripheral lesions seen in patients with infective endocarditis. 

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Clinical criteria
  2. Pathologic criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Clinical Criteria

Major Criteria

1. Positive blood culture

Typical microorganism for IE from 2 separate blood cultures.

(or)

Persistently positive blood culture of an organism consistent with IE from:

  • Blood cultures drawn >12 h apart.
  • All of 3 or a majority of ≥4 separate blood cultures, with first and last drawn at least 1 h apart.

(or)

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800.

 

2. Evidence of endocardial involvement

Echocardiographic identification of oscillating intracardiac mass on valve or implant or in the path of regurgitant jets

(or)

New Valvular regurgitation

Minor Criteria

1. Predisposing heart lesion or intravenous drug use

2. Fever ≥38.0°C (≥100.4°F)

3. Vascular lesions: Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions.

4. Immunological evidence: Glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor.

5. Microbiologic evidence: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion, or serologic evidence of active infection with an organism consistent with infective endocarditis.

 

Pathological Criteria

1. Microorganisms demonstrated by culture or histologic examination, in vegetation, embolus from vegetation, or intracardiac abscess

(or)

2. Histologic confirmation of active endocarditis in vegetation or intracardiac abscess

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established, if symptoms resolve and do not recur with ≤4 days of antibiotic therapy, or if surgery or autopsy after ≤4 days of antimicrobial therapy yields no histologic evidence of endocarditis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly associated  cardiovascular defect with Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome is endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

 Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere)

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and a wider gap between first and second toes

A score based on eight signs in the diagnosis of Down's syndrome in the newborn (Hall's criteria)

  • Abundant neck skin
  • Mouth corners turned downwards
  • General hypotonia
  • Flat face
  • Dysplastic ear
  • Epicanthic fold
  • The gap between first and second toes
  • Protruding tongue

The presence of the last 3 points is considered clinically proven Down syndrome. It is suggested that this score should be used routinely for the clinical evaluation of every newborn where the possibility of a diagnosis of Down syndrome has been raised.

 Note:

Down’s syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability.

  • The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign).
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukemia, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML). 
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life.
  • The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML).
  • The most common hematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM).
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

Image: Features of Down’s syndrome

Image: Brushfield's spots

questions.text: Which of the following skeletal muscle relaxants exhibit the following response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine exhibits the above-given response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade.

Train of four protocol is one of the methods used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade. It is done by stimulating the ulnar nerve with a stimulus and watching the contractile responses in the adductor pollicis muscle. Four successive stimuli of 2Hz strength are given at fixed time intervals and the response achieved is plotted as a graph.

  Non-depolarizing blockers Depolarizing blockers
Fade phenomenon  Present 

Phase 1: Absent

Phase 2: Present 
Mechanism

Initial stimulus: Amount of Ach released is large enough to compete with the drug at the motor endplate causing maximal contraction of the muscle.

Successive stimuli: Amount of Ach released is insufficient to compete with the drug and results in sequentially diminished contractions

Phase 1: No competition between Sch and Ach. Sch acts like Ach at its receptors, but is not as easily metabolized by acetylcholinesterases resulting in persistent depolarisation. 

Phase 2: When the dose of Sch is increased maximally, it also exhibits a fade phenomenon.

questions.text: What is the CT number of air?
questions.solution:
CT number of air is −1000 HU.

On CT, each image consists of a matrix of data points (pixels) that are assigned a number that represents the X-ray attenuation(μ) at that point in the body. CT number is a scaled version of μ that is normalised to the X-ray attenuation of water (μW).

CT = 1000 × (μ/μW − 1)

The resulting numbers are called ‘Hounsfield units’(HU). Due to this normalisation, and water is assigned 0 HU and air is assigned a CT number of −1000 HU.

CT numbers:

  • Water = 0 HU
  • Solid soft tissues are centered around 0 HU
    • Lungs = -1000 HU
  • Air = −1000 HU
  • Dense cortical bone = +1000 HU

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the finding given in the CT image?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the finding given in the CT image is pneumatised superior turbinate.

The superior turbinate is situated posterior and superior to the middle turbinate. It may get pneumatized by one or more cells. It forms an important landmark to identify the ostium of the sphenoid sinus which lies medial to it. Pneumatization is a commonly observed anatomical variation of the lateral nasal wall.

It can give rise to symptoms such as nasal obstruction, headache, epistaxis, anosmia, and postnasal drainage. In addition, it predisposes an individual to sinusitis by disrupting the mucociliary clearance and thereby affecting sinus drainage. It is usually an incidental finding on radiological examination and a CT scan helps in the diagnosis.

Superior turbinate pneumatization is mostly asymptomatic and does not require any treatment. However, when symptoms do occur, surgical techniques like outfracture, crushing, radio-frequency ablation, turbinoplasty, and microdebrider surgery may be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Pneumatization of middle turbinate leads to an enlarged middle turbinate which is ballooned out, this is called concha bullosa. 

The CT image shown below depicts concha bullosa.

Option C: Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal cell that may grow posteriorly, either by the side of the sphenoid sinus or superior to it. Onodi cell is surgically important as the optic nerve may be related to its lateral wall. 

A CT image of an onodi cell is shown below.

Option D: Haller cells are air cells situated in the roof of the maxillary sinus. They are pneumatized from anterior or posterior ethmoid cells. Enlargement of haller cells may lead to maxillary sinusitis as it may encroach the ethmoid infundibulum, impeding draining of the maxillary sinus.

A CT image of a haller cell is shown below.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a sore throat and a sandpaper rash as shown in the picture for the past 2 days. Tongue examination shows swollen papillae. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and rash of the child are suggestive of Scarlet fever.

Scarlet fever is a blanching, papular rash, commonly described as a sandpaper rash. It is usually associated with Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis in school-age and adolescent children.

The rash appears within 24–48 hrs of the onset of symptoms (upper respiratory infections). The trunk, underarms, and groin are affected first, and then it spreads to the extremities. Usually, the palms and soles are spared. The circumoral cheeks are erythematous, with pallor around the mouth.

The tongue is usually coated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in the left eye. A diagnosis was made and enucleation was done. The specimen is shown below. The microscopic appearance shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histology, clinical history, and gross specimen point toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. 

It most commonly presents with leukocoria followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain is the investigation of choice.

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy.Vincristine, Carboplatin, Etoposide are the choice of drugs for chemotherapy. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
 
Enucleation is done when the tumor involves more than half of the retina, optic nerve involvement, glaucoma, and anterior chamber involvement.

questions.text: A patient with lymphatic filarisis is being managed as shown in the image below. What is the level of prevention done here?
questions.solution:
The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection. Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

Other options:

Option A: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

Option C: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

Option D: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Early detection and intervention to minimize disability

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with frequent episodes of nose-bleeds. She also complains of frequent episodes of headache and fever. The following test is positive in this patient. Which of the given findings is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Cottle’s test which is positive in patients with deviated nasal septum. Septal perforation is not associated with DNS. Septal perforation usually occurs as a consequence of septal abscess.

Cottle's test: The cheek of the patient is drawn laterally during quiet breathing. If this improves the airway on the test side, the test is considered to be positive. This suggests an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve causing nasal obstruction.

DNS is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction: Deviated nasal septum may lead to obstruction of the nasal cavity at different levels based on the type of deviation.
  • Chronic sinusitis: Deviated septum causes obstruction to the ostia of the sinuses. This causes poor ventilation of the sinuses leading to sinusitis.
  • Middle ear infection
  • Epistaxis: There is drying of the mucosa over the deviated septum due to air currents. This leads to the formation of crusts which, on removal, cause epistaxis.
  • Anosmia: reduced airflow may lead to anosmia
  • External deformity: External deformities of the septum may be seen due to deviation of the cartilaginous or the bony part of the nasal septum. Deformity of the tip or columella may also be seen.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with NYHA class III heart failure presents with dyspnea, pedal edema, potassium level of 5.5 mmol/L, and creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Furosemide can be used in this patient. All the other drugs mentioned are avoided due to the risk of hyperkalemia.

The drugs used in heart failure that can cause hyperkalemia include:

  • β-blockers - Interferes with β2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake
  • ACE inhibitors - Inhibition of angiotensin II formation with a decrease in aldosterone secretion
  • Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) - Blocks AT1 receptor decreasing aldosterone secretion
  • K+ sparing diuretics - Inhibition of aldosterone
  • Digoxin - Inhibition of Na+/K+/ATPase pump

NYHA classification of heart failure:

NYHA class Description
I
  • No limitation of physical activity
  • Ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms
II
  • Slight limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
III
  • Marked limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
IV
  • Unable to carry out any physical activity without symptoms or symptoms at rest

questions.text: In patients with renal diseases, albumin is the first to appear in the urine. What is the reason behind this?
questions.solution:
In renal diseases, albumin is the first to appear because of its effective molecular diameter. 

Both charge and size selectivity normally prevent virtually all plasma albumin, globulins, and other high-molecular-weight proteins from crossing the glomerular wall. However, if this barrier is disrupted, plasma proteins may leak into the urine.

The molecular diameter of the albumin is only about 6 nanometers, whereas the pores of the glomerular membrane are thought to be about 8 nanometers. In minimal change nephropathy, the negative charges on the basement membrane are lost even before there are noticeable changes in kidney histology. As a result of this loss of negative charges on the basement membranes, some of the lower molecular weight proteins, especially albumin (effective molecular diameter of 7 nm), are filtered and appear in the urine, a condition known as proteinuria or albuminuria.

questions.text: You are a physiologist, studying the microstructure of a skeletal muscle. In the image given below, all of the following can be found in the area marked 'x' except ______.
questions.solution:
The marked region 'x' is depicting the I-band of the myofibril. It does not contain myosin.

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises 1 entire A band and 2 half-I bands. 

A band consists of Myosin (thick filaments) surrounded by Actin filaments. I-band comprises thin filaments that contain actin, troponin, and tropomyosin. H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. During skeletal muscle contraction, A band remains constant. Z lines come closer to each other. H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.

Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: Nerve supply to the muscle marked in the diagram below:
questions.solution: The muscle marked in the above image is the Teres Major and it is supplied by the Lower Subscapular Nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

Carbonic anhydrase is predominantly present in the epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule. By inhibiting carbonic anhydrase, HCO3- reabsorption is blocked and diuresis occurs.

Examples of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are acetazolamide, methazolamide, dichlorphenamide, and dorzolamide.

They are used in the treatment of glaucoma, urinary alkalinization in cystinuria, management of metabolic alkalosis, and acute mountain sickness.

These drugs may lower the urinary excretion of NH4+, which can contribute to the development of hyperammonemia and hepatic encephalopathy in patients with cirrhosis.

Other options:

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and acts by the inhibition of the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule

Option C: Furosemide is a loop diuretic and acts by inhibiting Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle.

Option D: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was admitted to the hospital with complaints of bedwetting, increased thirst and increased urination for 1 year. His father is a known case of diabetes insipidus. A water deprivation test confirms the diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The treatment includes all of the following except _________.
questions.solution:
Treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) includes pharmacologic treatment, which should be combined with salt restriction.

Treatment of nephrogenic DI (TIA-S): 

  • Thiazide diuretics
  • Indomethacin
  • Amiloride
  • Salt restriction

Thiazide diuretics paradoxically decrease the overall urine output (decrease in GFR) in NDI. Indomethacin and amiloride may be used in combination with thiazides to reduce polyuria.

questions.text: In a fasting state, glucagon promotes the production of glucose by which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
The source of blood glucose in a fasting state is Gluconeogenesis and Glycogenolysis. It is promoted by glucagon.

The first stage of fasting: The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting i.e; 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 11 hours will be liver glycogenolysis.

Second stage of fasting: Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days.

Substrates for gluconeogenesis are:

  • Glucogenic amino acids ( mainly alanine) from the muscle and
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue 

During fasting, the glucogenic amino acids are transported to the liver, transaminated into pyruvate, and converted to glucose.

Third stage of fasting:

  • Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by increased glucagon: insulin ratio.
  • Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. Triacylglycerols will be hydrolyzed to fatty acids and glycerol. 
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place which provides acetyl CoA. 
  • In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

Final stage of fasting: After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin. Hence glucagon: insulin ratio is increased.

Effects of increased glucagon: insulin ratio on enzymes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis:

  1. It activates glycogen phosphorylase, the key enzyme of glycogenolysis, and deactivates glycogen synthase. This causes a rapid mobilization of liver glycogen stores to be utilized as fuel.
  2. It favors the synthesis of glucose-6-phosphatase which converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. The resulting glucose is used by red blood cells (lack mitochondria) and the brain as they are largely dependent on glucose in the fasting state.
  3. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase and fructose-1, 6-bisphosphatase are induced, leading to increased gluconeogenesis.
Metabolic process         Fasting state      Fed state
Glucagon: insulin   Increased              Decreased
Gluconeogenesis    Increased                Decreased            
Glycogenolysis  Increased                Decreased
Ketogenesis  Increased                Decreased
Glycogen storage  Decreased  Increased

questions.text: Submucous fibroid can be detected by ___
questions.solution:
All of the above investigation can be done for submucous fibroid

  • USG is the most common investigation done. Transvaginal USG is useful to assess location, dimension and associated adnexal pathology.
  • MRI gives better soft tissue details but is not routinely done
  • Laparoscopy - If uterus is <12 weeks size and there is associated pelvic pain and infertility - to detect pelvic endometriosis and tubal pathology.
  • Saline infusion sonography and hysteroscopy are especially useful in submucous fibroids. 
  • Uterine curettage – Bump is felt in submucous fibroid during endometrial curettage.
  • HSG – Filling defect is seen.

A submucous fibroid clearly outlined during a saline infusion sonography:

questions.text: You are an intern examining a 68-year-old male patient who is a known case of rheumatic heart disease. You are able to feel a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. What is the type of pulse?
questions.solution:
A 68-year-old male patient who is a known case of rheumatic heart disease with a bifid pulse is suggestive of aortic regurgitation and the type of pulse is Pulsus bisferiens. It is a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR)
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Water hummer or Corrigan's pulse (option A) is one which collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls during late systole and diastole. Quincke's pulse (option B) is seen when pressure is applied at the tip of the nail. It causes alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail. These pulses can be seen in aortic regurgitation.

Pulsus paradoxus (option D) is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade, massive pulmonary embolism, haemorrhagic shock, obstructive lung disease and tension pneumothorax. It is characterised by a fall in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration.

The below image shows different arterial pressure waves

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought into the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There is no history of fever, night sweats, and weight loss. MRI  was done and the ​image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This HIV patient with seizures and MRI showing a solitary rim-enhancing lesion in the left posterior frontal lobe most likely has cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis:

  • It is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL.
  • It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Diagnosis:

MRI: Usually multiple lesions in multiple locations, however, in some cases a single lesion may be present. These lesions are associated with inflammation and central necrosis and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Surrounding edema is usually present.

Treatment: Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Prophylaxis: Primary prophylaxis with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given to patients with low CD4+ T cell count. The same regimen also offers primary protection against P. jirovecii. 

Other conditions with single or multiple enhancing mass lesions in the HIV-infected patient include primary CNS lymphoma (usually solitary, solid and subependymal lesion) and, less commonly, TB or fungal or bacterial abscesses.

Cryptococcus neoformans is the most common cause of meningitis in HIV patients. It does not cause ring-enhancing lesions

Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is encephalitis caused when JC polyomavirus infects the oligodendrocytes and leads to demyelination. It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. The patients develop focal and progressive neurological symptoms. MRI would show multifocal, asymmetric periventricular and subcortical involvement.

questions.text: Based on the disease shown in the image, which of the following specimens would the filarial worms be absent?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis, and the filarial worms cannot be demonstrated in saliva.

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of W.bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. The third stage larval forms from the mosquito enter the lymphatics and lymph nodes where they develop into adult worms. The adult worms become sexually mature and mate to release microfilariae which enter the peripheral circulation.

The disease initially causes acute attacks of lymphangitis and lymphadenitis. Early treatment may even cure the disease. The lymphedema may gradually worsen and get associated with the thickening of the skin and fibrosis of lymph vessels or blockage by adult worms. Hydrocele is another common manifestation that occurs due to lymphatic obstruction.

Microfilaria can be demonstrated in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid, however, peripheral blood is the preferred choice. The examination of a thick and thin blood smear stained with Giemsa stain shows the microfilaria. Other methods are by examining the unstained blood under a microscope for the actively motile microfilariae and by acridine orange-microhematocrit tube technique.

The best time to collect the blood samples is at night, between 10 pm and 4 am as they are nocturnally periodic.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

*Note:

  • W.bancrofti causes Bancroftian filariasis and is transmitted by Culex quinquefasciatus (C. fatigans). In India, Wuchereria bancrofti is the commonest cause of filariasis.
  • B. malayi causes Burgian filariasis and the vector is the Mansonia mosquito.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about cephalhematoma?

choices.text: It is usually found immediately after birth
It usually gets absorbed within 2-4 days
It is usually located on the presenting part of the head

questions.solution:
The true statement about cephalhematoma is that it may cause neonatal jaundice.

Cephalhematoma is a well-defined swelling that is contained within suture lines and does not cross them. It is not present at the time of birth and usually develops after a few hours/one day. This swelling is usually filled with blood. Hence, the resulting hemolysis leads to the development of jaundice with hyperbilirubinemia in the neonate. Some babies may require phototherapy in severe cases. It resolves within 2 weeks to a few months.

Caput succedaneum is an ill-defined swelling over the scalp that is caused by excessive pressure to the neonatal head by the cervix and pelvic walls during vaginal delivery. It presents as a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It is present at the time of delivery. It does not require any treatment and disappears within 1 week of life. Scalp ecchymoses are a feature of this condition.

Sub-galeal hemorrhage- It is an accumulation of blood underneath the aponeurosis of the scalp (galea aponeurotica). This is also a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It usually occurs due to rupture of emissary veins and is associated with vacuum-assisted delivery. A timely diagnosis is essential to prevent hypovolemic shock and death of the neonate.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of recurrent patellar dislocation. Which of the following would not be a cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Patella baja is an abnormally low-lying patella and is not responsible for recurrent dislocation of the patella.

Causes for recurrent dislocation of the patella include:

  • Excessive joint laxity as in connective tissue disorders like EDS, Marfan's syndrome
  • Patella alta - the patella is high-lying in the shallow part of the inter-condylar groove
  • Trochlear dysplasia
  • Small patella
  • Genu valgum

Given below is a lateral radiograph of the knee joint showing the Insall-Salvati index. This is the ratio of the patella tendon length (LT) to the length of the patella (LP). 

  • In patients with high-lying patella, the ratio is above 1.2. This is known as patella alta. 
  • In patients with low-lying patella, the ratio is below 0.8. This is known as patella baja.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not predispose to Eustachian tube obstruction?
questions.solution:
Choanal atresia does not predispose to eustachian tube obstruction.

Eustachian tube obstruction is caused by:

  • Extrinsic causes
    • Adenoids
    • Nasopharyngeal tumors
    • Nasal pack
  • Intrinsic causes
    • Allergic Rhinitis
    • Rhinosinusitis
    • URTI
  • Defective functioning of the tube
    • Cleft palate
    • Down syndrome
    • Submucous cleft palate

Eustachian tube obstruction can lead to

  • ASOM
  • OME
  • CSOM
  • Atelectasis and ossicular necrosis

questions.text: Weiss operation is done in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Weiss operation is done in senile entropion. In this operation, transverse lid split and everting sutures are placed.

Entropion refers to the inward rolling and rotation of the lid margin towards the globe. It is more common in the lower lid.

Causes include:

  • Horizontal lid laxity
  • Vertical lid instability
  • Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis during lid closure
  • Orbital septum laxity

 

Cicatricial entropion

Senile entropion

Anterior lamellar resection

Transverse everting suture

Tarsal wedge resection

Weiss operation

Transposition of the tarsoconjunctival wedge. (Modified Ketssey’s operation)

Plication of lower lid retractors (Jones operation).

Posterior lamellar graft

Quickert procedure

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient was referred to you with features of pituitary adenoma and testicular tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you saw the presence of parathyroid adenoma, and his chromosomal studies show a mutation in the CDKN1B gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CDKN1B gene : Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1b gene
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of pituitary adenoma, parathyroid adenoma, testicular tumor, and a mutation in the CDKN1B gene is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4 (MEN 4).

MEN 4 is an autosomal dominant endocrine tumor syndrome. It occurs due to the germline mutation in the CDKN1B gene in chromosome 12.

MEN 4 often presents with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, or neuroendocrine cervical cancer with adrenal or renal tumors. 

The clinical presentation in MEN 4 is almost similar to MEN1. The difference between MEN1 and MEN4 is in the germline mutation, where MEN 1 occurs due to the mutation of the MEN1 gene.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is a group of autosomal dominant disorders characterized by tumors involving two or more endocrine glands. Depending on the chromosomal location of germline mutation they are divided into four major forms as MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), and MEN 4. MEN 1 is the most common among the four types. 

Other Options:

Option B- MEN 3 is also known as MEN 2B. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid features. In contrast with MEN2A, parathyroid hyperplasia is not seen in MEN 2B.

Option C- MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary carcinoma thyroid, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma.

Option D- MEN 1 is also known as Wermer's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation in the MEN 1 gene. It is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with complaints of difficulty in opening his mouth, restricted tongue movements, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating food. He is a smoker and chews pan masala. On examination, scarring is present in the oral cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is oral submucous fibrosis. It is a premalignant lesion of the oral cavity, in which fibrous bands are formed beneath the oral mucosa.
Risk factors are

  • Betel nut
  • Chilli
  • Tobacco
  • Vitamin deficiency

Clinical features include ankyloglossia, trismus, soreness, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating.

Management includes intralesional steroids, vitamin supplements, and surgical excision.

Option A: Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by post cricoid web that is associated with iron deficiency anemia, glossitis, and koilonychia. It usually presents as dysphagia.

Option B: Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia appears as a white patchy lesion, that cannot be rubbed off.

Option D: Erythroplakia is seen as bright red velvety plaque in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A child presents with the complaint of perianal itching which occurs predominantly at night and disturbs sleep. The eggs of the causative organism have been shown in the following image. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo is suggestive of Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection.

Infection with Enterobius vermicularis presents with perianal or perineal pruritus and restless sleep (due to nocturnal pruritus).

Plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo, are deposited by the gravid female worm on perianal skin which causes pruritis.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens. 

The image given below shows the NIH swab.

Treatment: 

  • Albendazole 400 mg PO with a repeat dose 2 weeks
  • Frequent changing of underclothes, bedclothes, and bedsheets decreases environmental egg contamination and may decrease the risk for autoinfection.
  • Good hand hygiene is the most effective method of prevention.
The image given below shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with a history of asthma, complaints of pain and numbness in both legs. Examination findings include palpable purpura and asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex. Peripheral blood smear findings show eosinophila. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangitis).

It is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and in order to be diagnosed with Churg-Strauss, a patient should have evidence of asthma, peripheral blood and tissue eosinophilia (>1000 cells/μL), extravascular granuloma formation and clinical features consistent with vasculitis. 

Common presenting symptoms of this condition are lower respiratory tract symptoms such as severe attacks of asthma, upper respiratory tract symptoms such as allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, and nasal polyps, mono neuritis multiplex (a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerves) which presents with a complaint of pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas and skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules. P-ANCA antibodies are present in Churg Strauss syndrome. 

Glucocorticoids show effective responses in these patients. Other drugs that have been tried are mepolizumab and rituximab. For fulminant multisystem disease, daily cyclophosphamide with prednisolone followed by azathioprine or methotrexate is used.

Other options:

Option A: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis.

Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but they do not have eosinophilia.

Option D: Giant cell arteritis manifests with the cardinal symptom of headache localized to the temporal region.

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome
