Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: While performing a subtotal thyroidectomy, accidental ligation of which artery can potentially lead to hypoparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Truncal ligation of the inferior thyroid artery can potentially result in hypoparathyroidism. Both superior and inferior parathyroid glands receive their blood from the inferior thyroid artery which arises from the subclavian arteries.Hence during thyroidectomy, only capsular branches closer to the thyroid gland should be ligated.

The inferior parathyroid glands may have a variable blood supply, from either the ascending branch of the inferior thyroid arteries or the thyroid ima artery.

Related Pearl: Blood Supply to the Thyroid Gland

Arterial supply of the thyroid gland

Origin

Superior thyroid artery

Inferior thyroid artery

Arteria thyroidea ima

Brachiocephalic trunk/arch of aorta

Note: Inferior thyroid artery supplies the parathyroid gland

 

Venous drainage of the thyroid gland

Vessel

Origin

Inferior thyroid vein

Tributary of brachiocephalic vein

questions.text: You have been tasked with studying the age and sex structure of a population with high rates of female infanticide. Which of the following methods will you prefer to use?
questions.solution:
The age and sex structure of a population may be best represented using a population pyramid.

It is a histogram that shows the distribution of ages across a population. It is divided down the center between male and female members of the population.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text:
Match the following diseases of the salivary glands with the location of their highest incidence.
Disease Salivary Gland
1. Sialolithiasis a. Minor
2. Benign tumor b. Parotid
3. Malignant tumor c. Submandibular
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-c, 2-b, 3-a

Disease Salivary Gland
1.Sialolithiasis Submandibular
2.Benign tumor Parotid
3.Malignant tumor Minor 
  • Sialolithiasis- Formation of stones in the salivary gland duct. The submandibular gland is most commonly affected (85%) owing to the ascending course of its duct, predisposing it to stagnation of the mucinous as well as the more viscous saliva it produces.
  • Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign salivary gland tumours. They occur most frequently in the parotid glands.
  • Mucoepidermoid carcinomas are the most common salivary gland malignancies. As the salivary gland gets smaller, the proportion of tumours that are malignant increases; 50% of sub-mandibular/sublingual tumours and 80% of minor salivary gland tumours are malignant.

    (The most common site of Mucoepidermoid carcinomas is the parotid gland while the highest incidence of malignant tumours is seen in minor glands)

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus.
  • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus.
  • T11, T12 - supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region.
  • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.

questions.text: A female patient comes with complaints of swelling and pain in her great toe. Her uric acid level is found to be high. A drug which reduces uric acid levels is prescribed. Which of the following enzyme should the drug inhibit?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is a purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme.

Allopurinol is used to treat hyperuricemia in patients with gout. It also prevents the occurrence of gout in those with haematological malignancies about to undergo chemotherapy.

Allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine), reduce urate production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. This prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine, and xanthine to uric acid, thereby reducing plasma uric acid levels. Allopurinol is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase. 

Febuxostat is a nonpurine inhibitor of uric acid synthesis. It is not an analogue of hypoxanthine. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase and it is indicated in gout management. 

Other options:

Option A: Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor (urease generates ammonia from urea that elevates the pH of the urine that can lead to formation of triple phosphate stones).

Option B: Alkaptonuria is a disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate.

Option C: Menkes disease is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme.

Related Pearl: Some Examples of Suicidal Inhibitors

Suicidal Inhibitors

Enzyme

Allopurinol

Xanthine oxidase

Aspirin

Cyclooxygenase

5-Flurouracil

Thymidylate synthase

Penicillin

Transpeptidase

DFMO

Ornithine Decarboxylase

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with gradually progressive muscle weakness and leg spasms for 2 months. He says that he had been consuming an inexpensive dal resembling red gram for the past 2 years. Pure motor paresis was seen on examination. Which of the following could have prevented this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of neurolathyrism. It can be prevented and treated by the administration of vitamin C at doses of 500-1000 mg.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram or Bengal gram.

BOAA (beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water-soluble and can be removed by the following methods:

  • Soaking pulses in hot water and discarding the water 
  • Overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling 
  • Parboiling - for large-scale detoxification

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

Food Adulterant Toxin Disease
Dal Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) BOAA* Lathyrism
Oil Argemone mexicana (oil) Sanguinarine Epidemic dropsy
Millet Crotalaria seeds (Jhunjhunia) Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites 
Bajra, wheat Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Ergotism

 * BOAA-Beta Oxalyl Amino Alanine

questions.text: During a school health survey on malnutrition, the children are arranged according to ascending order of their heights. This arrangement is made to obtain which of the following data?
questions.solution:
The 50th centile can be obtained when values are arranged in order and the central value is picked out. This is the same as the median.

In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.

In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.

An example of how to calculate the median of an odd and an even number of elements is given below.

Option C: Geometric mean is obtained by taking the arithmetic mean of values on a logarithmic scale.

Option D: Mean deviation is a measure of dispersion. The average of deviations from the arithmetic mean gives the mean deviation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition and the given image is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is neuroblastoma.

Most common cause:

Unilateral proptosis Bilateral proptosis
In children: Orbital cellulitis In children: Neuroblastoma and leukemia (chloroma)
In adults: Thyroid ophthalmopathy In adults: Thyroid ophthalmopathy

Exophthalmometry: measures protrusion of the apex of cornea from the outer orbital margin (with the eyes looking straight ahead).

An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labeled as proptosis.

Instruments used to measure proptosis:

  • Luedde exophthalmometer
  • Hertel’s exophthalmometer: Most common instrument used. Its advantage is that it measures both eyes simultaneously.

Image: Bilateral proptosis

questions.text: Electron microscopic picture of which of the following conditions is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given electron microscopy image shows tennis racket-shaped Birbeck granules. These granules are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is BRAF V600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus giving a coffee-bean appearance. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm on electron microscopy. The tumour cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted with complaints of fever with dysuria for 5 days. Her husband reports that she now appears withdrawn and apathetic. She had complained of seeing bugs crawling on her hand. She is drowsy on examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an acute decline in the level of awareness and visual hallucinations (seeing bugs crawling on hand) in an elderly female admitted with fever and dysuria suggests a diagnosis of delirium.

Delirium is characterized by:

  • Acute decline in the level of awareness 
  • Global impairment of cognitive functions (particularly attention)

It also involves:

  • Perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations
  • Abnormal psychomotor activity
  • Sleep cycle impairment.

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a diagnostic algorithm for delirium. The diagnosis of delirium requires the presence of features 1 and 2 and either feature 3 or 4.

  • Feature 1: Acute onset and fluctuating course
    • Positive responses to the following questions satisfy this feature:
      Is there evidence of an acute change in mental status from the patient’s baseline? Does it fluctuate during the day, or does it increase and decrease in severity?
  • Feature 2: Inattention
    • Positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Is there difficulty focusing attention, easily distractibility, or difficulty keeping track of what was being said?
  • Feature 3: Disorganized thinking
    • A positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Was the patient’s thinking disorganized or incoherent. Was there rambling or irrelevant conversation, an unclear or illogical flow of ideas, or unpredictable switching from subject to subject?
  • Feature 4: Altered level of consciousness
    • This feature is satisfied by any answer other than “alert” to the following question: Rate the patient’s level of consciousness: alert (normal), vigilant (hyperalert), lethargic (drowsy, easily aroused), stupor (difficult to arouse), or coma (unarousable)?

The scale may not identify the full spectrum of patients with delirium, but all patients who are acutely confused should be presumed delirious. A course that fluctuates over hours or days and may worsen at night is known as sundowning. It is typically seen in delirium, but is not essential for the diagnosis.

Other screening tools that can aid in identifying patients with delirium are:

  • Nursing Delirium Screening Scale (NuDESC)
  • Organic Brain Syndrome Scale
  • Delirium Rating Scale
  • ICU version of the CAM
  • Delirium Detection Score

Related Pearl: Delirium vs Dementia

Delirium

Dementia

Hallmark is impaired consciousness

Loss of memory and intellectual abilities

More common in children and elderly 

More common in the elderly 

Associated physical findings:

  • Acute medical illness 
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Abnormal EEG 
  • Carphologia or floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes) 

Associated physical findings:

  • No medical illness
  • Little autonomic dysfunction
  • Normal EEG 

Psychological findings:

  • Impaired consciousness
  • Illusion, delusion 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 

Psychological findings:

  • Normal consciousness
  • Depressed mood 
  • Personality changes in early stages in Pick’s disease 

Course:

  • Develops quickly
  • Fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning) 

Course:

  • Insidious-onset
  • Progressive downhill course

Causes:

  • CNS disease (E.g: Huntington or Parkinson disease)
  • CNS trauma
  • CNS infection (E.g: Meningitis)
  • Systemic disease (E.g., hepatic, cardiovascular)
  • Substance abuse/withdrawal
  • HIV infection
  • Prescription drug overdose (E.g: atropine) 

Causes:

  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Vascular disease (15-30% of all dementias)
  • CNS disease (E.g., Huntingtons or Parkinsons disease)
  • CNS infection (HIV, Prion diseases)
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Pick's disease (Frontotemporal dementia) 

Treatment:

Treat the underlying medical cause

Treatment:

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and NMDA antagonist (memantine)

questions.text: Identify the pathology indicated by the image.
questions.solution:
The image depicts candle wax dripping in sarcoidosis.

Ocular inflammation occurs in 25–70% of sarcoid patients, depending on ethnicity.

Granulomatous anterior uveitis is the most common manifestation.

Ocular Features in Sarcoidosis

  • Granulomatous pan uveitis
  • Chronic uveitis
  • "Mutton fat" keratic precipitates (KPs) and/or small granulomatous KPs and/or iris nodules (Koeppe and/or Busacca).
  • Trabecular meshwork (TM) nodules and/or tent-shaped peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS).
  • Snow ball opacities/string of pearl appearance
  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Band-shaped keratopathy
  • Fundus changes
    • Candle-wax dripping: Thick venous sheathing of periphlebitis
    • Pre retinal nodules: Lander’s sign
    • Choroidal granulomata
    • Optic nerve
    • Sarcoid infiltration

questions.text: The gold standard test for the diagnosis of insulinoma is _____.
questions.solution:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour, monitored fasting test.

In this test, the levels of blood glucose, insulin, proinsulin, C peptide are measured in 1 to 2 hours interval. When done so, a patient with insulinoma will have higher values of insulin, proinsulin and C peptide which are expected to decrease in a normal person in response to the hypoglycemia due to fasting.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the outpatient department with oligomenorrhea, acne, and increased facial hair. Which of the following is not an expected finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Streak ovaries/gonads are a characteristic finding in patients with Turner's syndrome. It is not seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS).

Polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS) is an endocrinopathy characterized by anovulation, insulin resistance, clinical signs of androgen excess, and multiple ovarian cysts. Patients with this disorder present with oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, increased facial hair, and acne. Other features that can be seen in this condition are dyslipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, acanthosis nigricans, hair loss, and an increased risk of endometrial cancer. 

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone >2 ng/mL, free T >2.2 pg/mL (Normal level 0.2–0.8 ng/mL)
    • Normal androstenedione level is 1.3–1.5 ng/mL
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes insipidus is prescribed vasopressin. This drug has its maximum effect on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts.

Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 5-monophosphate (cAMP), and protein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Tolcapone acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme and is used in the management of Parkinson's disease.

Parkinsons disease arises as a result of the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the striatum. Therefore the mainstay of treatment in this disease is to increase dopamine in this area.

Important drugs used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease are

1. Levodopa is a prodrug. It crosses the blood-brain barrier. In the brain, levodopa is converted to dopamine by decarboxylation in dopaminergic neurons in the striatum.

Levodopa therapy significantly improves the signs and symptoms of Parkinson's disease. But the major problem with levodopa is the wearing-off phenomenon. Each dose of levodopa improves the symptoms for a period of 1–2 h, but rigidity and akinesia return rapidly after the effect of the drug reduces. Increasing the dose and frequency of administration can improve this situation, but the patients often develop dyskinesias, excessive and abnormal involuntary movements. In the later stages of the disease, patients may fluctuate rapidly between being “off,” having no beneficial effects from their medications, and being “on” having some beneficial effects but along with side effects.

2. Carbidopa- is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor. Levodopa if administered alone will undergo decarboxylation by the decarboxylases present in the intestinal mucosa and other peripheral sites. This will lead to decreased concentration of the drug reaching the brain. In order to prevent this levodopa is always given with carbidopa.

3. Catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitors- The addition of carbidopa to the levodopa prevents the peripheral decarboxylation of the drug. However, levodopa can now be methylated by catechol-O-methyl transferases and inactivate it. This is prevented by COMT inhibitors tolcapone and entacapone. 

4. Selective monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitors- Dopamine in the striatum is predominantly metabolized by the MAO-B enzyme. Inhibiting this enzyme will increase the dopamine concentrations in these neurons. Eg. selegiline and rasagiline.

5. Dopamine receptor agonists- They act at the dopamine receptors and help in the improvement of the symptoms. Rotigotine acts on D1 and D2 receptors, whereas ropinirole and pramipexole both act on the D2 and D3 receptors. Apomorphine acts on D4 and mildly on D2, D3, and D5 receptors. It also has adrenergic action.

6. Muscarinic receptor antagonists- these are used as adjuncts to dopamine therapy. Eg. trihexyphenidyl and benztropine. Diphenhydramine, an antihistamine is also used.

7. Amantadine is an antiviral agent used for the prophylaxis and treatment of influenza A. It has antiparkinsonian activity. It alters dopamine release in the striatum, has anticholinergic properties, and blocks-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. It can be used in mild diseases.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis.

In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. 

Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are:

  • Antibiotic use
  • Advanced age
  • Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers
  • Immunosuppression

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria, and mild hepatomegaly. A biopsy specimen seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of systemic Amyloidosis. The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized light, diagnostic of amyloidosis.

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Kidneys are the most frequently involved with heart being second. Cardiac involvement is the leading cause of death from AL amyloidosis. 

Renal amyloidosis usually manifests as proteinuria, often in the nephrotic range, and is associated with hypoalbuminemia, secondary hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and edema or anasarca. 

The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with (A) focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material, and (B) apple-green birefringence under polarized light, diagnostic of amyloidosis. 

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows blue stained hepatocellular iron.

 

Acid mucin is stained by Alcian blue. 

 

The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

questions.text: A person with myasthenia gravis notes increased muscle strength when he is treated with an acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor.  The basis for his improvement is due to the increase in _______

choices.text: The amount of acetylcholine (ACh) released from motor nerves
The level of ACh at the muscle end plates
The number of ACh receptors on the motor end plates
Synthesis of norepinephrine in motor nerves

questions.solution:
Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g.,neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate.

Myasthenia gravis:

  • It is caused by the presence of antibodies to the ACh receptor.
  • Is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability resulting from a reduced number of ACh receptors on the muscle end plate.
  • The size of the EPP (end plate potential) is reduced.
  • Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate, partially compensating for the reduced number of receptors.

questions.text:
Arrange the following layers of the retina from superficial to deep.
  1. Retinal pigment epithelium
  2. Inner plexiform layer
  3. Nerve fiber layer
  4. Inner nuclear layer
  5. External limiting membrane.
questions.solution:
From the given options, the correct order of layers of the retina from superficial to deep is:

  1. Retinal pigment epithelium
  2. External limiting membrane 
  3. Inner nuclear layer
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Nerve fiber layer

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina (outer to inner)

  • Retinal pigment epithelium
  • Rods and cones
  • External limiting membrane
  • Outer nuclear layer
  • Outer plexiform layer
  • Inner nuclear layer
  • Inner plexiform layer
  • Ganglion cell layer
  • Nerve fibre layer
  • Internal limiting membrane

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.solution:
The true statement is that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source in brachytherapy.

Radiotherapy is a common treatment modality for various cancers, including endometrial carcinoma. It works by targeting rapidly dividing cancer cells with ionizing radiation, which can damage the DNA of these cells and lead to cell death. Radiotherapy can be delivered externally (external beam radiotherapy) or internally (brachytherapy). In brachytherapy, radioactive sources are placed within or adjacent to the tumor, leading to a high radiation dose delivered directly to the tumor while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue.

Stage III and IV of endometrial cancers are not operable. They are treated with brachytherapy followed by external radiation. Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. 

Other options:

Option B: Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature.

Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells.

Option D: Small intestinal epithelial cells (intestinal crypts), which divide rapidly with no differentiation are the most radiosensitive.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with a history of unprotected sex  96 hours ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Since the patient had unprotected sex 96 hours ago, an intrauterine contraceptive device(IUCD) can be used for emergency contraception in this case. It can be inserted within 5 days of coitus as a method of emergency contraception. All other methods of emergency contraception mentioned above need to be administered within 72 hours.

The administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy is known as the emergency contraception method. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.

IUCD (Intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A patient presented with atrophic dry nasal mucosa, extensive crustations, and a woody hard external nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages:

  • Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.
  • Granulomatous stage– Painless, non ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving feel of woody/hebra nose.
  • Cicatricial stage– Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. Deformity is called tapir nose.

Option A: Atrophic rhinitis doesn’t cause woody nose.

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: The most appropriate description of vasomotor reversal of Dale is

choices.text: Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by blockade of beta 2
Stimulation of beta 1 followed by blockade of beta 2

questions.solution:
Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.

Normally, a high dose of epinephrine injected produces α1 mediated rise in BP followed by β2 mediated fall in BP.

Vasomotor reversal of Dale: Administration of epinephrine after administration of α blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β mediated response is seen, i.e., fall in BP.

questions.text: A patient who is undergoing chemotherapy is to be started on allopurinol. Which of these drugs might require dose reduction?
questions.solution:
A patient receiving allopurinol requires a dose reduction of 6-mercaptopurine. 

Allopurinol is a potent xanthine oxidase inhibitor that is often used in acute leukemias as supportive care to prevent the development of hyperuricemia due to tumor lysis syndrome.

6-mercaptopurine is converted to an inactive metabolite (6-thiouric acid) by xanthine oxidase in the liver and intestine. Therefore, the oral bioavailability of the 6-mercaptopurine is reduced significantly due to high first-pass metabolism.

Concomitant allopurinol use increases 6-mercaptopurine availability which leads to toxicity, thereby mandating oral dose reduction.

Note: Intravenous dosing of 6-mercaptopurine need not require any dosing adjustment when administered with allopurinol.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument?
questions.solution:
This is the image of the laryngeal mask airway (LMA).

It aids in intubation in case of difficult airway.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that sits in the hypopharynx and partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions, but not gastric regurgitation.

Position:

  • Distal tip lies against the Upper esophageal sphincter.
  • Proximal tip juxtaposed with base of the tongue.
  • Side cuffs cover pyriform fossa.

Contraindications:

  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Pharyngeal obstruction
  • Restrictive airway disease
  • Hiatal hernia
  • Pregnancy

Option a:

Guedel airway -

It is an oral airway which is used to create and maintain air passage between tongue and posterior pharyngeal wall.

Option c:

Endotracheal tube -

Endotracheal intubation is usually performed emergency procedure to secure airway where endotracheal tube is placed in the trachea by passing it through mouth or nose.

Option d:

Nasogastric tube –

It is passed into the stomach via nose. It has many diagnostic and therapeutic uses like aspiration of stomach contents, evaluation of upper GI bleed, stomach wash in case of poisoning etc.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.
  • Mouth opening < 1.5cm

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 20 cm of H2O.

questions.text: A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus due to calorie malnutrition.

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin,  having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart  or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below). 

The children should be assessed for the following: 

  • Severe edema 
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test) 
  • Medical complications 
  • One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

 

Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet that spread to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the edema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is posted for cataract surgery. The given lens is chosen to be used for implantation. Identify the lens.

choices.text: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
Singh and Worst's iris claw lens

questions.solution:
The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL).

A PCIOL rests entirely behind the iris. They may be supported and fixed by capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method), ciliary sulcus fixation or scleral fixation. 

Parts of the PCIOL

  • The central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic.
  • The peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization are the haptics.

questions.text: Which of the following indices is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to the nitrogen intake?
questions.solution:
Net protein utilization is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to the nitrogen intake.

NPU = (Biological value of a food substance x Digestability coefficient) / 100

Note: The NPU of Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals a child with sparse and kinky hair. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia. These features strongly suggest a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme.

This results from a deficiency of its co-factor i.e copper due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A: Menkes disease - X-linked                 
  • ATP7B: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Other options:

Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase(BCKAD) enzyme defect causes Maple syrup urine disease (Option A)

Valine transaminase enzyme defect causes Hypervalinemia (Option B)

A defect in Cystathionine synthase causes Homocystinuria type I (Option D)

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. She gives a similar history of hearing loss to her mother.  The otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes are given below. The pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curves bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is active otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles. 

Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis Willisii (better hearing in a noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech. The otoscopic picture shows a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, called the Schwartze sign. This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity.

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Eustachian tube function is also normal. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to hasten the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is surgical, that includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

Audiogram given below shows Cahart's notch seen in otosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120-155 dB such as explosions, gunshots etc, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz.

Option C: Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear that arises from the glomus bodies. When the tumor is intratympanic, the hearing loss is a conductive type and a swishing, pulsatile tinnitus that is synchronous with the carotid pulse is heard. On otoscopic examination, a red reflex through the tympanic membrane is seen. This is known as the 'rising sun' appearance.

Option D: Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

Related Pearl: Meniere’s disease vs. Otosclerosis

Meniere’s Disease

Otosclerosis

Middle age (M>F)

Middle age (F>>M)

Unilateral

Bilateral

Sensory neural hearing loss

Conductive Hearing loss

Cochlear pathology (endolymphatic system)

Middle ear pathology (stapes footplate)

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: The COPRA was instated in India, in 1986. This legislation is related to ______
questions.solution:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted to deals with consumer rights.

  • It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are
    • Right to safety
    • Right to be informed
    • Right to be heard
    • Right to choose
    • Right to seek redressal
    • Right to consumer education

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The image is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

  1. Closed method
  2. Open method

The open method is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound. The use of the open technique for creating a pneumoperitoneum avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture.

To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar (shown below) is inserted and anchored, and a pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. 

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

The image below shows a Veress needle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the hospital with complaints of hematuria for the past 1 month. After a detailed evaluation, it was found to be due to the renal cell carcinoma of his right kidney. All of the following paraneoplastic syndromes can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Acanthosis nigricans is not associated with renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

The most common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with RCC is increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

Others:

  • Polycythemia: Occurs as a result of the production of erythropoietin by tumor cells
  • Cushing's syndrome: due to adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) release
  • Hypercalcemia: because of increased vitamin D, parathyroid hormone-related protein

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who presented with secondary dysmenorrhea has been diagnosed with endometriosis. Which of the following drugs is not useful in treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is estrogen-dependent. Hence estrogen is not used in treatment.

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management:

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDS DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G:GnRH analogue
  • O:Oral contraceptive pills
  • L:Letrozole
  • D:Danazol
  • G:Gestrinone
  • A:Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P-Progesterone

Surgical management:

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oopherectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions gives the haematological picture as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given haematological picture showing basophilic stippling with Cabot's ring is suggestive of chronic lead poisoning also called as plumbism or saturnism.

Clinical features of lead poisoning include

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling.
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums).
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain).
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy.
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma).
  • F - Facial pallor -earliest sign.

Other Options:

Option A : Minamata disease is chronic mercury poisoning can show anemia secondary to GI hemorrhage.

Option C : Chronic iron toxicity, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).

Option D : Arsenic poisoning can induce microcytic hypochromic anemia or hemolytic anemia.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits

questions.text: Which of the following is true about global warming?

choices.text: CO2 is the major greenhouse gas
Kyoto Protocol called for 10% reduction in emission of greenhouse gases

questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas.

Greenhouse gases include:

  • Water vapour
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Methane
  • Tropospheric ozone
  • Nitrous oxide
  • Chlorofluorocarbons (non-natural)

Tropospheric ozone and chlorofluorocarbons are also important greenhouse gases. Water vapour is the most abundant greenhouse gas, but the water vapour produced directly by human activity contributes very little to the greenhouse effect. Hence, its emissions have not been estimated.

Greenhouse gases lead to global warming, which is the major cause of climate change. Climate change accelerates species extinction on Earth. 22nd of April is observed as Earth Day.

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

  • Certain gases in the atmosphere absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after it has left the Earth’s surface
  • These gases are known as greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs)
  • These gases then emit longwave radiation in all directions, the downward going portion of which add to the radiation arriving at the Earth’s surface and raise the equilibrium temperature.
  • In this entire process, the Earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as Greenhouse effect.
  • The most important natural GHGs are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, tropospheric ozone and nitrous oxide and non-natural GHGs are chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).
  • Stratospheric ozone is not harmful and doesn’t contribute to the greenhouse effect
  • Greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.
  • The Kyoto Protocol is an internal agreement linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change by which its Parties set internationally binding emission reduction targets. The Parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18 percent in period between 2013 and 2020.
  • The Paris Agreement central aim is to strengthen the global response to the threat of climate change by keeping a global temperature rise this century well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius. It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, apdaptation and finance starting in the year 2020.
  • The Montreal Protocol is related to the depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer, which is protective.

questions.text: Isolation in a separate room is mandatory for which of the following air-borne infections?
questions.solution:
Among the given options isolation in a separate room is mandatory for measles.

Isolation is defined as the separation of an infected person or animal for the period of communicability in places to prevent direct or indirect transmission to susceptible individuals. 

Measles is an infectious disease mainly seen in the childhood age group. It is caused by an RNA paramyxovirus and is transmitted to humans primarily by droplet infection and also through airborne transmission. The period of isolation is from the onset of symptoms (catarrhal stage) to the fourth day of the rash.

Features include

  • The prodromal phase-characterized by fever, cough, conjunctivitis, coryza, 
  • The eruptive phase- macular or maculopapular rash begins behind the ears and spreads to the face, neck, and extremities. Koplik's spots are rashes seen in the buccal mucosa opposite the first and second molar. 

Some of the complications of measles include otitis media, laryngotracheobronchitis (croup), post-infectious measles, or subacute sclerosing pan encephalitis (SSPE). SSPE is a rare but fatal complication. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at supportive care such as relieving the symptoms, treating dehydration, and isolating patients.

The below images show a characteristic rash in measles and Koplik's spots on the buccal mucosa. 

Other options:

Option B: Rabies is transmitted via a bite or scratch from an infected animal. Contraction of rabies by inhalation of virus-containing aerosols is extremely rare. Human-to-human transmission is possible but has not been confirmed.

Option C: Nipah is transmitted mainly from direct contact with sick pigs or their contaminated tissues. To prevent human-to-human transmission, close unprotected contact with infected people is avoided. Regular hand hygiene should be followed when caring for or visiting infected people.

Option D: If the diagnosis is confirmed as aseptic meningitis, the patient can often be discharged home. Isolation is required if the meningitis is of infectious etiology.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Disease

 

Duration of Isolation

Chickenpox

 

Until all lesions are crusted – 6 days usually.

Measles

 

From onset of catarrhal stage to 7 days of rash.

Cholera, diphtheria

 

3 days after tetracycline start until 48 hours.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

 

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

 

3 weeks.

Influenza

 

3 days after onset.

Polio

 

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

 

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Herpes zoster

 

6 days after onset of rash.

Mumps

 

Until swelling subsides.

Pertussis

 

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease.

Meningococcal meningitis

 

Until first 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

Streptococcal pharyngitis

 

Until first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

questions.text:
In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a primigravida goes for institutional delivery after being motivated by an ASHA worker. What are the benefits they will receive (in terms of money in rupees) under the Janani Suraksha Yojana?

ASHA- Accredited social health activist
questions.solution:
According to Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) scheme, the mother will receive 1000 rupees and the ASHA worker will receive 400 rupees.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), whose aim is to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

The Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is the link between pregnant women and health institutions. She is responsible for making institutional antenatal and postnatal care available. 

States are divided into low-performing and high-performing on the basis of institutional delivery rate. (The 10 low-performing states (LPS) with a low institutional delivery rate are Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand, Bihar, Rajasthan, Chattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, and Jammu & Kashmir. All the other states are high-performing states) (HPS).

The incentives under JSY are as follows:

Category  Rural area Urban area
LPS

Mother package: 1400/-
ASHA's package:600/-
Total:2000/-

 Mother package: 1000/-
ASHA's package:400/-
Total:1400/-
HPS Mother package: 700/-
ASHA's package:600/-
Total:1300/-		 Mother package: 600/-
ASHA's package:400/-
Total:1000/-

Under this scheme, the cost of cesarean section and management of obstetric complications is also subsidized, up to Rs 1500 per delivery to the government institutions, where government specialists are not present.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has had perfectly normal cycles every month since her puberty. Which of the following pattern of hormones is expected in the proliferative phase, around the time of ovulation, and luteal phase respectively?

choices.text: High progesterone, high FSH, high estradiol
Increasing estradiol, high FSH, low inhibin A
Increasing FSH, LH surge, low estradiol
Increasing estradiol, high FSH, high inhibin A

questions.solution:
The pattern of hormones that are expected in a normal menstrual cycle is increasing estradiol in the proliferative phase, FSH surge around the time of ovulation, and high inhibin A levels in the luteal phase.

Hormone Proliferative/follicular phase

Around the time of ovulation

 Luteal/secretory phase
Estradiol

The estrogen levels tend to increase progressively in the proliferative phase

 

 36 to 48 hours before the ovulation, it reaches a maximal concentration to cause LH surge

Due to the production from the corpus luteum, the estradiol levels are higher in the initial to mid-luteal phase.

Once the corpus luteum starts involuting, their levels fall.
Progesterone very low low Due to the production from corpus luteum, their levels reach a maximal concentration
FSH Due to the secretion from the anterior pituitary, the FSH levels increase moderately. This causes the growth and development of the follicles The FSH levels also increase at the time of ovulation about twofold to threefold from the baseline Under the strong inhibitory effects of the estrogen secreted from corpus luteum, their levels tend to be lower
LH The levels of LH increase only minimally by secretion from the anterior pituitary Due to the positive feedback by estrogen, the levels of LH surge to the highest possible levels. This is very essential for the ovulation to happen Similar to LH, once its function of luteinizing is complete, their levels start decreasing
Inhibin A Low Increased Inhibin A is also secreted from the corpus luteum and hence increased
Inhibin B

During the earlier days of the follicular phase inhibit B levels are low.

After this, when the follicles mature, the granulosa cells secrete inhibit B, increasing their levels. 

 There is a postovulatory peak  Decreased

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of lethargy, increased thirst, and increased frequency of urination for a few months. On examination, his BMI was 19 kg/m2 and laboratory investigation showed low levels of C-peptide, raised blood glucose, and absent ketone bodies. Anti-GAD antibodies were positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Anti-GAD: Antibodies to glutamic acid decarboxylase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 32-year-old, thin-built male, presenting with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy with laboratory investigation showing low C-peptide, and positive anti-GAD antibodies are suggestive of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). 

LADA is adult-onset diabetes with features of both type1 and type2 diabetes mellitus (DM). They phenotypically appear as type 2 but have autoantibodies like anti-GAD as in favor of type 1.

General characteristics of LADA are:

  • Age of onset more than 30 years
  • Family history of autoimmunity
  • Low or normal body mass index
  • Low C-peptide levels
  • Anti-GAD antibodies positive
  • Do not present with ketoacidosis initially due to the slow progression of beta-cell destruction

The diagnosis can be made based on three criteria as given by The Immunology of Diabetes Society

  • Adult age of onset (>30 years of age),
  • Positive circulating autoantibodies, and
  • No need for insulin treatment initially for several months after diagnosis

Initially, they don't require insulin but are more likely to be in insulin treatment within 5 years of onset. 

Other options:

Option A - Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes patients are usually middle-aged men who are overweight and have a positive family history of diabetes. They have features similar to classic type 2 diabetes but often present with severe hyperglycemia and severe ketosis as in type 1 diabetes. Autoantibodies against beta-cell are negative in these patients. 

Option B: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is an autosomal dominant monogenic form of diabetes that occurs in less than 25 years of age. This is due to beta-cell dysfunction that impairs insulin secretion. The patients are non-ketotic and do not have pancreatic autoantibodies.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus most commonly develops before 20 years of age with most of them having evidence of islet-directed autoimmunity. Most of the patients present with hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. There is increased lipolysis and ketone body production which results in muscle wasting, polyphagia, fatigue, and weakness.

Related Pearl: Comparative Features between MODY and Type 2 DM

 

Type 2 DM

MODY

Predominantly middle to old age

Predominantly young (< 25 years)

Pathology

Beta cell dysfunction

Insulin resistance

Only Beta cell dysfunction

No insulin resistance

Family history

Positive

Inheritance - Polygenic 

Vertical transmission through successive generations is not essential for diagnosis

Positive

Inheritance – Monogenic / Autosomal dominant 

Vertical transmission through at least two successive generation (ideally three) is essential for diagnosis

Insulin dependence

Non-insulin dependent

Obesity

questions.text: A 68-year-old man complains of shortness of breath and coughing at night that awakens him from sleep. He is a known case of COPD. On examination, distended neck veins and S3 sounds were noted. The bronchoalveolar lavage of this patient is given below. Identify the marked cells.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure. The image shows heart failure cells, which are siderophages or hemosiderin-containing macrophages.

They are seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema. The alveolar walls become thickened and fibrosed. These pigmented macrophages result in a brown induration of the lung.

The following image shows siderophages.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic because of walking difficulties. He also has progressive muscle weakness. The examination is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding of enlarged calf muscles and atrophied thigh muscles with a history of muscle weakness are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is an X-linked recessive disorder. In DMD, pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles occurs due to muscle enlargement by the infiltration of fat. It is weak, unlike the muscle that enlarges due to hypertrophy. Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is the characteristic feature of DMD, whereas the other 3 conditions mentioned in the options do not have this feature.

Clinical features:

  1. Progressive weakness with developmental delay
  2. Pseudohypertrophy of calves
  3. Wasting of thigh muscles
  4. Characteristic Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle.
  5. Gower’s sign
  6. Dilated cardiomyopathy

Treatment includes supportive management for cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids. Death usually occurs by 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

Other options:

Option B: Myotonic dystrophy presents with distal muscle weakness, proximal muscle involvement is very late.

Option C: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), type 1 (which is most common) presents in infancy. Death occurs early. 

Option D: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles, due to a decrease in the number of available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junctions as a result of antibody-mediated autoimmune attack.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female cook presents with a 1-year history of dyspnea, episodic cough, wheeze, shortness of breath, and chest tightness.  What is the best way to diagnose bronchial asthma in this patient?
questions.solution:
The best way to diagnose bronchial asthma is by the demonstration of reversible obstruction of the airways.

Wheeze, dyspnoea, and reduced FEV1 values are nonspecific indicators of airway obstruction and are seen in any of the obstructive pathologies (i.e. asthma, COPD, and bronchiectasis). Therefore, they do not independently diagnose asthma.

Whereas, the administration of an inhaled beta 2 agonist can differentiate between Asthma and COPD as follows:

  • ≥12% (≥200ml) increase in the FEV1 demonstrates the reversibility of airway obstruction which is diagnostic of bronchial asthma.
  • <12% or no increase in FEV1 demonstrates the irreversibility component of airway obstruction indicating COPD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the signs and symptoms of the condition represented below?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals enlarged adenoids, indicating a diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Patients present with a flattened or absent nasolabial fold, not a prominent one.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

Treatment of adenoid hypertrophy follows both medical and surgical approaches. Medical management includes antibiotics for acute infections, antiallergic measures, and nasal decongestants. However, adenoidectomy remains the definitive treatment when medical management fails or in cases with persistent symptoms.

The surgical indications include:

  • Chronic nasal obstruction
  • Chronic mouth breathing
  • Recurrent otitis media
  • Sleep apnea
  • Failure to thrive

questions.text: The rounded secretory cells bearing microvilli present in the epithelial lining of the alveoli are _____
questions.solution:
The secretory cells bearing microvilli present in the epithelial lining of the alveoli are the type II pneumocytes.

The cells forming the lining epithelium of alveoli (also called pneumocytes) are mainly of the following types:

  • Type I pneumocytes - large flattened cells which present a very thin diffusion barrier for gases. They are connected to each other by tight junctions.
  • Type II pneumocytes - These are rounded secretory cells bearing microvilli on their free surfaces. These cells secrete the surfactant which decreases the surface tension between the thin alveolar walls, and thus prevents alveoli from collapsing during respiration.
  • Type III alveolar cells (brush cells) - function is not clearly known.

The given image shows a histological section of the lung showing the pneumocytes.

questions.text:
The arterial blood gas of a patient in the emergency department is as follows. What is the likely diagnosis?

pH = 7.12

pCO2 = 50 mm Hg

HCO3 = 28 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Based on the above arterial blood gas values, the likely diagnosis in this patient is respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is reduced (7.12), hence acidosis.

Step 2: Since there is a significant increase in pCO2(50 mmHg), it is respiratory acidosis.

Step 3: There is a mild elevation in HCO3 (28 mEq/L) suggesting that there is metabolic compensation.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A rape victim presents with 25 weeks of pregnancy. What should not be done?

choices.text: Male doctor can examine in the presence of female attendant
Vaginal swab examination is not necessary
No need to confirm pregnancy by UPT
Termination of pregnancy with her consent by a Gynaecologist

questions.solution:
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill 2020, the induction of MTP in a mentally ill or rape victim is allowed until 24 weeks. 

Salient features of amendments:

  • Enhancing the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women which includes survivors of rape, victims of incest and other vulnerable women (like differently-abled women, minors) etc.
  • Opinion of only one provider will be required up to 20 weeks of gestation and of two providers for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks of gestation.
  • Upper gestation limit not to apply in cases of substantial foetal abnormalities.
  • Name and other particulars of a woman whose pregnancy has been terminated shall not be revealed except to a person authorised in any law for the time being in force.
  • The ground of failure of contraceptive has been extended to women and her partner.

Note: The bill has been passed by Rajya Sabha on 17th March 2021.

 

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: Which of the following is a part of AMTSL?
questions.solution:
Controlled cord traction during placental delivery is a component of AMTSL (Active management of third stage of labour).

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate (within 1 minute) administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. Generally, it should be given after delivery of the fetus and before the delivery of the placenta. 
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women(done every 15 minutes for 2 hours)

Uterine massage is not a part of AMTSL. During the uterine tone assessment to ensure a contracted uterus, if there is uterine atony, a fundal massage is performed. 

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of case-control studies?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, follow-up is not a part of case-control studies. 

Case-Control Studies are also called retrospective studies. This study proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred. They focus on diseases or health problems that have already developed. They are less time-consuming and have no risk of attrition because they do not require follow-up.

There are four basic steps in conducting a case-control study:

  • Selection of cases and controls
  • Matching- This is done to ensure comparability between cases and controls. Controls are selected such that they are similar to cases with respect to certain pertinent selected variables that influence the disease outcome.
  • Measurement of exposure - This is obtained by interviews, questionnaires, or study of the past records of cases.
  • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio.

Odds Ratio (OR) calculated from a case-control study, is a measure of the strength of the association between risk factors and outcome.

Note: Follow-up is a part of cohort studies. The elements in cohort studies include selecting study subjects, obtaining data on exposure, selecting comparison groups, follow up and analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Revised Trauma Score ?
questions.solution:
Pulse rate is not a component of Revised Trauma Score.

Glasgow coma scale, Respiratory rate and Systolic BP are components of Revised Trauma Score (0-12).

Various scoring systems are used to score the trauma are :

  • AIS – Abbreviated Injury Scale
  • ISS – Injury Severity Score
  • OIS – Organ Injury Scale
  • GCS – Glasgow Coma Scale
  • RTS – Revised Trauma Score
  • MESS – Mangled Extremity Severity Score
  • TRISS – Trauma and Injury Severity Score

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
1-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: Trigone of bladder develops from:
questions.solution:
Trigone of the bladder develops from the distal part of the mesonephric duct.

Derivatives of the Wolffian or Mesonephric duct:

  • Epoophoron (organ of Rosenmuller)
  • Paroophoron
  • Gartner’s duct

Derivatives of the Mullerian duct or Paramesonephric duct:

  • Fallopian tubes
  • Uterus
  • Upper three-fourths of vagina

Derivatives of the urogenital sinus:

  • Lower vagina
  • Skene’s tubercles
  • Bartholin’s gland
  • Urinary bladder 
  • Urethra

questions.text: Enzyme level tested in thiamine deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase provides an index of vitamin B1 nutritional status. Thiamine pyrophosphate (vit B1) is the cofactor of transketolase.

Transketolase reaction requires two cofactors:

  • Mg2+
  • Thiamine diphosphate (vitamin B1)

Transketolase and transaldolase are involved in the non oxidative phase of HMP pathway.

Other options:

Option A: Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA which enters the citric acid/Kreb’s cycle.

Option B: Pyruvate kinase is involved in substrate-level phosphorylation to form 2× ATP per molecule of glucose oxidized. The reaction of pyruvate kinase is essentially irreversible under physiological conditions. It is involved in regulation of glycolysis

Option D: Transaldolase is involved in the non oxidative phase of HMP pathway.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Assay and test

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Serum methyl malonate level
