questions.text: A neonate presents with feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. Her urine has a peculiar burnt sugar odour due to an excess of branched-chain amino acids. Which of the following amino acid is not restricted in this neonate's diet?
questions.solution:
In maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), only branched-chain amino acids are restricted, hence, methionine does not need any restriction in diet.

Branched-chain amino acids are:

  • Leucine (L)
  • Isoleucine (I)
  • Valine (V)

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a partial or complete deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKD). This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids. These amino acids, particularly leucine and their metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain. Features include feeding problems, vomiting, ketosis, and a characteristic burnt sugar odour/maple syrup-like odour of urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine, and valine.

Treatment involves restricted intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.

questions.text: Which health planning committee proposed the 3 million plan?
questions.solution:
The 3 million plan was proposed by the Bhore Committee.

It proposed to set up the following in the long term:

  • Primary health units with 75-bedded hospitals for each 10,000 to 20,000 population
  • Secondary units with 650 beds
  • District hospitals with 2,500 beds

 As a short-term measure, it was proposed that each PHC must cater to 40,000 people and have:

  • 2 medical officers, 4 public health nurses, 1 nurse
  • 4 midwives, 4 dais, 2 sanitary inspectors, 2 health assistants
  • 1 pharmacist
  • 15 other class IV employees

  • 3 months training in PSM for physicians
  • Preventive and curative services at all administrative levels

  • Also known as Health Survey and Planning Committee

  • 1 PHC for not more than 40,000 people

  • Outlined responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme
  • One basic health worker for 10,000 population

  • Delinked malaria activities from family planning activities.
  • Family planning assistants were for family planning work and basic health workers for other activities.

questions.text: An alcohol addict presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, he is found to have pallor. Peripheral smear showed macrocytes and anisocytosis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia likely due to folate deficiency caused by alcohol addiction. Folate deficiency leads to atrophic glossitis because of damage to the epithelial surfaces.

Option B: Migratory glossitis / geographic tongue is due to rapid loss and regrowth of filiform papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with psoriasis and reactive arthritis.

Option C: Strawberry tongue is due to the hypertrophy of fungiform papillae. It is seen in scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease.

Option D: Macroglossia is an abnormal enlargement of the tongue and can be congenital or acquired. New-onset macroglossia in adults is highly suggestive of amyloidosis.

questions.text: A group discussion was conducted among villagers to assess their knowledge on personal hygiene. Which of the following statements is false regarding this format of health education?

choices.text: Many different topics can be spoken about in one discussion
A group leader guides the conversation
It can bring about change in the attitude of participants
It usually consists of 6 to 12 people

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding group discussion is many different topics can be spoken about in one discussion. A group discussion discusses one topic on its agenda.

Group discussion is an aggregation of people interacting in a face-to-face manner. The exchange of ideas, knowledge, and opinions is done by participants which influences a change in their attitudes.

It usually involves 6–12 people with a group leader who guides the conversation, giving equal opportunity to everyone to voice themselves. In a group discussion, everyone must speak and be open to criticism without interrupting others.

A limitation of this form of health education is that not everyone is open to speaking in public. There is also a high possibility of diversion of the topic of discussion when many people are involved.

Methods of Health Communication

  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1. Lectures
  2. Demonstrations
  3. Discussion methods

    • Panel discussion

    • Conferences
    • Seminars

questions.text: A patient presented with midline swelling in the neck. Biopsy revealing orphan Annie's eye nuclei as shown in the image below is suggestive of ________:
questions.solution:
The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • The carcinoma shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with simple or stratified cuboidal epithelium.
  • At high power, the nuclei appear optically clear or empty as the chromatin is dispersed. These empty appearing nuclei are called Orphan Annie eye nuclei.
  • Concentric calcified structures called psammoma bodies are usually seen.
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion by the tumor are usually present.

Note : 

The presence of Orphan Annie-eye nuclei is diagnostic of papillary thyroid cancer, regardless of the presence of papillary architecture.

The image below shows papillary thyroid carcinoma with characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei:

The image below shows psammoma bodies in papillary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: Lack of sensation, no capillary refill, and leathery texture of skin is characteristic of which type of burn?
questions.solution:
The characteristic features of full-thickness burns (third-degree burns) are lack of sensation in the burned skin, lack of capillary refill, and a leathery texture that is unlike normal skin.

Deep dermal and full-thickness burns require excision with skin grafting for the patient to heal the wounds properly.

Colour Red Red, maybe blistered White, with erythematous areas White or mottled brown White, mottle brown or red.
Skin texture Normal Oedematous, dry to small blisters Dry, waxy, less elastic  Dry, leather like Dry, charred
Caplillary refill Yes Yes No  No No

Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or amputation, if necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a physiological uncoupler?
questions.solution:
Thermogenin is a physiological uncoupler.

Uncouplers act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions. They collapse the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across the membrane without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex.

  •  Synthetic: 2, 4 dinitrophenol
  •  Natural:Thyroxine and thermogenin. Thermogenin is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation, especially in a newborn

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of recurrent pain and discharge due to lesions around the anus, shown in the image is likely to be a fistula-in-ano.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal connection between the anal canal and the perianal skin, lined with granulation tissue. It may follow the drainage of a perianal abscess or may be seen in association with diseases like tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Clinical features are perianal pain, swelling, and intermittent purulent discharge, which might be blood-stained. On examination, one or more external openings may be visible.

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula. Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract. Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

 

 

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano can include a fistulogram, endoanal ultrasound with hydrogen peroxide, MRI, and computed tomography (CT) scan. An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. 

Surgical management includes fistulotomy, fistulectomy, ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT), setons, or advancement flaps.

Other options:

Option A: Pilonidal sinus is a chronic skin condition in the sacrococcygeal region caused by hair penetration leading to infection and abscess formation. It commonly affects young adults and may require surgical drainage or excision for treatment.

Option B: A carbuncle is a deep, painful skin infection involving a cluster of interconnected boils (furuncles), usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It commonly occurs on the back, neck, or thighs and may require drainage and antibiotics for treatment.

Option C: A boil, or furuncle, is a painful, pus-filled infection of a hair follicle caused by bacteria, usually Staphylococcus aureus. It typically presents as a red, swollen lump and may require drainage if severe.

questions.text: A 52-year-old hypertensive male came with a complaint of lower back pain. His BP and creatinine levels were normal in previous visits. Now they are 154/90 mmHg and  2.5 mg/dL respectively. He started taking NSAIDs for a few months and also started exercising to alleviate knee pain. What is the reason for an increase in his creatinine levels?

choices.text: Increased muscle mass due to exercise

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the use of NSAIDs caused increased afferent arteriolar resistance.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) inhibit the synthesis of prostaglandins leading to constriction of afferent arterioles. As a result, the afferent arteriolar resistance is increased leading to reduced GFR. The decrease in GFR, in turn, leads to an increase in serum creatinine.

Other options:

  • Increased efferent arteriole resistance and increased glomerular capillary filtration coefficient both causes an increase in GFR.
  • Increasing muscle mass due to exercise does not have any significant effect on serum creatinine.

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of using contact lenses over spectacles?
questions.solution:
Prismatic effects will be less in contact lenses as compared to spectacles.

In spectacles, the edge of the lens acts as a prism leading to prismatic effects. Due to the prismatic effect produced by the spectacles used in aphakia, patients can experience visual problems like roving-ring scotoma and jack-in-the-box phenomenon.

Contact lenses are artificial devices that act as a substitute for the anterior surface of the cornea. Contact lenses have multiple therapeutic uses. They include providing pain relief in bullous keratopathy by using soft bandage lenses as it protects the exposed corneal nerve endings from the eyelid's shearing forces during blinking.

Constant use can cause complications such as giant papillary conjunctivitis, superficial punctate keratitis, tight lens syndrome, and acute/chronic hypoxia.

Patients with regular use of contact lenses are at higher risk of infection leading to acanthamoeba keratitis. This occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lenses with tap water

Inflammation can be a complication in contact lens users. A giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis, most commonly associated with contact lens wear. 

Contact lenses decrease corneal oxygen supply. The cornea obtains its O2 supply from the atmosphere. The use of contact lenses decreases the O2 supply from the atmosphere. Although dry eye is caused by wearing contact lenses, lenses made of hydrogel, which are high in water content are beneficial in dry eye.

Difficulties in the correction of aphakia by spectacles include the following:

  • Image magnification by 25–30%
  • Spherical aberrations producing a “pin cushion effect”
  • Roving-ring scotoma is seen in the correction of aphakia with spectacles due to prismatic effects at the edge of the lens.
  • Jack-in-the-box phenomenon from the prismatic effects at the edge of the lens
  • Reduced visual fields
  • Physical inconvenience

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA(polymethylmethacrylate). 
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA - hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of sarcoidosis presents with skin lesions shown in the image below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given condition is lupus pernio.

Lupus pernio is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis. It involves the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eye, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

There are two syndromes that are associated with the condition.

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome is bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The most common presenting features are cough, dyspnea, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.  The eyes can be involved in the form of anterior uveitis, photophobia, dry eyes, and blurred vision. Neurological involvement in the form of myelopathy, basilar meningitis, and facial nerve paralysis. Skin involvement can be seen as maculopapular lesions, keloid formation, ad subcutaneous nodules. Lupus pernio refers to the skin involvement of the bridge of the nose, periocular region, and cheeks and points to a chronic state.

Histopathological examination reveals non-necrotizing granulomas made of macrophages and giant cells. Calcium and protein concretions known as Schaumann bodies and stellate inclusions called asteroid bodies may be seen within the giant cells. 

Chest X-ray is preferred to stage lung involvement. CT features include peribronchial thickening and reticular nodular changes.

Glucocorticoids are the drug of choice for management.

Other options:

Option A- Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis.

Option C- Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

Option D- Erysipelas presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges. It is caused due to streptococcal skin infection.

questions.text: Which of the following changes does not occur in the renal system during normal pregnancy?

choices.text: Increase in GFR, renal plasma flow
Increase in amino acids and water-soluble vitamin excretion

questions.solution:
The change that does not occur during normal pregnancy is an increase in serum creatinine levels. Serum creatinine levels decrease during normal pregnancy from a mean of 0.7 mg/dL to 0.5 mg/dL.

Creatinine clearance

Anatomical changes:

  • Both kidneys enlarge by 1.5 cm.
  • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis (more common on right side) due to dextrorotation of the uterus and relaxant effect of progesterone 
  • Congestion of bladder causing decreased bladder capacity
  • Increased bladder pressure and intraurethral pressure.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic man comes to  OPD for a follow-up visit. His serum LDL level is high. He is started on a lipid-lowering drug that acts on the rate-limiting step of cholesterol synthesis. Which of the following is the site of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis.

HMG-CoA reductase is inhibited by the statin group of drugs (e.g. Atorvastatin, Rosuvastatin, Pravastatin, etc.) which are widely used as lipid-lowering agents.

Regulation of HMG CoA reductase:

Activity increased by Activity decreased by
Insulin Glucagon, glucocorticoids
Thyroid hormone Cholesterol, mevalonate
  Dietary cholesterol
  Statins

Glucagon and glucocorticoids repress the transcription of HMG CoA reductase via sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP).

questions.text: The forced expiratory volume in the 1st second (FEV1) curves shown in the figure below were obtained from a healthy man (purple curve) and a 57-year-old man with shortness of breath (green curve). What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The green curve in the above image and the case scenario denotes that the diagnosis is likely to be emphysema.

FVC (Forced vital capacity) is the maximum volume of air that can be expired forcefully after maximal inspiration. It is decreased in both restrictive and obstructive diseases

FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) is the fraction of forced vital capacity expired during the first second of forced expiration.

Pulmonary function tests can be used to differentiate between restrictive and obstructive diseases.

  • In obstructive lung diseases, the obstruction in the airways reduces both FEV1 and FVC. However, the decrease in FEV1 is greater than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio FEV1/FVC also decreases. The total lung capacity is normal or elevated.
    Ex: Asthma, COPD, Bronchiectasis.
  • In restrictive diseases, the FVC is reduced. However, the patient's airflow is fast initially, which soon levels out with the FVC. As a result, the FEV1/FVC is normal or increased. The total lung capacity is reduced.
    Ex: Pulmonary fibrosis (Tuberculosis), pneumoconiosis, sarcoidosis, kyphosis.

The following graph shows the FVC of restrictive and obstructive lung diseases.

questions.text: A microbiologist performs the following test and observes swelling of the capsule. In which of the following organisms will this phenomenon not be observed in?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Quellung reaction and is seen in capsulated bacteria. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not capsulated, therefore Quellung reaction will not be observed in it. 

In Quellung reaction, a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope, the capsule becomes very prominent and appears swollen.

Capsules- Cryptococcus neoformans

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes for an evaluation of blood pressure. He had a history of occasional flank pain. His BP was found to be 160/90 mm Hg. Further evaluation with CT was done and the finding is shown below. What could be the possible diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The CT shows the presence of multiple cysts in the kidney. This CT finding along with the clinical features of the patient is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

ADPDK is characterized by the progressive formation of epithelial-lined cysts in the bilateral kidneys that ultimately leads to the loss of normal functioning renal tissue. Many patients do not have any symptoms until they are 40-50 years of age. The clinical manifestations include flank pain, hematuria (from cyst rupture), and hypertension due to increased Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS) activation.

Extrarenal manifestations of the disease include benign hepatic cysts, intracranial aneurysms, mitral valve prolapse, and colonic diverticula.

Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due to multiple cysts. The nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD. 

Other options:

Option A and C: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) and acute pyelonephritis, show striated nephrogram on CT nephrography (as shown below).

Option D: Renal angiomyolipoma show well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue on CT imaging.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure
  • The commonest cause of abdominal mass in children

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to the clinical finding being tested in the image below?
questions.solution:
By asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed (Schamroth sign), the finding being elicited is clubbing. Clubbing is seen in conditions like lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, and aortic aneurysm, but not in irritable bowel syndrome.

Digital clubbing is a focal bulbous enlargement of the terminal segments of the fingers and/or toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue between the nail matrix and the distal phalanx. Clubbed fingers are also known as watch-glass nails, drumstick fingers, and Hippocratic fingers/nails.

Hypoxia causes increased release of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This leads to increased vascularity, permeability, and connective tissue changes.

The image below shows clubbing.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: It is performed by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, but this window is obliterated in clubbed fingers. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: It is the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, this angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.
  • Hyponychial angle: This is constructed by drawing a line from the distal digital crease to the cuticle and another line from the cuticle to the hyponychium (the thickened stratum corneum of the epidermis under the free edge of the nail). The normal angle is less than 192°.
  • Phalangeal depth ratio: This is defined by the ratio of the digit's depth measured at the nail bed and distal interphalangeal joint. Normally, the depth at the distal interphalangeal joint is more than that at the nail bed. A phalangeal depth ratio of more than 1 is indicative of clubbing.
  • Digital index: This is the sum of the phalangeal depth ratios for all 10 fingers. A digital index of 10.2 or more is indicative of clubbing. This is more specific for clubbing than pharyngeal depth ratio.

The causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

questions.text: Nystagmus to the side of the lesion occurs in
questions.solution:
Serous labyrinthitis results in nystagmus to the side of the lesion.

Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component. By convention, the latter denotes the direction of nystagmus. Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, trauma to the labyrinth, and sectioning of the 8th nerve cause nystagmus to the healthy side. Serous labyrinthitis, which is an irritative lesion, leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

Nystagmus is a rhythmical, involuntary, and oscillatory movement of the eyes. It can be horizontal, vertical, or rotatory. It can be of two types:

  • Vestibular (peripheral) nystagmus due to a lesion of the labyrinth or eighth cranial nerve.
  • Central nystagmus is due to a lesion in the vestibular nuclei, brainstem, or cerebellum.

The following features can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus. 

Nystagmus Peripheral lesion Central lesion
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration Less than one minute More than one minute
Direction Fixed Changes
Fatiguability Fatiguable Nonfatiguable
Associated symptoms Severe vertigo None or slight

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, supported with the image, is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis:

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring

Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment:

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

World Glaucoma Week is celebrated annually on March 7-13 to raise awareness among people on Glaucoma. The 2021 theme reflects the hope that with regular testing, people continue to see the world around us: full of beauty, charm, and adventure. The world is bright, save your sight!

questions.text: A young patient with Hepatitis E virus infection develops acute liver failure. Which of the following scores can be used in assessing the prognosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with acute liver failure, MELD score and King's College Hospital criteria can be used to assess the prognosis.

MELD (Model for End-stage Liver Disease) score is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation. However, there are certain diseases that impair patient survival and are not accounted for in the MELD score. Patients with these diseases are given upgraded MELD points to accurately represent the mortality risk and these conditions are called MELD exceptions. 

The MELD exceptions include:-

  • Portopulmonary hypertension
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Familial amyloid polyneuropathy
  • Primary hyperoxaluria (necessitating liver-kidney transplantation)
  • Cystic fibrosis with liver disease
  • Highly selected cases of hilar cholangiocarcinoma.
  • Hepatopulmonary syndrome
  • Hepatic artery thrombosis 7–14 days post-liver transplantation.

Option A: Pitt score is used used to predict mortality in patients having bloodstream infections.

Option B: The child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity of cirrhosis. 

Option D: Maddrey's Discriminant Function (MDF) score suggests which patients with alcoholic hepatitis may have a poor prognosis and benefit from steroid administration.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: The family pedigree chart of a child with inherited anaemia is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The pedigree chart given is suggestive of an autosomal dominant inheritance which is seen in hereditary spherocytosis.

Such an inheritance has a vertical pattern in pedigree charts where individuals of each generation are affected (parents and children). Males and females are equally affected and each affected individual has a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to their offspring.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

According to the above flowchart:

Step 1: All affected individuals have an affected parent. Since multiple generations are affected it is a dominant inheritance pattern.

Step 2: Male-to-male transmission is present. The disorder thus has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

Thalassemia is autosomal recessive, which means both parents must be affected with or carriers for the disease to transfer it to the next generation. It is caused by mutations or deletions of the Hb genes, resulting in underproduction or absence of alpha or beta chains

Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner and symptoms are more common in males.

Sickle cell anaemia occurs due to a mutation when negatively charged glutamine is replaced by a neutral valine at the sixth position of the beta-globin chain. The mutation is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and the site at which it is used to take samples.

choices.text: Ayre's spatula used at the squamocolumnar junction
Ayre's spatula used at the endocervix
Cytobrush used at the squamocolumnar junction

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take samples from the endocervix for Pap smear.

Ayre’s spatula is used to take samples from the squamocolumnar junction. Given below is the image of Ayre's spatula.

Pap/ Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. A positive test requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation, but can be done at any other time as well. 24 hours prior to the test, patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications.

Procedure:

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol and stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the blood-brain barrier?

choices.text: End feet of astrocytes covering the capillary walls

questions.solution:
Capillaries with fenestrations are not part of the blood-brain barrier. 

Blood-brain barrier is constituted by:

  • Capillary endothelium with tight junctions (no fenestrations).
  • Basement membrane of the endothelium.
  • End feet of astrocytes covering the capillary walls.

The barrier permits a selective passage of blood constituents to the nervous tissue.

questions.text: A 40-year-old hairdresser presented with complaints of swelling, throbbing pain, and heaviness in her left leg for the past 1 year. A duplex scan done showed great saphenous vein incompetence. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of varicose veins and the treatment of choice in this patient is endothermal ablation. Endothermal ablation technologies replaced surgical ligation and stripping as the gold-standard treatment.

Management of varicose veins

1. Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral incompetence (SFJ) 

  • Endothermal ablation - It is the gold standard method. It includes:
    • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
    • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA).
  • Trendelenburg procedure ± stripping  - Flush ligation of SFJ and ligation of 6 tributaries.

2. Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal incompetence (SPJ). 

  • Flush ligation of SPJ. No stripping is done to prevent nerve injury
  • EVLA or RFA.

3. Perforator incompetence

  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfacial ligations.
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS)
  • EVLA or RFA

New treatment modalities

  • Foam sclerotherapy 
  • Endovenous glue therapy
  • TriVex - Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

questions.text: A 42-year-old male was diagnosed with a tumor in the right submandibular gland and was posted for surgical removal of the gland and its duct.  During the procedure, which of the following nerves is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Lingual nerve loops around the submandibular duct, and hence is susceptible to injury during the procedures involving the excision of the submandibular gland or its duct.

Damage to the lingual nerve causes loss of sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.

Superficial to the hyoglossus muscle, the submandibular duct lies between lingual and hypoglossal nerves. As it reaches the anterior border of the hyoglossus, it is crossed by the lingual nerve.

The submandibular gland is divided into a larger superficial and smaller deep part by the mylohyoid muscle. They are continuous with each other around the posterior border of mylohyoid.

Important structures related to superficial part are:

  • Facial artery
  • Facial vein
  • Cervical branch of the facial nerve
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve
  • Submandibular ganglion
  • Lingual nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Deep lingual vein

Important structures related to the deep part are:

  • Sublingual gland
  • Lingual nerve 
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Deep lingual vein

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following skin lesions. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques in an HIV-positive patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8. It also causes primary effusion lymphoma. 

HHV-8 or Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is known to cause Kaposi’s sarcoma, especially in immunocompromised persons. Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, AIDS patients, and organ transplant recipients are all at a high risk of showing signs of infection.

It is one of the currently known human cancer viruses or oncoviruses.

KSHV is a known causative agent of four diseases:

  1. Kaposi's sarcoma
  2. KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD)
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma

questions.text:
Choose the option with correct matches:
Term Description
1. Puppe's Rule a. Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact

2. Kennedy Phenomena

 b. Planting a bullet inside a stab wound
3. Rayalseema Phenomenon c. Relationship between trauma and new growth
4. Ewing's Postulates d. Chronological sequence of bullets fired
questions.solution:
The correct match would be as follows:

Term Description
1. Puppe's Rule a.Chronological sequence of bullets fired

2. Kennedy Phenomena

 b. Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact
3. Rayalseema Phenomenon c.Planting a bullet inside a stab wound 
4. Ewing's Postulates d. Relationship between trauma and new growth

Puppe's rule: Helps in determining the sequence of bullets to hit the skull, when there are multiple bullet injuries to skull. The fracture line resulting from the later bullet will typically stop at the previously formed one.

Kennedy's phenomenon: Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefac. The evaluation of wound as entry or exit wound becomes difficult.

Rayalaseema phenomenon: Here a person is killed by stab injury, and a bullet is implanted inside to mislead the investigation.

Ewing's postulates: Establishes a relationship between trauma and new growth.

The following postulates should be satisfied before a relationship between trauma and new growth is accepted:

  • Evidence of previous integrity of the injured part.
  • Undeniable and adequate trauma must be proved.
  • There must be a proof of reasonable time interval between injury and appearance of tumour.
  • Disease must develop at the exact site of injury.
  • The nature of the tumour must be proved.

questions.text: Peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in which type of shock?
questions.solution:
Distributive shock is a condition of reduced oxygen delivery due to low peripheral vascular resistance (PVR). It is the only shock with a compensatory increase in cardiac output. All other types of shock have low cardiac output.

     Hypovolemic    Cardiogenic    Obstructive  Distributive
Cardiac output Low Low Low       High
Vascular resistance High High  High  Low
Venous pressure Low High  High   Low
Mixed venous saturation Low Low Low High 
Base deficit High  High  High  High 

The most common cause of distributive shock is sepsis. The mechanism of vasodilatation in various types of distributive shock:

Type of distributive shock  Cause of vasodilatation 
Septic shock  Bacterial endotoxin and immune activation
Anaphylactic shock  Histamine release 
Neurogenic shock (spinal cord injury)  Failure of sympathetic outflow

questions.text: A  26-year-old male patient presents with painful ulcers on his penis with the classical "kissing ulcer" appearance. He also has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.  If the ulcer is swabbed, which of the following will be found on microscopy?
questions.solution:
This patient with tender genital ulcers with the "kissing ulcer" appearance and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy most likely has a diagnosis of chancroid. 

If the ulcer is swabbed, the classical "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance will be seen on microscopy, as shown below:

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STD) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a Gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers".

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by the gram stain findings. Treatment is recommended with a single dose of azithromycin (1g oral) or ceftriaxone (250mg intramuscular).

Chancroid has gained clinical significance because it can increase the risk of HIV transmission. Hence, it is important to identify and treat these patients and to inform their sexual partners.

 Spirochetes are seen on dark field microscopy in syphilitic ulcers. They are caused by Treponema pallidum and present with a single, painless genital ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis can be confirmed by specific treponemal tests such as fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS), Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test (TPHA) and the enzyme immunoassay (EIA)Treatment is with parental Penicillin G, irrespective of the stage of the disease. Dose and duration depend on the clinical stage and presentation. 

Darkfield microscopy with spirochetes are shown below:

Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis. It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes". The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining which shows the Donovan bodies which show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance"). Management is with a course of azithromycin.

 The slide below shows Donovan bodies with the safety-pin appearance:

Multinucleated giant cells are seen on Tzanck smear in herpes genitalis. These ulcers are caused by herpes simplex type 2 virus and present as a cluster of vesicles on an erythematous base with painful inguinal lymph nodes. The diagnosis can be made with an initial Tzanck smear by deroofing the vesicles and taking a swab. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing can be used to confirm this diagnosis. The first-line drug used to treat herpes genitalis is oral aciclovir.

Tzanck smear with the above-mentioned findings can be seen below:

questions.text: Which does 'I' stand for in the PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.solution:
The 'I' in the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) stands for iatrogenic causes.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 3-6 months minimum.

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: What is the amount of land required to practice the trench method of sanitary landfill for a population of 10,000?
questions.solution:
The amount of land required to practice the trench method of sanitary landfill for a population of 10,000 is one acre.

It is estimated that one acre of land per year will be required for 10,000 population if compacted refuse is placed in the fill to a standard depth of 2 meters.

Controlled tipping or sanitary landfill is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. The material is placed in a trench or other prepared area, adequately compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the working day. There are three methods under controlled tipping: 

  • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
  • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping
  • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries, and clay pits.

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with yellowish discoloration of sclera. His liver function tests reveal conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver enzyme levels. Liver biopsy revealed an accumulation of dark melanin like pigment in the hepatocytes. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with dark pigment deposition (image below) in the liver. These features are suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome.

In Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) there is defective excretion of conjugated bilirubin and various compounds like epinephrine metabolites causing the liver to appear black.

Rotor syndrome also has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but there is no pigmentation of the liver. Serum bilirubin levels are not helpful in differentiating between Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) and Rotor's syndrome as both these conditions present with mild elevation of serum bilirubin.

These two conditions can be differentiated as follows:

Test Rotor Syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Oral cholecystography Gall bladder is visualized

Gall bladder not visualised 

Impaired ability to concentrate the contrast material into bile
Total urinary coproporphyrin Elevated

Normal 

Increased excretion of coproporphyrin 1 and decreased excretion of coproporphyrin 3
Bromsulphalein (BSP) clearance test

Delayed clearance of BSP

No reflux

Rise in plasma levels of BSP after 90 minutes of injection

Reflux of BSP from hepatocytes 

Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndromes are characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Related Pearl: Rotor syndrome vs Dubin johnson syndrome

  Rotor syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Inheritance Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
Defect Organic anion transporting polypeptide  defect.(OATP1B1,OATP1B3) Multi drug resistance protein (MRP )2 mutation
Biopsy Normal Black pigmentation
Conjugated bilirubin Elevated Elevated
Kernicterus absent absent

questions.text: Roof of the anatomical snuff box is related to _______
questions.solution:
The superficial branch of the radial nerve forms the roof of the anatomical snuffbox.

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or "snuff."

Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: 

Lateral wall:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL),
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  

Medial wall:

  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL).

Roof:

  • Cephalic vein
  • Superficial Branch of radial nerve

Floor:

  • Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium and 1st Metacarpal. 

Only content: Radial artery

questions.text: Which of the following nitrogenous bases are seen in a human DNA?
questions.solution:
The nitrogenous bases present in human DNA are adenine, guanine, cytosine and thiamine.

Structure of DNA:

Watson & Crick model:

  • Right-handed double helical structure (sugar and phosphate on the outside and base pairs on the inside).
  • Antiparallel arrangement (5' -> 3' & 3' -> 5' directions).

Watson Crick base pairing rule:

  • Bases interact by forming a hydrogen bond
  • Adenine - Thymine
  • Guanine - Cytosine

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA regardless of species:

  • Adenine= Thymine, Guanine = Cytosine
  • Sum of purine = Sum of pyrimidines i.e A+G=C+T.

Base stacking: Vertical interaction between the base pairs by non-covalent forces like hydrophobic interactions and Vanderwaal's forces. Other options: The nitrogenous bases present in human RNA are adenine, guanine, cytosine and uracil.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient underwent bypass surgery for obesity. She has noticed sweating, palpitations, colicky pain, and loose stools on consuming food. These episodes start immediately post meals and last for 1 hour. They are relieved by lying down. What is the mainstay of treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment for this condition is small, frequent low carbohydrate meals.

A 50-year-old female with symptoms of sweating, palpitations, colicky pain, and loose stools on consuming food after undergoing gastric bypass surgery for obesity is highly suggestive of dumping syndrome. Dietary manipulation with small, frequent low carbohydrate meals is the mainstay treatment.

Dumping syndrome can be early or late.

  • Early dumping syndrome is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). This shift induces autonomic responses. It is characterized by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects. It appears to be secondary to the release of several humoral agents, such as serotonin, bradykinin-like substances, neurotensin, and entero- glucagon.
  • Late dumping syndrome is due to the high carbohydrate load in the small intestine, which causes an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia. This hypoglycemia activates the adrenal gland to release catecholamines, which results in diaphoresis, tremulousness, light-headedness, tachycardia, and confusion.

Dietary manipulation is the mainstay of treatment of early dumping syndrome. The patient is asked to consume small, dry, more frequent food with avoidance of carbohydrates.

Other options:

Option A: Octreotide, a somatostatin analogue is used in intractable syndromes and is administered subcutaneously before meals. It not only inhibits gastric emptying but also affects small bowel motility. Hence, the intestinal transit of the ingested meal is prolonged.

Option B: Oral rehydration solution (ORS) is used for the supportive treatment of diarrhoea.

Option D: Surgical treatment is considered when all other methods fail; available options include pyloric reconstruction or conversion to a Roux-en-y gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: You are a radiation oncology resident explaining the harmful effects of radiation to a patient. Which of the following is not a deterministic effect of the same?
questions.solution:
Mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: stochastic effects and nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

 

Stochastic effects

 Deterministic effects
Description These are chance effects. The probability of occurrence increases with increasing absorbed dose but severity does not depend on the amount of absorbed dose. This is called 'All or none' phenomenon. Increases in severity with increasing absorbed dose in affected individuals.
Threshold level It cannot be set. It can be set.
Examples  Genetic effect, development of cancer Organ atrophy, fibrosis, lens opacification, blood changes, decrease in sperm count, irreversible skin damage,fetal abnormalities

A pregnant lady comes to your clinic with various ultrasound reports. The gestational age assessed using various parameters at different times is as follows.

questions.text: A patient developed a lesion as shown below a few months after undergoing heart surgery. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is a keloid scar.

Keloid is a consequence of abnormal wound healing. It is suspected that overacted fibroblasts are responsible for patients developing this condition. Keloids present as firm, rubbery nodules in areas of prior skin injury.

Keloids almost always extend beyond the initial site of an injury, in contrast to hypertrophic scar.

There is a high chance of recurrence post-surgical excision, hence this must always be paired with other modalities such as intralesional steroid injections.

Other options:

Hypertrophic scars are raised, red scars that remain within the boundaries of the original wound. They are characterized by excessive collagen formation during the healing process. Unlike keloid scars, hypertrophic scars do not extend beyond the original wound site. They may regress over time and are less likely to recur after surgical excision.

Atrophic scars are characterized by a depression in the skin's surface, often resulting from a loss of underlying tissue. They can occur due to conditions like acne or trauma. They are the opposite of hypertrophic and keloid scars, as they result in a loss of tissue rather than excessive collagen formation.

Contractures are scars that cause the skin to tighten and pull, leading to reduced mobility of nearby structures. They can occur after burns or extensive tissue damage. Contractures are characterized by tightening and pulling of the skin, leading to functional limitations.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the following image.
questions.solution: The given image depicts Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor used in mastoidectomy.

questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:

choices.text: A -i B-ii C- iii  D- iv

questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A researcher is studying the phases of the ventricular muscle action potential as shown below. Which phase represents the closing of fast sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Phase 1 represents the closure of fast sodium channels.

Phases of cardiac muscle action potential.

  • Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels(voltage-gated sodium channels) open and causes sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. 
  • Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel close and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. 
  • Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in potassium efflux via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 
  • Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. 
  • Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: A young patient was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following is not a 'B symptom' expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pruritus is not a b symptom of Hodgkin's lymphoma. The b symptoms of Hodgkin's lymphoma are persistent fever (>100.4ºF), drenching night sweats, and unexplained weight loss of >10% body weight over the past 6 months.

Hodgkin's lymphoma is a lymphoid neoplasm characterized by the histological presence of Reed Sternberg cells on a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells.

The patient commonly presents with palpable, firm, rubbery, non-tender lymphadenopathy in the cervical or supraclavicular region. Systemic symptoms that are classified as B symptoms are important in the staging of the disease. Hepatosplenomegaly is rarely detected clinically. 

Ann Arbor Staging of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma:

Stage I

Involvement of a single lymph node (I) or of a single extra-lymphatic organ or site (IE)

Stage II

Involvement of 2 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (II) or localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site and 1 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (IIE)

Stage III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm (III), which may be accompanied by

involvement of the spleen (IIIS) or

by localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site (IIIE) or

both (IIISE)

Stage IV

Diffuse or disseminated involvement of 1 or more

extra-lymphatic organs or tissues with or without

associated lymph node involvement
 

B symptoms

  • The presence of fever >38°C (100.4°F) for 3 consecutive days
  • Drenching night sweats
  • Unexplained loss of >10% of body weight in the 6 months

questions.text: A patient presented with an unknown fungal infection. Histological examination of the lesion shows the presence of round, irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histological examination of the lesion showing round, irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae is suggestive of sclerotic bodies. So the possible diagnosis is chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It is more commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefoot. Traumatic implantation is the mode of infection.

Patients present with warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. The disease generally remains localized with slow peripheral extension. Lymphatic spread can occur.

Diagnosis can be established by demonstration of these sclerotic bodies or medlar bodies and by culture on Sabouraud agar. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount.

The image below shows sclerotic bodies seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is not associated with the infant born to a mother with gestational diabetes?
questions.solution:
The complication not associated with the infant born to a mother with gestational diabetes is microsomia.

Infants born to diabetic mothers may present with:

  1. Macrosomia (large for gestational age)
  2. Hypoglycemia
  3. Respiratory distress syndrome
  4. Neural tube defects
  5. Hypocalcemia
  6. Cardiomegaly
  7. Heart failure
  8. Cardiac malformations
    1. Ventricular or atrial septal defect
    2. Transposition of the great vessels (most specific)
    3. Truncus arteriosus
    4. Double-outlet right ventricle
    5. Tricuspid atresia
    6. Coarctation of the aorta
    7. Lumbosacral agenesis

Additional anomalies include hydronephrosis, renal agenesis and dysplasia, duodenal or anorectal atresia, situs inversus, double ureter, and holoprosencephaly.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought for complaints of short stature. His bone age is greater than his chronological age. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with bone age greater than his chronological age is likely to have precocious puberty.

Precocious puberty is an early onset of puberty and secondary sexual characteristics in children. It can lead to an early height spurt followed by premature epiphyseal fusion and ultimate short stature.

The relationship between bone age and chronological age is summarised below

  • Bone age = chronological age in familial short stature
  • Bone age > chronological age in precocious puberty
  • Bone age < chronological age in other causes like constitutional delay, undernutrition, genetic diseases, and endocrine causes. 

Other options:

Option B: Children with constitutional delay are normal during the first year and fall behind till 3 years, after which the velocity becomes normal. Bone age is lower than chronological age(corresponds to the height age). The onset of puberty is also delayed and they achieve a normal final height. History of delayed puberty and delayed height spurt is usually present in one or both parents.

Option C: Children with Familial short stature have normal according to their own genetic potential determined by the parent's height. The body proportion is appropriate and bone age equals the chronological age with normal growth velocity. They achieve puberty at an appropriate age and their final height is within their target range. 

Option D: Children with growth hormone deficiency have bone age lower than chronological age and other signs like crowding of mid-facial structures, and depressed nasal bridge.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with complaints of syncope. ECG is suggestive of LV hypertrophy. A doppler echocardiography revealed abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral valve. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, can lead to vasodilation and may reduce preload. This reduction in preload can exacerbate the obstruction in the left ventricular outflow tract, worsening the symptoms in some patients with HOCM.

Smaller chamber size and increased contractility exacerbate the severity of obstruction. These include conditions of low preload, such as dehydration, and low afterload, such as arterial vasodilation.

Drugs that can lead to possible aggravation of outflow tract obstruction and thus contraindicated in HCM are:

  • Digoxin
  • Inotropes
  • Nitrates
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg- nifedipine, amlodipine)

Beta-blockers and verapamil are first-line agents in the treatment of HCM. Disopyramide and amiodarone are the preferred antiarrhythmic agents.

questions.text: Identify the following incision used for appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
• Lanz incision is a Transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis,2 cm below the  umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–midinguinal line
  • Rockey–Davis incision : Transverse right lower quadrant incision.
  • Gridiron incision : Oblique muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. Also called as Mc Burney incision.
  • Rutherford–Morrison incision : oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who is a labourer presents with weakness in the legs. He says that the weakness is more in the morning and it improves for a while as the day progresses. He is a known smoker. Examination reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton syndrome (LES). 

It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel. Patients typically present with weakness in their extremities. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength. Diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes help differentiate between LES and myasthenia gravis.

In about half the cases, there is an underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung -Small cell lung carcinoma. 

An increase in the compound muscle action potential (CAMP) amplitude after exercise or with high-frequency repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered to be of diagnostic significance.
